02-07-15: I think I would rate this as a 9.5/10 as a solo game, 8.5/8 as a 2-3 player game, and a 3 (!) with 4 players (official BGG rating meaning I would never ever play it with 4 again).

RATING: 10
This game might look ugly (at least part of it), but it's wonderfully deep and engaging. Definitely in my top five. The epic scale, strategic planning aspect and balanced character development keeps it engaging through six-hour sessions. Highly recommended to any hardcore gamer.

The rulebook and intro scenario book are great, in my opinion, and I have found that I actually have to consult BBG less than with many other games. On the whole the game is a tight, complex challange where you have to always keep your eyes on your goal to get there in the end.

Rating is based on few plays and might change.

EDIT: Have now played it a couple more times since giving the game a 10, and I'm NOT changing the rating. What a game!

RATING: 5
A solo game disguised as multiplayer game.

My first impression leaves me not entirely convinced. It is a glorified card game that feels too drawn out and chaotic, with lots of downtime and too much luck and AP for my taste. 

In the good and the bad it has the hallmarks of a Vlaada Chvatil design: some neat ideas, but ultimately feels like it's lacking proper development to truly realise its potential. Now it feels like it's stuck in a clunky prototype stage. 

I like some of the visuals, but overall the component quality does not impress me. I'd say it needs more plays to properly grok it, but ATM it doesn't interest me that much. 

Horribly expensive.

RATING: 9
I have played this as a solitaire experience several times and still do not know what the big deal is. I don't know whether I enjoy it or not. It's odd. More plays will tell, however introducing this to the kids is a bear, and will limit the time it sees on the table.

Update: I'm thinking this is one of the finer solitaire experiences around. Bumping this from 8 to a 9+. I'm still trying to introduce this to the kids -- and to a group we assemble every so often, but without success so far. It's certainly daunting, and we find we favor games we already know well to get on the table. We'll see though.

Update: Two things regarding component quality. (1) The cards from the expansion are clearly of different finish and quality than those of the base game. Sleeving the cards solves this problem handily. (2) The expansion tiles are definitely a different shade than the tiles from the base game. Simply use dice to make the appropriate tile selection, adjusting the results to account for the remaining tiles for the scenario. I prefer a d20 for this, as you can determine one chance in two (odd/even), one chance in three (1-6, 7-12, 13-18, rerolling 19,20), one chance in four (1-5, etc.), one chance in five (1-4, etc.), one chance in six (1-3, ..., rerolling 19-20), etc.

This way, you don't have any issue with, nor do you care about how the tiles look. You have a pool from which to select, and the dice make the selection. It's always just as much of a surprise as if the tiles were in a stack. 

:)

RATING: 10
I Love this game and as a beginner board gamer this is my first title, the thing that drew me to this game initially was the fact it could be played by ones self and after some research into solo board game this was the one that came out at the top of everyones list. I was worried initially wether or not to buy this game due to the multiple reviews of people saying how complicated the game was, but after completing the walk through twice and a read through the rules (which are quite long) I was away. I know can't get enough of this game and much to my wife despair I think this could be the beginning of a life long affair with board games and at the very least with Mage Knight. 

The game can take a while so it is a good idea to ensure you can complete the game in one sitting of at least have a space to leave it idle were it can't be disturbed until you can return. If you want a fun and enjoyable game that you're going to want to keep coming back to then look no further you've found it. 

Happy Playing,

RATING: 9
Love Mage Knight! I'll state that right off the bat. I just want to keep playing. And it wasn't until we compared it to its descendant "Star Trek: Frontiers" did we realize just how beautiful - artwork and components - and rich in gameplay - day and night, fortification, etc. - and immersive and magical the game really is (see my "Star Trek: Frontiers" comments. We had a difficult time getting started with it because back then we had such little experience with this type of game and flipping back and forth between the two manuals was a challenge. We put it on the shelf. Later, though, I kept having little flashbacks about its fascinating mechanics. Which game had the crystals? Which game had a shared mana base and a day and a night phase? Which game had a draft for a special ability? Which game had two actions to choose from on a card? Mage Knight?! Mage Knight! We played it again. Suddenly it all made perfect sense and I had SO MUCH FUN. We couldn't believe why we thought it was so hard.

RATING: 6.5
In short, I was glad that I played the game, I wouldn't mind playing it again, but I am happy that I didn't buy it. 

Here is what I didn't like:

- The down-time with four was pretty ridiculous, yes, it was learning game, and yes, this probably goes down with more plays... but still.

- The learning curve was steep. I was glad that somebody else was teaching the game because I would not want that job... so many little details - yes, most of them could be learned when they arose, but I couldn't help frequently asking myself, "what is this or that little detail adding to the game experience... would the game still be good without it?" I'm sure the rules aren't that complex once you get them but you need to be a hard-core gamer to go through the effort and most of my friends don't fit into this category.

- The theme. Actually, to answer one of my questions above, my impression was that many of the complex rules where there to further develop the theme. Indeed, insofar as the thematicness of a game is measured by the beautiful components and rules that directly represent thematic situations, the game is extremely thematic. For me, though, the theme didn't really work on another level - I like my heroes to be defined by some larger concern or struggle, but the heroes in this game are just seeking power. I don't find that thematically interesting. I think I would have enjoyed this kind of system much more had it been applied to a co-op or an accordingly balanced full-out confrontational game.

- This game is multiplayer solitaire with indirect confrontation of the annoying kind. Essentially, you interact with other players only by stealing things from underneath of their noses. My impression is that the game works kind of like this: a lot of your play is determined by circumstances created by other players... however, these players are generally playing to first and foremost further their own self-interest and not to hinder that of others... in most situations, hindering the interests of others is just inconvenient and would pull both the hinderer and the hindered behind everyone else. Thus, when someone effects someone else its because they happened to be in a position where it was possible for them to do this. In other words, the hindered person just got unlucky in a big way, which is't cool in this sort of game. 

So, those are my impressions of Mage Knight after a 3+ hour mini-learning game. It probably all sounds rather harsh but I'm just trying to look at it objectively. In fact, I didn't dislike the game and will probably like it more with more plays. However, I would be very surprised if my rating of this game would ever go higher than a 7.

RATING: 7.5
This is a thinking man's version of something akin to Runebound. Very tightly wound, there are a surprising amount of subtle rules to track (e.g. there are many location types and card types in the game) which leads to rules references and complexity. This is to be expected from any elaborate fantasy adventure game. I enjoyed it very much over all, and although it is true there is 'strategy' to the game, it's more a very well done adventure experience. The use of cards is smarter than I expected, but it certainly isn't a deck builder. More like a deck-driven action game. It takes a very long time to play out - which is expected as well, but exhausting. Still, very good game.

RATING: 9.2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Oh Bloody Chvátil, what have you done again. You have given us a rather simple game with so many layers that it has become very difficult to learn, memorise and teach the rules. It certainly is not a good quality to a game if you have to spend your first plays browsing through the rulebook pondering how everything works. Sure, you can watch the tutorial videos and read the rules and think "OK, now I've got this." But when it is the time to play, you will be facing so many exceptional situations that you just have to check, how it goes again. There is a need for tracking of so many things simultaneously, i.e., you are constantly flipping tokens, pushing tokens, drawing cards, playing cards, rolling dice etc. All this while trying to keep all the restrictions in mind. There are too many things you have to get into your kinetic memory.

Once every single player in the table gets a hang of it, the game becomes a smooth, fast and enjoyable experience. But I literally mean EVERYONE. Should there be even a single player who requires assistance with the rules, the flow is gone.

When it comes to the gameplay, I like the deck building and hand management aspect. It is a brilliant choice for a RPG style boardgame adding more decision making and strategy to the standard action point allocation system. It is also a nice thing that battles are not totally random. However, a hint of uncertainty and push-your-luck elements in the battle would have been nice. Not too random but just a tiny little bit. With a deterministic battle system you know exactly whether you can beat the monster or not. This does not encourage heroic moves against against all odds. 

In a nutshell, a fun game and a fun experience. However, I have a sneaking suspicion that Mage Knight is a single use fun. By single I mean that you'll probably play this quite a bit at one time of your life, but after that never again. Re-learning the game will be just too much of an effort for occasional playing, and hence the game will stay in your shelf untouched ever after, no matter how good it was and how fond memories you have of it. But if you have time, investing it in Mage Knight is not a bad choice.

RATING: 7
Thematically evocative of the Heroes of Might and Magic video game series, with a deep and satisfying hand management/deck building system to interact with the world. However, I'm not particularly interested in solo board gaming and large rules overhead and fiddly setup meant this was never really going to hit the table for 2+ players. Playing multiplayer also feels like everyone is playing a solo game, unless you opt for the PvP mode (which I did not try) - which adds even more rules complexity. The game also rewards really taking your time on turns to solve the puzzle in your hand, which creates a lot of downtime in multiplayer.

Removed from collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Mage Knight is probably THE adventure game on the market right now. It has beautiful components and you really get that feeling of leveling up and advancing with your character.
The difficulty of the different scenarios is quite high and challenging.
The 4 different mage knights only differ in their standard decks in 1 single card and in their different skills which they gain after leveling up. I felt that they could have put some more unique cards into the according decks to give every knight a totally different approach while playing but thats okay.
The game comes with various scenarios which arent predefined levels such as in 
descent or other dungeon crawlers but simply set up the game and give the instructions such as number of rounds to be played and so on.
Mage Knight can be played solo, cooperative and competetive, whereas cooperative feels more like a huge solo experience just with more players. The skills which were only made for this mode just show up too randomly to have any effects on the gameplay.
Competetivly played this game gets another boost since you always have to watch your back.
The real con of the game is its long amount of time to be played and the downtime when playing with other people.

Rating based on solo game only. Haven't played PvP or coop.

I like the puzzle-like nature of the game. Thinking about things like the interactions of the cards or what cards have come up and what cards remain to be used, while also considering the timing of movement and where to move, makes me feel like I am making interesting and even agonizing decisions. Often though, this makes for long turns for me.

Yes, there will be random features such as what is in the offer pile or what tiles come up but I like the fact that you need to adapt to the situation each time, almost every turn. So there feels like a grand strategy can be adopted but it is more of a tactical game in nature so if you do  not adapt, you will lose.

It seems like playing against or with others would simply take too long so I probably won't do it.

A lot of rules to remember, especially as it relates to the monster tokens and how to defeat them, and I find myself referring back to the rule book often even while considering my options. This breaks the immersion for me.

RATING: 9
Excellent game!  Brings a fantastic RPG feel to tabletop gaming.  I like how the deck building aspect drives the game (your options and available choices) without diluting the RPG elements.

Reasons I don't rate this higher:

(1)  Rules are not for the faint of heart (but it is emulating a RPG, so you should be expecting some rules complexity).

(2)  Not a fast play.  Yes, subsequent plays will increase speed, but the game does not lend itself to fast play.  Expect long games of this.

(3)  Bad luck early on carries through.  The rich get richer.  Success breeds success.  No catch up mechanism.  (How many different ways can I say the same thing?)

Notwithstanding the above, really an excellent game!

9/01/13:  Upping my rating to a 9.  (1) becomes better with repeated plays, as does (2).  (3) is true, but you have to be willing to push things and take some wounds.  Not the end of the world if the mob goes down, not at all.

Probably is best at 1 or 2 to avoid lengthy downtime and shorten the game.  I will be playing this more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Mage Knight is just an awesome board game!

It allows you to experience some of the coolest things about RPGs in board game form... and that's really an impressing achievement! You get to go on adventures, exploring and advancing with your character, recruiting allies, gaining powerful spells and fighting dangerous monsters. Yet, if this theme wasn't supported by a solid set of mechanisms, I wouldn't like the game so much... just like I don't like other games that are all theme and no game-play (Arkham Horror, I'm looking at you).

Mage Knight instead has a very cool action card system, with some very innovative elements. It offers you a puzzle every turn, as you have to figure out how to chain your cards to achieve your goal. The designer really managed to combine theme and mechanisms here. Absolutely brilliant! Furthermore the amount of game in this box is HUGE: you can play competitive, cooperative, different characters and different scenarios!

This game would be a 10 for me, if it wasn't for a few issues that make the game less enjoyable in my opinion. First, the game has a very dense rule-set and I know that it's part of what makes this title so cool... but I know for a fact that, if a designer would tackle this game today, they would be able to streamline it a lot. The game could really use some, especially for the combat mechanics, where things get seriously counterintuitive. The game is already long as it is, but if you add the constant rule checking before attacking the toughest monsters, things get quickly out of hand. 

The other problem I have with the game - and this is very personal - is the same I had with other games from Vlaada Chvatil: the scoring. I cannot wrap my head around the scoring system and I'm not sure that it's really a fair one. However this doesn't bother me in Mage Knight as much as it would in a strategy euro game. Because, even if I lose, I can find enjoyment in everything that I achieved during the course of the game. Yet, it still bothers me a tiny bit when we count up the points.

Therefore, summing up, I really really enjoy Mage Knight. It's an exciting adventure game that let's you experience things you wouldn't imagine possible in board game form. It's a perfect marriage of theme and mechanisms and I always look forward to play it. Yet in my opinion it could use some streamlining. If it was a bit smoother, this would be one of my favorite games of all time. Still great though! Highly recommended!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Mage Knight is a very good game.  I've played a lot of games in a very saturated field (fantasy battle) and this one carves out a unique niche and carves it out very well.  It plays so smoothly from start to finish.  It manages to combine a board game with a Magic The Gathering feel (without having the break the bank on new cards) and deck building.  It has a great solitaire system built in, it can be played cooperatively and it can be played competitively.  

Complexity:  Don't let it scare you off!  It is far less complex than it has been made out to be.  The game teaches you how to play using a walkthrough while using the rules as a reference rather than something to read cover to cover.  There are also many tutorials on the net that will help.  The complexity lies in the strategy and how best to utilize your cards and resources.  

Demerits:  I see two that are worth mentioning.  First, the components are not great quality (as has been stated before).  The cards bend easily and the tiles warp and don't sit flush on the table.  This is a minor quibble, however.  Secondly, will this game get old quickly?  There are a limited number of scenarios and the game expansions don't add a ton of variety.  To be fair, I've only played solo so the game might play completely differently with other players (I suspect it does).  And also to be fair, it hasn't gotten "old" for me yet and I've been playing for a while so these two concerns may be baseless.

RATING: 9
FAVOURITE GAME - It is one of the heaviest boardgames I have encountered. It combines a lot of mechanics. The game is scenario based, of which there are only a few, but the randomness of the setup makes every gameplay totally different. You start with a hero venturing out and discovering new tiles with new monsters and locations to defeat and explore, to gain precious influence, to be able to upgrade, and get on to stronger enemies. The turn is card management: you draw a number of cards and then move and take an action as your cards allow it. The combat system is very nice and usually won`t give you a bloodless fight. The rules are many, the handbook is not the greatest but the game is quite immersive. Although it can support up to 5 players, it is advisable to play in 2-player mode, as it can take up hours exploring the seemingly petit kingdom.

RATING: 10
Why I think you should play this:

*Mage Knight has a pedestrian theme. However, the generic narrative leaves a lot open-ended, and this assists in allowing you to build different characters different ways every time. Mage Knight is not an adventure game; it's a deck-building game with a fantasy theme. 

*This game has been called fiddly, but it shouldn't be compared to Euros. Instead, this is Magic Realm playable in an evening. When you read it in that vein, you see the economy of components and how enormous breadth has been contained in a pleasant and functional tactile experience.

*The gameplay is absorbing. [thread=864817]Beginner strategy here[/thread] and [thread=864916]Expert strategy here[/thread].

*Patrick Carroll makes a good distinction between 'god' and 'hero' games and in Mage Knight I think you are seeing the perfect blend. You are building your hero with personal customizations, but you are also above the game, manipulating it, not falling prey to the whims of chance. The world is randomly constructed but you control what you do in it. Definitely not an adventure game!

Why I might not recommend this:

*I play it exclusively as a solo experience and as a solo game this is definitively the best. I can see playing co-operatively with experienced players, but cannot see how this succeeds as a multiplayer game. The downtime issues are tremendous, and the options for conflict between players badly written up. I think for the time this takes to play, there are many, many better multiplayer conflict games.

RATING: 8
I played this 5 times at BGG Con 2011, even though it takes an eternity to play, which for me is a rarity.  Around 4-5 hours per play, and we were playing the 'shorter' two day scenarios like Blitz Conquest, with only 3 players.  About the only long games I like are this, Die Macher, and Through the Ages.  

The theme is excellent, and all of the game mechanics are exceptional.  I love the mana management, the deckbuilding, the hand management, and the wide variety of options available.  There are also tons of different scenarios, so you can tweak the game to your desires.   I love that you have options to do all sorts of things, even pillaging villages and burning down monasteries, and that these are sometimes or often good decisions, not just automatically terrible.  (Especially village pillaging, I feel is a critical part of strategy).

I ended up loving this game and wanting to repeatedly play it again, in spite of an enormous playtime, and thats extremely rare for me.


Update:  With 3 experienced players I've played Blitz conquest now in 3 hours.  Still too long but not by as much.

RATING: 8
I initially adored this game, but after 80+ plays (many including the expansion) I've developed some gripes. I still love it because it's basically the only fantasy adventure game on the market that's not a crappy dice fest. The core is extremely well designed but the rough edges become more magnified with continued play.

My primary concern is that the competitive balance is skewed by the random factors. While there can certainly be a runaway leader problem, the games that annoy me more are the ones where you lose by only a few points because of how the monsters became distributed. Getting a grey guard in the white city is still only worth three points despite how hard it is to kill while someone else might draw a more vulnerable enemy and get more fame. I feel like the competitive game would be more meaningful if you had to win by a certain percentage of points. Honestly I don't mind that much because playing the game is really engaging and pleasant. I don't get actually annoyed at the table because of losing by a few points but I feel like it's a problem on a design level. However, it's enough to make me want to play co-op to the exclusion of competitive.

Norowas is notably more luck dependent than the other characters. He can be a beast or lag behind and you don't have a ton of say in the matter in some games. 

The game is too easy at the default difficulty and the random factors become too decisive at higher difficulty levels. You need to find your sweet spot.

The scenarios are hit and miss. Dungeon Lords in particular is probably the most "fun" because you get to play with a pile of artifacts and other powerful cards but it magnifies the runaway leader problem and sucks the joy out of the game. 

update: lowered from 9 to 8 because of general disinterest due to how much I've played this. You generally get into the same patterns and the competitive play isn't as sound as I'd like. This is still the best adventure game on the market but my tastes are moving in a different direction. This is my main fix for a big sprawling fantasy game with lots of bits.

RATING: 8.7
One walkthrough play of the walkthrough scenario. 

First impression: Ghastly, horrid art and graphic design, on par with Runebound in that respect.

Second impression: Those rules aren't _that_ hard to swallow, wonder what's everybody complaining about? (Yes, I took my time with the game, didn't rush it, also I missed a few rules in my play, yet it took fewer visits to the BGG rules forum than usual to clear up the mysteries.) Maybe my dabbling in wargame territory has payed off in toughening me up somewhat in dealing with one of those a-big-pile-of-small-print rulesets?

Third impression: A game that never let's the player off the hook, involved and involving, a rich meaty dinner.

You can plan ahead quite a bit if you hang on to those cards, but it still doesn't feel overwhelming (at least on my beginner level of play... might change if you know the effect chains better)- you can still break it down into one puzzle per turn.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Mage Knight seems to be universally beloved. It's too big of a game for this comment box to go over every single aspect in detail. This game feels like the designer dumped every board game they own out onto a table and stuck pieces in, then added rules ad-hoc to explain the pieces. The bloat in this game is measurably ridiculous. Someone should've taken it through several streamlining procedures before allowing it to go to print. 

Most of the mechanics feel thrown in "just because" and all of them feel incredibly restrictive. Movement is an absolute chore. Overall, it feels like it takes a huge design philosophy from DnD 3.5/PF without any of the editorial graces. Hugely prescriptive lists of specific rituals to get this or do that make the game feel like an elaborate masturbation ritual. You "do" a lot but don't get a lot "done". Wounds are yet another incredibly restrictive mechanic added into the game that compound your existing restrictions. Some may find the "new challenge every turn, let's McGuyver a solution from just this hand and a wad of bubblegum" vibe to be fun. Me and my group did not at all.

Most things in this game range from inefficient to useless, though a rare few cards/skills/units/whatever did feel about mid-powered. Monsters were just numbered tokens with no personality and several don't even move. The game is not even technically multiplayer. Players are all off doing their own thing on their turns, mostly ignoring each other completely. Very rarely do they interact and it's ALWAYS extremely bad. Usually for both of them. This is a solo game for 1-6 players, where you compare score at the end for no good reason. To that end, wounds essentially just prohibit your actions (read: make you lose entire turns, how fun) which only ultimately result in less win points at the end. 

I calculated it takes 16 strong move actions to traverse 8 map tiles in one game and you only get 20 possible turns in a 6-round game if you add cards at every round. Which you may not do since adding cards to the deck is, yet another prohibitively slow and difficult task. Cards that you add don't even feel more than 25% more powerful than your starting deck in most cases and in some cases feel the same or WORSE.  But in a game where you're lucky to get two-to-three strong move actions a round, getting across 8 tiles is incredibly difficult especially if you have to reveal half yourself. 

Combat is a whole can of worms. Aside from being a sterile affair of "play cards at it until it dies", range attacks happen first and are the only non-prohibitive way to kill something without taking massive wounds. Melee will basically just get you stacked with wounds after a while as you need to block the full amount of attack as well as have your own attack be the full amount of their HP. Or some combination of taking wounds and not killing it occurs. Don't get me started on defenses/resistances/fortifications which are all just the same thing only worded slightly differently so you have to turn the knob a few degrees to the left depending on which word was used...

There are almost no redeeming qualities in the game except the cute crystal pieces. Even the character roster is incredibly misogynistic. The ONE female character (of SIX) is a psychopathic blood-loving crazy person who wears almost no clothing. Overall this game is a hard pass for me and apparently very polarizing for other gamers from what user reviews have to say.

RATING: 6.5
It's a reasonably good game, though it falls short in a lot of ways that make me pretty sad.  At first it looked like a spiritual successor to Magic Realm, but gone is the sense of adventure and exploration - rather, it's a clean-ish puzzle game with decent theme where you play as a dude running around a map trying to level up and kill some cities or something.

Luckily, the core gameplay is solid.  Unfortunately, it takes forever - which is surprising, because there are significantly fewer important decisions than in other long games like TI3 or Civ.  The puzzle game core is very limiting, and while it's a fun enough puzzle game it never did impress me too much.

This floats somewhere between 6 and 7 I think.  It's a 7 when I really appreciate the overall mechanics, and then drops down to a 6 after I actually play it and remember that for all the good, it's ultimately disappointing.  An interesting core that was overdesigned into a sort of bland mess via specifics.  Regardless, the competitive rules make it more enjoyable and the puzzle itself is interesting, so that's a plus...

RATING: 8.5
Mage Knight is a tough game to really collate my thoughts about. It's a tough game with a very steep learning curve. BUT, once you get though the 4 maybe 5 games it takes to EVEN LEARN the game it becomes simply amazing! It's an epic in every way! The feeling one comes to when one burns a monastery, lay waste to a city, delve a dungeon and roam across the lands purge all you see is simply brilliant! But the game can also be absurdly frustrating with the limitations, the overly complex rules, the limitations brought on by hands not giving you want you want and not having a good way to mitigate it.Its a game that does not feel consistent. Some games feel puzzle like and dull with horrible hands and lack of options, others feel like the world is ready to tremble below your heels. Mage Knight can be a very good game and one that scratches a very nice itch, but more than often its a complicated mess that outstays its welcome. Approach with caution, and give in to the game when you arrive.

RATING: 9
1-4(2)

Okay, so there is plenty of rules complexity, like nearly every Vlaada game there are all sorts of idiosyncracies and some corner cases and etc. (you can attack marauding orcs from one square away, but you must siege a keep by moving onto it). The rulebooks remain, as is Vlaada's trademark, pretty difficult to use as a reference.

But, still, I loved it. It was a great game. I've only done the intro Recon mission, which didn't introduce many of the advanced elements and, though it introduced spells, we never managed to get any spells, so it did feel like a very curtailed version of the game.

Still, this is a fascinating deck-builder. Every player has a (very slightly) different deck and different abilities. It's great because it makes your game and your deck individual, but isn't as prone to horrible "A Few Acres of Snow"-esque imbalance. There is a real, thematic flow to the game, and you actually do feel like you're doing what it says on the tin (exploring, fighting, and all that).

The basic action / enhanced (with mana) action deal is brilliant in combining a form of resource management with hand management. You actually feel like you can do something most every turn ... but just not quite enough. It's a really slick system.

The downsides are pretty apparent. The fiddliness is sometimes over the top: so, wait, when do I gain a reputation and when do I lose it? Oh, wait, can I even recruit this guy here? The rules, I reiterate, are tough to reference in-game. You don't get *quite* the same deck-building feel because (at least in the Recon mission) you cycle your deck so few times, meaning you get benefits from some cards only a few times. And then, everybody starts out with (nearly) the same deck and the opportunities to differentiate are sort of far in between (every other level you get a unique skill and advanced action) that it feels like you're playing similar games with just different draw orders.

Still, I'm being really critical. We had a lot of fun with this and time flew by while we were playing. This is top-shelf stuff and I'm eager to try it again.

RATING: 5
Mage Knight confirms that long fantasy adventure games are not for me.  Whenever the playing time edges over two hours (and Mage Knight goes way over that), I'd always sooner play an RPG.  The rinse and repeat of move, kill monster, gain allies over four or five hours simply isn't enough to hold my attention.  

At first glance, Mage Knight does add an interesting deck building element to traditional fantasy adventure elements.  It allows wounds to be handled nicely by adding useless cards to your deck.  However, I found how the deck operates in practice not to my liking.  Here is my fearsome warrior unable to slay a puny orc because...I currently have a hand full of movement and influence cards.  And my deck cycles slowly, so I can spend a while standing next to that orc, doing nothing.  That may simulate that I'm not actually very fearsome, but I prefer a system that gives me a chance to do something, albeit at low odds.  Colour me Ameritrash, I guess. The limitations imposed by the mana/crystal  system seemed to work better.  Victory point scoring for a variety of things struck a bum Euro-efficiency note with me; I find complete the quest/kill the ultimate monster sorts of goals much more satisfying. 

As in many adventure games, there is a fair bit of down time.  I wouldn't play again with more than three players.

The pre-painted miniatures are quite nice and the tiles and cards are all good quality.  I found the artwork pretty undistinguished.  None of it creates an impression of a non-generic fantasy world.  Some of the iconography on counters is quite hard to see.

RATING: 8
I've only played a handful of games solo, but it's already on of my favorites. High on strategy, low on luck - this one will give your brain a good workout, if you play it properly. I am not a huge fan of deckbuilding games outside of MtG, but this combo of deckbuilding and board game really struck a chord with me.

Pros:
Gameplay
Modular board
Replayability
Artwork
Pre-Painted mini's / pawns and Components (except for the cards)
Walkthrough rulebook and separate full rulebook.

Cons:
Rules could be written much better. They make is seem much more complex then it is (Arkham Horror is much harder to work, IMO).

Cards - The art is good, but the card stock is flimsy and on the cheap end. By my 2nd play, I already had the print on the back of a few cards start to slough off. This is rather bad, considering the cards will be the most used and handled component. I'm not one to sleeve cards, usually, but I HIGHLY recommend sleeving this one. I only hope WizKidz steps up and makes the cards to be a bit more sturdy in later prints.

Warnings:
Length - I like the length for solo play, but I can already see that playing this with 4 or 5 players will take a great deal of time. (45 mins to an hour per player)

It may not be for everyone, but I love it.

RATING: 10
An excellent fantasy RPG board game. A short and concise rulebook is needed because you get lost in the actual ones when search for details. This game provide good complexity and great strategies but with the cost of many hours spent. Is not so easy to learn and have many exceptions hard to find in rulebook... searching will eat time too, but when learned to be played offer many satisfactions and good feeling. 
Conclusion: need 10-20 games to learn to play it well and without time dragging. Rating goes from 9.5 - 9.6 up to full 10 after only 8 plays!
In fact the only regret is that it don't play a bit faster and this keep this wonderful game out of the table considering that few friends have so much time to spend with a single game session. Play best with 1-3 players.
 
Best style of play: competitive without PvP.

Plays status with expansion included: 
- starting scenario with 5 players - 6+ hours
- played in 2 and 3 players a blitz conquest and game took around 4-6 hours.
- full conquest (2players) - 6+hours
- played mines liberation (2 players) - 5+hours
- played dungeon lords scenarios (2players) -6+ hours(Obs.: a blitz variant work if you exclude all non-dungeons,village,monasteries green tiles and you put red enemies only on core tiles secret tombs, brown on countryside tiles even near monasteries or you'll have to fight red monsters at the start of the game)  
Is nice that you have variety in choosing from few different kind of scenarios with different goals.

Amazing experience! Is a game that you'll dream playing if you don't play it. Have somehow the feeling of Heroes of Might&Magic or King's Bounty on a board.

RATING: 6.5
15-5-2013
Played 3 times solo. One introductory scenario, and 2  conquest solo.

Pros
-Diverse. All 3 games played out very differently. 

-Solid as a puzzle game. There doesn't seem to be a way to "break" the game.

-Good solo. As a result of the first two points above.

-Many options. This is a mixed blessing. I like the calculation part but it may lead to AP with the wrong crowd.

Cons
-Ridiculous battle mechanics. (not to mention ANTI-THEMATIC).

-Deck building is tertiary to the game, although pronounced by everyone in bgg. Also it doesn't help immersion.

-Very fiddly.

-Very long game. Needlessly so as a result of the point above. A solo can last 3 hours including setup which is too long for what actually transpires in the game. 

-Unnecessarily random at crucial points especially unit offer. I suppose that this will become a factor in PvP.

-[b]Very bad manual.[/b] It is one of the worst organized rules book that I've ever read. The split rules are a mixed blessing. Sometimes they help sometimes they confuse. I acknowledge the help they provide to the newbie but at the end it doesn't help the same newbie to master the game.

Conclusion: Don't believe the hype. This game is good but not that good. I don't think it deserves it's top 10 status.

update 19-07-2013:
I am beginning to like it more and more. It still has defects but at least it is rewarding and diverse. Bumped from 7 to 8.

RATING: 9.1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
MageKnight is a huge complicated beast that will be true love for a certain crowd. I am not one of that crowd for a couple reasons, but I still want to do it justice because it's such an interesting design. 

Pros: the open modular nature of the board, the dual-mode cards, and to a lesser degree the magic system are innovative and appealing. Add to that the inherent joy of RPGs (leveling dudes and upgrading decks is super fun) and you have a formula for a great time. If long, heavy RPGs with in-depth rules systems appeal to you (maybe you played a lot of Baldur's Gate back in the day and really enjoyed the character min-maxing) MK is probably your jam. 

Cons: there are two main obstacles between me and that jam. First, I'm turned off by lazy, generic fantasy art, and Wizkids is a repeat offender. The board tiles themselves are fine, but many of the card illustrations are just ugly, literalist art ("Promise" is an image of two armored fists shaking hands, etc). Add to that the uninspired theme (blah blah, kill some orcs) and the requisite chainmail bikinis and the product is a game that doesn't inspire me as a mature adult gamer. If you played Baldur's Gate for the storyline and artistry, this will turn you off. 

The second issue is more arguable: the game has a few too many interconnected rules systems layered on top of one another to seem entirely coherent. To some this is the grand beauty of Vlaada's design, but to me this just seems busy and an unnecessary barrier to entry. Too many "bells and whistles" distracting from the core of the game; I'd prefer something a little more streamlined. Day/night is the perfect example: it's kind of interesting from a design perspective, but I don't feel it is a necessary addition to the game's complexity. 

To sum up, this is an RPG for the strategy wonk in the room who could care less about aesthetics and design elegance. For me, I'd rather be playing Imperial Assault, Gloomhaven, or just D&D...

Mage Knight finds itself in the opposite plane of existence within my board game collection, as opposed to T.I.M.E. Stories - while I complain about the latter in terms of my perception of its lack of strategy and meaningful decisions (which as I note in my comment about that game is caused by my misconception of that game and how it is supposed to be played, but I have yet to try it again with the correct mindset) - I have issues with this game itself in terms of just how much tactical focus exists and how it really slows down the game and drags it on without any real excitement to it.

RATING: 8
You are going to be frustrated. Because this game is hard and complex. Mind you it is still fun. The components are awesome with beautiful artwork on the tiles and well painted minis to boot. But there are just sooooooo many mechanisms you are trying to keep track of. A very slow deck building aspect combined with dice rolling, hand management and host of others. There is even a dummy player for 2-player game (though it isn't as bad in this game and just acts as a timer) There is an exploration aspect to this game that we love as we uncover new locations and enemies. That part we love. But that brings us to the part we loathe. The combat in this game is just too fiddly to keep up with. The rule book even advises you that you should ask other players for help in combat. So Vlaada has made an awesome gamers version of a fantasy adventure game. But maybe we just aren't gamers enough for it.

RATING: 7
Se trata de un Eurogame "camuflado" como juego de aventuras. Las acciones vienen determinadas por la eficiencia de tu baraja y no se tiran dados. Básicamente debes saber administrar las cartas de tu mano para sacar el máximo partido a cada uno de tus turnos. Existe un componente de exploración y otro de aventura pero a diferencia de juegos como Runebound aquí se tiene un mayor control de la situación y muchas veces estás planeando tu turno actual pensando en que debes guardarte tal carta para utilizarla dentro de un par de turnos.
El sistema de juego es bastante propenso al AP y la partida puede hacerse muy larga cuando no se tiene demasiada experiencia.

RATING: N/A
Reviews of Mage Knight are common, but a few of my friends asked me to share my thoughts on the game. So, here they are! I'll update this review after a few more games, if I feel it's necessary. I'll mostly be talking about the *feel* of the game, which I don't expect to change.

This review is for gamers newish to the tabletop scene who are interested in diving headfirst into something complex and magical.

**First Impressions**

Mage Knight is a heavy game. The first thing you'll see when you open the box are two rulebooks - One is a walkthrough, the other is a reference guide. Both seem pretty great, but they're a little confusing when it comes to combat. I recommend printing off a few of the guides from the BGG Files page for quick reference.

The introductory walkthrough does a great job of helping you set up the game step-by-step. It introduces the mechanics to you *as they come along*, instead of all at once up front. You don't even draw some of the cards you can eventually buy until you reveal a certain tile in the first game, so there's that much less to wrap your head around.

**Components**

The game has four minis for your heroes and four minis for the cities you discover in the game. The cities are neat, but the heroes are *rad*. The paint and figure quality on the heroes is spectacular.

The monster tokens are cardboard punch-out tokens, *but* they're already punched and in a nice little plastic tray with a clear plastic lid for storage. They have a good enough weight and feel to them, and they're easy to place onto and remove from the board.

The hex tiles feel about as solid as any Twilight Imperium or Catan piecies.

Everything fits in the box *just so*, with no extra room for cards to shift around. Note, if you sleeve your cards, they won't fit in the insert.

**Gameplay**

It's awesome, but it's complex as hell. The gameplay is fun, it takes forever, and it's intense. When you figure out how to overcome an obstacle with the resources you have, it feels like you just finished a puzzle. Scraping by a monster by the skin of your teeth at the beginning of the game makes smashing strong enemies with powerful abilities later in the game *incredibly* satisfying.

It feels like an adventure RPG video game mixed with a tabletop D&D session and a deckbuilder card game.

**Time**

I played the "First Reconnaisance" mission, the walkthrough scenario, over the course of three days. I was able to leave the game set out on our dining room table, and it was easy to pick up and play for an hour or so each day.

This is a game you'll need to set aside a big chunk of time for a full scenario, at least a few hours. I've heard that each added player (up to four) significantly increases playtime.

**Experience as a new player**

I just barely beat the introductory scenario, which is focused on exploration and teaching you the mechanics of the game. 

The rampaging enemies were tough to beat at the beginning of the game, but I managed to defeat two enemies at once while exploring ruins by the final round. This game gives you a real sense of progression, as you add stronger cards to your deck and more units to your command.

I ended up with one movement tile still unexplored, and I hadn't found The City yet. I had just exhausted the dummy player's deck, which meant the game was over at the end of my turn. I managed to use the last of my resources and my last available unit to discover the final tile and reveal The City. 

I spent around ten minutes putting the cards and pieces back in the spots and set the box on the shelf. I already want to take down the box again and start my next adventure.

**Thoughts**

If you like fantasy-themed video games and books, if you like tabletop games like Dungeons and Dragons or Twilight Imperium, and if you have a great deal of patience; I recommend this game. 

I paid around $65 after shipping from an online store, and a local game store has it in stock for about $80. After my first playthrough, I think $80 would have been a reasonable price for the game. I can already tell it's going to give me hours, maybe days, of enjoyment. I'm looking forward to sharing the game with my friends, and I look forward to rainy days at home with this game sprawled across my table.

------------------------------

FIRST REVIEW
This game is flippin' gorgeous. The minis, the tiles, the cards, everything looks and feels solid. Even the rulebooks feel like they're printed on high-quality paper, and there are two of 'em! A walkthrough for the first playthrough, and a rulebook for reference.

I started the tutorial mission, and my confidence in the size of my table wilted with each newly placed component. This game has a sprawl factor, I think.

I'll write a full review once I've got a few plays under my belt, but so far - This game seems amazing.

RATING: 7
Leading off with a 7 after two 2P plays of the intro scenario, which means the rating is hardly conclusive.  I like it, and think it could be great for those that can really dedicate time to it.  For me, it's harder to picture getting lots of value out of it with infrequent play, especially with requisite rules consulting.  It's also hard for me to picture enjoying it with more than 2P because of the potential downtime.  I think I like it a good deal more than Prophecy, and could actually see enjoying an epic length playing of it.  Hope to read the rules myself and revisit soon, while the iron is still hot.  I consider it an adventure game with a splash of deckbuilding, which kind of surprised me given the emphasis on the deckbuilding aspect.  I could see that coming a bit more into play on longer scenarios, but still not a lot of churn and zero (AFAIK) shaping.  If it sounds remotely interesting, I highly recommend trying it with 2P.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My favorite designer has put together another winner. While the high fantasy theme of Mage Knight is a fairly  dull, run-of-the-mill, orc-fest -- the game itself is epic.

Most of the stuff we see in this genre is either a dungeon crawl (like decent), or some sort of Magic: The Gathering clone.

Mage Knight tells a much broader tale.  Instead of trudging through a dungeon or engaging in some sort of spell-slinging wizard duel, you trudge through multiple dungeons and sling many spells.  You also raise your own army or followers and can even burn down the occasional monastery just for fun.

There are several Vlaada trademarks in this design.  One of which is his tendency to resolve critical gameplay moments with a kind of puzzle solving rather than a die role.  The plus side is that it can be very satisfying to play your hand of cards in just the right way as to move to the wizard tower and defeat the guardian there, while still having enough left over to bank a mana crystal for the next round.

The downside is that sometimes there are moments in the game that lose their dramatic punch as everything has already been worked out by the time it's your turn.  It's one thing to see a battle hinge on that critical die roll it's another to have the maths already in your pocket and have it all just "work out".

Still there is so much variety and strategic opportunities in this game that it really deserves your attention.  It's a true exploration game done right(much like High Frontier actually), where you really feel like you are earning every new encounter, every spell, every artifact.

Warning:  This is best explored first on your own (a few solo rounds will be really helpful), and then probably with one other experienced player.  Don't dive into a 4-player game with all newbies.

RATING: 7
Az utóbbi évek egyik legsikeresebb szerzőjének egyik legsikeresebb játéka... nekem mégsem annyira jött be. A szerzőnek szinte minden ismertebb játékát jobbnak érzem, de tény, hogy műfajilag ez áll tőlem legtávolabb. Elismerem, hogy a játék tényleg nagyon össze van rakva, de ebben nem érzem azt az átütő eredetiséget, mint a TTA-ban, a Dungeonokban, vagy a Space alertben. A szerző szerintem minden témában tudna egy működőképes és viszonylag komplex játékrendszert alkotni, és még csak nem is a megszokott paneleivel (néhány kivételtől eltekintve)... de ezen a játékán kicsit azt éreztem, mintha megrendelték volna tőle, hogy legyen egy ilyen típusú is. Egyébként sokszor újrajátszható, többféle játékmód van (kooperatív, felfedező, egymás elleni...), szépen meg van csinálva, de szerintem nem nagyobb durranás, mint mondjuk az Odalent. Ráadásul baromi hosszú a szabály, és maga a játék is elnyúlhat. Nekünk (igaz, hogy 1. parti volt) 1 napszak majdnem másfél óráig tartott, és egy hosszabb küldetés 6 napszakból áll. Elpakolni se két perc, de a doboza nagyon dicséretes, ugyanennyi tartalommal általában 2-3-szor ekkora dobozokban adnak ki egy játékot! Én egyébként egyre kevésbé szeretem azokat a sok kellékes játékokat, ahol azt érzem, hogy a rengeteg féle jelölő meg pakli öncélú. Ez is kicsit ilyen. Maga a pakliépítés és paklikezelés viszont rendben van. Ami negatívum: a holtidő már 3 fővel is nagy volt sajnos. A szerencse szerepéről: egyikünk végig a rossz lapjárásra panaszkodott, a végén viszont egy jó lapkahúzással kb. megduplázta a pontjait, és nyert is. Nem is tudom... mindenképp játszani kell még vele. Érdekes, de nem látom még, hogy miért top 10...és miért top1 tematikus játék.
---
Egyet aludtam rá, végül úgy döntöttem, az Odalent-tel megegyező pontszámot kap. Először kevesebbet adtam, de végül is kb. az a szint. Az Odalent valamiért nekem kicsit nagyobbat ütött, talán mert az volt az első ilyesmi, amit próbáltam. Kár, hogy már nem adok fél pontokat, most indokolt lett volna... Amúgy mindkettővel kellene még játszanom.

RATING: 5
I know I'm really going against the grain here but I can't believe how highly ranked this game is.  I can see why someone would like it, it's not awful.

First, I don't think the mechanisms in this game are thematic at all.  I'm so surprised people see this as a thematic game.  Imho it is completely abstract.  I never felt like I was attacking an orc or assaulting a mage tower.  I was just doing the math before making my move and then, well, not doing that action if the math didn't add up.  So no suspense

Second, what's the reward for putting in all the work? I didn't feel like I conquered anything.  If a mage knight's job is to read a rule book over and over again just to find out that nope, i can't beat that dungeon, and then waste my time moving 2 spaces instead, then wait 20 minutes to go again, I don't want to be a mage knight.

Third, I didn't feel any strategy, everything is tactile.  Now that would normally be fine but to make tactile mechanisms so difficult to learn is just cruel.  It's fun to boggle the brain with the "why" of doing something (strategy) but to melt my brain with the question of how I can accomplish simple actions is just plain wrong.

In short, boy am I glad I rented this before buying.  ALL HYPE

although if you love this game, that's cool too!

RATING: 10
Wow, I am amazed. Vlaada is without any doubt the most versatile games designer around.

I normally hate adventure games, because they usually are boring dicefests where one goes around killing everything he ecounters. So, a long (very long) adventure game is one of the less likely games I would possibly like.

But I absolutely love Mage Knight.

It has theme, it has replayability, it has very small doses of luck, it can be played cooperatively or competitively. Furthermore, one can do good or evil deeds, and both have consequences!

This is a great, innovative design. It puts the deckbuilding mechanic inside a true game (the only other design doing that is A Few Acres of Snow), but there is also much more to love: the mana management is so clever, the day/night alternance is brilliant, the tactics card are another touch of great design...

Mage Knight would be on my personal top10 if it would be a shorter game. BUT, would a shorter Mage Knight have the same appeal?
Don't know, but if it can stand another handful of plays retaining the same level of excitement, it would enter the top10 anyway...

Update july 14, 2012: after 10 games, the awesomeness of Mage Knight strikes me even more! What a wonderful masterpiece! I even had a couple solo plays (and I normally don't care playing solo...) and they were amazing! Now I am convinced the game needs its length to be so epic... if only I'd be able to squeeze some more games in my tight timetable...
Rating upgraded to 9.5!

Update february 25, 2013: after more than 25 plays, I am fully convinced that this game needs to be at the top. The only game of this lenght and complexity I ever rate this high. It's a 10!

RATING: 9
Known as one of the premier solo games, the divisive Mage Knight can be difficult to learn and is best approached with long-term commitment in mind. There are lots of rules and the gameplay is not always obvious, but with a patient approach the game will yield its subtle rewards. Once you understand how it works, it is not exceedingly complex; and if you continue to play often, you will be able to retain the necessary information rather easily. It's a multi-faceted adventure that is wholly engaging. It's a great game for getting your mind off of your troubles because it invariably commands your full attention; I never find myself losing interest, and the time tends to fly by. If anything, be on guard against analysis paralysis, and figuring out your turn can be a brain-burning process at times (perhaps another reason why this game really shines in solo play). One drawback to the game is that it can feel rather mechanical, as stories do not tend to develop as much as fantasy fans may prefer; there are no events at all, and though encounters are random, the particular enemies that show up are rather inconsequential thematically. Know thyself -- if you can handle the barrier of entry and you enjoy the mechanical process of maximizing your efficacy and building combos, you will be rewarded with a rich, fulfilling experience. This isn't a game to pull out on a whim every couple of months -- the more you invest in Mage Knight on a regular basis, the more you'll get out of it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Having a difficult time scoring this game... I give it a 9/10 based solely off of my impressions of it as a solo game.  It is a great game and probably my favorite solo game at the moment.  There is a lot to keep track of, but it is manageable as things flow accordingly.  This game isn't a game that you are going to play correctly or without looking things up on your first several plays, but don't let that discourage you.

I just dove in and played after watching some videos and skimming through the walkthrough.  I later learned I made some mistakes, but it allowed for me to understand the game some so when I read through the walkthrough again, it made much more sense and was easier to grasp what was going on.

I recommend this game anyone that is looking for a deep game that takes up a lot of time and to those that think they would enjoy a puzzle like adventure with a bit of D&D type theme as well.  I recommend people take advantage of BGG and all the resources they have available for the game as it makes it easier to follow and learn.

This is a game I'm enjoying more and more with each play.  It is definitely not for anyone that does not like a rules heavy game.

After numerous plays and after having played many other games, I'm upgrading my initial rating from a 9 to a 10.

Score is going back down to a 9 because it is too demanding, time wise.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Ok,
I finally got this game. Bring it on!

Edit after 8 plays: I remember this game to be more exciting. It is a puzzle, and it turns out I don't like solitaire games that much. 
As a solitaire, I really enjoy it. I play one round, and then immediately start playing the next one. But I would always swap a Mage Knight session solo for a multiplayer game (Agricola, Runewars, even Castles of Burgundy).
As a thematic game, the first time I played it (not my copy), I thought it's the most thematic game ever. Because it has orcs, dragons, resistances, cities, etc. However, after trying Robinson Crusoe, Mage Knight seems almost abstract, with a pasted on theme. The game doesn't react to your actions in the thematic way as Robinson did (You have diarheea now because two turns before you ate a dead goat).
Also, the game has soooo many rules. I still have the manuals near me, and I consult them several times per session. The playtime is long, but it is a good investment for an epic feel after a session.

Now the paradox: although the game is convoluted and with so many rules, I won 6 out of 8 sessions (and other 2 games with Goldyx I have abandoned, I am still figuring this guy out, his skills are sub-par in my opinion). The ease with which I won this games (city level 4) made me wonder about this game solo replayability. I won with Arythea, and this bitch is just awesome and easy to play. I won with Torvak, and this guy is a little clunky, and lacks firepower. However he is great defensively, and can take a lot of abuse. Unfortunately, that doesn't help him to kill monsters and conquer cities, which you ultimately have to do.
After walking over level 4 cities as a simple breeze, I tried to increase difficulty to level 5 and 8. I lost. Then, downgraded 2nd city to 5. And I was wining easily. Until I tried Goldyx. This guy has bad skill, or I just don't know how to play him. From 4 attempts, I abandoned 3 games as hopeless, and won another in the last tour of the last night. That was a close call for sure, as I had to conquer 2 cities in just one night. Fortunately I was stoked with powerful spells, powerful allies, powerful Advanced actions, artifacts and crystals. It was a force showcase.
And now, I am playing my 5th session... with Goldyx. This game has something, that you want to play one more turn. Sign of a good game? Perhaps. 
Overall, Mage Knight is a frustrating affair for me. It is not the kind of game where you have light fun, like let say... Arcadia Quest, where you kill some monsters and have fun. But the difficulty of the game also makes it very good as solo game. And that alone will keep it in my collection, as I totally lack solo games. I still have a lot of content to explore in this game , as I have played only solo conquest scenario   up to now.

RATING: 5
Euro dungeon crawl at its finest.  Battles are determined by making the most efficient card combo. The lands are arranged to get harder as you advance so skipped content doesn't usually get revisited. The only flavor are cards with generic fantasy names and the finely crafted prepainted minis you most efficiently move around with. Doing good and evil tasks are only based on what is most efficient. I had no difference in feelings between burning a monastery down versus saving a village, just whatever gave the max loot and VP reward.

RATING: 4
First Play: We all pre-read the rules watched the videos and were ready to hit the ground running. However the game slowed to a crawl immediately. Every turn needed cross reference to the rules over wording or meaning and not all the rules are in one book so each turn was tortuously slow. As a result the down time between turns was massive. Combine that with the fact that you have no idea what move the player next to you will take so you cannot pre-plan with any confidence.

The cards predictably dont fall pat so I found myself unable to move to my desired location, unless I burnt the cards I needed to use when I got there. Once in the night phase the mana dice turned rapidly black and single coloured so I literally could not use enhanced benifits on any deed cards.

All in this was the epitome of frustration. A tedious experience of waiting for your turn and then not being able to do what you would like to (at all). And way way too long.

I am told this is the pain you must endure to reach the inner beauty of the game. That maybe the case if you play with the same group, but I play with a wide range of players and most sessions involve teaching a new comer a game. There would always be this inertia for my circle of gamers.

I found this a souless and ghastly experience that I never want to repeat. A rating of 4 reflects the quality of production, otherwise I would rate this a 2.

RATING: 10
Very impressive game. If you're heavily into this, this could be that one game of a lifetime.

I'm not a dungeon crawl kind of guy. At all. Infact, I haven't liked any of the other games of this style that I've tried. But this game is sufficiently euro that I can join in.

I really like the cardplay here. Also, the game really is very immersive.

But, I have only played it solo so far. The fact that I don't like solo gaming or computer gaming in general, but still enjoy this solo, probably says a lot about the quality of this game.

I will probably try to play it with someone else, but man, I'm afraid how long it will take. Even solo, the advertised 150 minutes playing time is crazy optimistic. That might be the playing time if you're very experienced, but two or three newbies, let alone 4, playing this is gonna take forever.

One thing that feels slightly frustrating is that once you're about to get going and have a few strong cards in your deck, the game is over. It is probably the correct decision from a designer perspective though.

So overall, this did not in any way look like my kind of game, but I still enjoy it very much. If it DOES look like your kind of game, then I think you are in for a real treat.

RATING: 8.5
An incredibly deep strategy adventure game. The number of interactions available to the player is quite high. I believe the rules are less complex than many people suggest, but there are quite a bit of "fiddly" rules to remember. In such and such situation you do X but in every other situation you have to do Y. You can only do A/B/C if conditions D/E/F are met. There are dozens of rules that follow this pattern and you'll be referencing the two rule books for a while until you've encountered every odd combination of situations.

The only reason I'm not rating this a 10 or higher is because of BGG's rating suggestions. It is an EXCELLENT game, however I am not able to play it "all the time". Or necessarily willing. It takes a good chunk of time to set up, and then longer yet to play. I'm not opposed to long games, but long solo games (MK isn't ONLY solo but I think it's best solo) are harder to justify.

I would say the game is a 10 for quality, innovation, and thoroughness of world design and an 8.5 for "how often I want to play it".

RATING: 9
I love this game! 

It's immensely satisfying to feel your character level up with a custom pool if skills that you've been building and when you eventually start taking out monsters that could easily murder you just a little bit earlier in the game. And yet at the same time everything you encounter is a new mini-puzzle as you try to figure out the best way to approach the ruins/keep/rampaging monster/etc to maximize your turn. And the biggest battles, whether it is a castle or the boss guy in the lost legion expansion really feel as tough and epic as you would expect! 

Every turn feels important and will engage you greatly throughout the whole experience

However, I don't think I would ever suggest playing this at 3+ players - especially if anyone's prone to AP. And the rules did take a while to learn the nuances of, but if you start this game expecting that it won't feel like a problem at all. Just sit down and set aside an evening for it and treat it like any other book.....

Also - I feel the lost legion expansion isn't absolutely essential, but it will make your solo and co-op players feel better. Feels like your gearing up for this huge threat that's marching your way rather than an empty feeling timer.

***Played 10+ times at 1-4 players as of this posting  No sight of getting tired of this game***

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Beyond its pompous skirmishes-evoking title, Mage Knight is just another half-successful attempt by the same author at making a crossover between euros and ameritrash: nevertheless, despite his good will, rules and mechanics are still the core of a soulless game desperately trying to look thematic.

Ultimately playing Mage Knight feels more like an act of devotion to the playing mechanics in itself than a mind-relaxing pastime as it should be: the goal of this game indeed isn’t having fun as much as mastering the rules and making the best out of them, just like any other euros do.
The one difference between those and Mage Knight is you don’t have wooden cubes or discs here but four pre-painted, D&D Miniatures-quality figures instead of meeples, some fancy dice (all of them d6) to randomize the wooden cubes in play and a handful of plastic pieces acting the same as differently-colored wooden cubes would: like those though the game is card-driven, prevents randomness, punishes risky actions and requires every player to carefully choose how to best use the few actions he’s allowed to perform in a turn, each of them only once per in-game day or night. 

The actions on these cards are pretty limiting, so that you never feel like you can do what you really want to: it’s the same sensation of helplessness you experience in your typical eurogame, when for example you have to choose whether that turn you need to increase your red cubes production, feed your folk the yellow cubes or rather build a blue cubes factory, then brood over this decision during the other players’ turns and finally act according to the actions still available on the board. Thus, from an eurogamer’s point of view Mage Knight is undoubtedly thematic, fun and even innovative; yet from a thematic gamer’s point of view this game plays just too fiddly, complex and hopelessly boring.
You make a mistake, such as dashing into a difficult combat just to see what happens and losing it, and you waste any hope to make up with the other players for the rest of the game: shockingly indeed, there’s no such thing as luck here but, as in the Procustean bed of mythology, everything has to fit the rules and be comfortingly predictable or be dealt accordingly.
This sounds as bad design to me since it takes all the fun out of the game.

Given the huge feedback and the positive comments about Mage Knight I heard and read, I confess I expected much more out of this disappointing game. (Original comment written in January 2012, revised in September 2012)

[b]Edit[/b] - After further playing Mage Knight I’ve come to despise it, hence in September 2012 I lowered my previous rating from 6 to 4 and touched up my comment here and there accordingly to better couch my mind about the game.

RATING: 10
Mage Knight is an experience.  It takes a lot of time to learn, and a lot of time to play.  

It took me a while before I was comfortable with the rules.  I actually took the rulebook with me to work/school and would study it on the bus and during down time.  I started several games that I didn't finish because I got too tired to continue.

Now that I have the rules down and a few wins under my belt, Mage Knight is my go-to solo game.

I don't consider the time investment that it takes to play this game as a negative thing.  If it didn't have as many rules, or if it didn't play for as long, it wouldn't be the epic fantasy adventure that it is.  

If you put in the time, it will be totally worth it.  The game is so intricate and exciting, it stays with you long after you finish playing.

RATING: 5
Update: Just so long and complicated and solitary and random.  It's not bad, but it gets old really fast.

Maybe the best of these fantasy RPG wannabe games I have played, but that still leaves something to be desired.  First off, this sucker is long.  You could get an actual and more fulfilling session of PnP roleplaying done in the same amount of time and the rules burden of Mage Knight is not significantly better either.  Furthermore like all of these games, after the first few plays you have seen all that the game has to offer and the gameplay is not compelling enough to warrant continues play.

As for gameplay specifics, the deckbuilding aspect is a pretty cool way to simulate the growth of your fantasy character.  Unfortunately, this also adds a fair amount of randomness as your turns are dictated by your hand more than any strategic considerations.  This is especially clear because movement is handled by your hand and movement costs are fairly high.  Multiple times a game you will suffer through useless turns due to lack of movement cards.  This is frustrating but the game needed another resource controlled by your hand beyond monster slaying potential.

I recommend everyone try it because it is solidly fun at first.

RATING: 7
I'll admit, I am not a fan of the original Mage Knight. And the learning experience I had can best be described as confusing.

And yet...and yet...there's a pretty cool adventure game that feels like a great port of some sort of MURP like Warcraft or Zelda or...whatever.

The card play is what gives the game its tension. So many chances for a great combo. So often, you're not _quite_ there. You know if you were a level higher...

The production values are excellent. There is a solid game with clear opportunities for expandability. The characters are a bit stock, but cool. Imagine something Fantasy Flight might do. Now streamline it so you can get four people around the table and play it in an afternoon.

Mageknight, where were you six years ago???

RATING: 10
What can I say?
This game is amazing! I am a kind of a board game noob although I have played computer games and some board games back in the days. Me and my gf wanted to get into boardgaming because it's something we both can participate in. So we started looking at MK and Robinson Crusoe as OUR 1ST GAMES (co-op is what we wanted). At first I was kind of scared for her if she would be turned away by the heaviness of the games but she was actually happy when she heard it was "hard" (she only played Carcassone so far). So after a few looks into some reviews and the Rahdo (God bless you) runthrough we decided to get MK. 
And we were blown away by the amazing playability of MK as there're so many things one can do here and with so much style. We only played co-op but we'll try other modes as well. We both like EURO style games and we both like the good looks of board games (mostly from reviews-we only have a few board games) and MK has both.
The only problem this game has is its playing time...which is not a problem at all...it only makes it a more weekendish game ;D
People say there is too much downtime...not a problem at all...I mean we played it pretty smoothly (2 player game).
Analisys paralisys? Is this a negative thing? I mean is thinking bad? :o If you hate thinking so much then maybe think loudly and share it with your co player (in a co-op game ofc). Actually if you hate thinking this won't help you :/
All in all great mechanics, great replayability, great co-op, awesome graphics and minis, only time being your enemy.

RATING: 7.5
It's a fantasy board game that promises huge theme, but pretty much delivers none.

It's odd - there are some lovely things about this game. Every game round feels like a puzzle to solve, and by hook or by crook, you can generally get the job done, with a huge sense of satisfaction when you've achieved it. But what do you get for your troubles? a new spell? some dope actions? Well, maybe, but you'd better be in a position to use them there and then, because if you can't the chances are you're going to have to use them in their secondary capacity to move somewhere, and then you won't see them again until next round (where you have to rely on luck to be able to use them there).

You can literally go from being Jimmy Big-Guns to little Johnny crap-the-bed in a single turn, which wouldn't be so bad if the game were more abstract, and more emphasis were placed on the 'puzzle' aspect, but it has the well polished veneer of a fantasy epic and none of the flavour. 

Scratch the surface and you'll find a satisfying back story, lovely components, great ability and magic cards and loads of powerful monsters and allies and well crafted locations. However, dig a little deeper and there's no substance - The back story is never elaborated on, the ability and magic cards are as previously mentioned fleeting and often superfluous, the monsters are represented by cardboard tokens and are made of maths, and the cities - well crafted click-tracker minis - have no names, just colours.

It's sad really that so much work has gone into making this a fantasy themed game, with so little attention to detail.

That said, if you can overlook the shortcomings mentioned above, and focus on the fact that it's an excellent puzzle game, its well worth playing.

Shame I can't....

RATING: 7
This is an interesting title. It's not what I'd call thematic but it is immersive in its own way. It is a very, very thick problem solving title involving tossing around possible card combos and variations of chained moves together to accomplish a result, each telling a little story. It doesn't really add up to a whole story but a string of hard won moments of intellectual satisfaction, perhaps resulting in a feeling of accomplishment (and exhaustion) at the end. The rules are a bear to understand completely and just learning how to play and explore the game makes for a kind of game in itself. I'm glad to own it but see this as an event game for a solo play or two players at most.

Update: I dropped this to a seven just because it's such a bear to prepare for physically and mentally to play that I always find myself choosing something else.

Update: I really need to get this out again, watch Ricky Royal's videos and try to give this game another shot. Too many gamers whose taste I respect regard this too highly for me to allow it to sit on the shelf. Take the rating and comments with a grain of salt until then...

RATING: 8
Juego de aventuras en las que cada jugador se hacer cargo de un personaje con características propias. En su turno, el jugador tiene que utilizar las cartas de su mano, que son las que le van a permitir realizar acciones. Esas cartas se roban de un mazo propio, al que se pueden ir añadiendo nuevas cartas a medida que vas consiguiendo ciertos logros o adquisiciones. Se juega en escenarios y el tablero es modular, y se va descubriendo poco a poco (al menos en el escenario inicial, que hasta el momento es el único que he jugado). El objetivo imagino que depende del escenario, aunque lo habitual será lograr mayor número de puntos de victoria. Una ronda dura hasta que uno de los jugadores agota su mazo. Las cartas tienen dos usos : básico y avanzado.. para usar el avanzado se necesitará maná de determinado tipo, que se tiene que usar en el turno o se pierde (a menos que el personaje lo cristalice). Hay cartas de hechizos, se pueden contratar unidades, que te ayudarán en combates etc. A medida que el personaje se desplaza por el tablero, se puede ir interactuando de diversas formas (contratar unidades, saqueos, entradas a mazmorras, combates, etc).

Es un juego muy completo y con muchas opciones. A pesar de que la mano está compuesta (En principio) por cinco cartas, hay que pensar muy bien qué hacer y cómo hacerlo.

Los componentes son fabuloso. No es un juego para no iniciados. Puede resultar algo "atorante" o lento, por la cantidad de cosas que hay que pensar.

Aguardo siguiente partida para matizar valoraciones.
