RATING: 7
(reposted from http://thegamebox.byethost15.com/smf/index.php?topic=1420.1260)

Not quite sure how I feel. It's got the level of 'annoyance burden' that Magic Realm and Arkham Horror do,
in terms of crappy rules, painful lookups for all sorts of special cases, and the like. On the other hand, I like
the storyline/playout better than either of those others (I think), and it still captures some of that very personal
association with the character - though maybe not quite as much.

One big gripe is, and this is definitely like MR, that it feels over too soon, even when the game takes too
long to play. I had hoped this would just be the learning scenario that felt that way, but even the conquest scenario
feels as though I'm just hitting stride. I guess one can (like MR) extend these further, but maybe just the finite ending
is the issue. Dunno.

Part of the problem there is the 'someone wins anyhow' rule. For the conquest scenario, after it became clear that 
there was no way in hell we would get the victory conditions (it was a pretty dicky game - something she's getting much
better at), it ended up with me gobbling up the citadels she already had, in an attempt to 'catch up'.

Update (after several more plays): yeah, this is getting addictive. I definitely like it better than Thunderstone, even if it takes more thought. There just aren't the gamey factors which get in the way of that one. I also think it does a better job of giving an 'engaging' goal in the various scenarios than does Magic Realm. Oh, I'm sure that MR could be modded to provide closer to a play experience that I enjoy, but this one does a better job, on all wheels, out of the box. A lot less agonizing over what the hell some ability actually means too - even if figuring out the combats is just as taxing. Still, I find it's a lot easier to get up to speed on what happens when with this game. My final comparison is to Arkham Horror. This is so much better, with the semi-coop feel, for me. Yeah, I'd probably like AH better with that aspect - but it doesn't fit the 'flavor' of AH to do so. Here, if anything, I can put myself in the mindset of a general, who will be rebuked if the mission fails, but really wants to come out on top of his class, even if it means a wee bit of friendly fire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Feels like a hugely-improved Runebound, with actual strategy and much-reduced randomness. We played 4-player, and like comments on BGG here suggest, this is a suboptimal # and I wouldn't play 4-player again. I think 3 would be good, maybe co-op. We ended up only playing the 'short' version at 2 days instead of 3, and it still took us just over 5 hours.

The mechanic of making your hand and being able to hold cards over to your next turn is huge: it allows you to plan say a 'fighting' hand this round and keep 'purchasing' cards for next round. That said, there is still some (unwelcome) luck both in the cards you get, and in the tiles drawn. Like Runebound, towards the end as heroes are powered up, it more devolves into a race to who can get to the easier monsters fastest.

Still, very enjoyable and I would play 2 or 3 players again. If you could get a full game done in 3 hours or less I feel it would be a most satisfying fantasy boardgaming experience.

Update: played second game, bumped to a 7.5

RATING: 9
Perhaps the only multiplayer game I can safely say is best with one.  Yes, you can play it with two, and it is fun that way - but with any more, the downtime is really not worth it.  There is very little player interaction in this game.  Yes, or course, you can engage in PvP combat, but it wastes precious turns to do so, and the game doesn't incentivize it very well (the risks far outweigh the rewards imo).  So, with more than two players, you will be waiting a long time between turns, and those other players don't really add much to the game; in fact, the game somewhat suffers from runaway leader issues.  If you want to play with more than two, play the co-op mode.

As a solo game, this is very immersive.  It is basically a huge efficiency/optimization puzzle game.  It is very mathy, and benefits from working your hand in multiple ways turn by turn.  One of the beauties of this game is that there are so many ways to skin any particular cat-conundrum.  You'll often work through many possible combinations of moves and say "Aha!  Yes, this just lets me do exactly what I want!"  At the same time, just as often you'll be left saying "If only I had one more card..."  The real innovation to this game is that all cards in the deck can be played as weak additives to one of the four basic actions (move, fight, block, influence) - so you're never left with a totally bum hand, just a sub-optimal one.  

Ok, as far as theme goes, the game is a little wonky.  It is a heavy game, rulesy, and simulates an awful lot of things we'd want in an adventure/fantasy game.  Exploring is cool; fighting is cool.  Going into a dungeon and seeing what's there is tense.  There's magic, and day and night cycles.  There are followers.  You can pillage and burn things.  Really, this is as close to Magic Realm as any modern board game will get.  And yet, the theme doesn't quite stick.  Perhaps it's the deterministic, mathy nature of the game (no dice, fool!), perhaps it is the lack of flavor text, but it feels more like a Euro.  This is not bad for someone like me, but a Runebound fan might object (although the Ameritrash fans I've played it with have claimed it superior, and more fun, than Runebound).  One of the really cool things about the game is how much it does with so few components - it feels epic, and yet can easily fit on anyone's table.  Lovers and haters alike will agree, I think, that this is a very unique game.  If you are looking for a heavy brain-burn that uses Euro mechanisms, and is best with a low player count, this will not disappoint.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This just gets better and better. Cool theme, awesome components, and an innovative premise: a dungeon-crawler with no dice! I love the deck-building aspect, love the cool spells, advanced actions, military units, and special abilities. The different scenarios and the expansion, not to mention the solo options, give you so many ways to play that you should never tire of this game.

The lack of an index for the rulebooks is unfortunate, and the game runs a little long, but usually I am so engrossed that I don't even notice the hours fly by. I do hate having to discard handfuls of cards just so I can move two or three spaces on the board. This single feature of the gameplay almost kills the game for me: it makes some turns drag interminably, and is generally annoying. We usually alleviate this by giving each player a +1 movement skill token at the beginning of the game. Is this cheating? Yes, but who cares.

RATING: 9
Mage Knight: I love you.

Let's not lie: this is a complex game.  It's going to take a while to learn.  You're going to get tired of running your friends through the tutorial scenario.  It takes a long time to play, and probably has too much downtime with 3-4 players.

RATING: 9
Amazingly deep game, although quite complicated. Combat is pleasantly challenging, especially when you factor in monster powers and resistances. Seriously beautiful components, I love the pre-painted miniatures. Each game will be wildly different thanks to randomized environment tiles and card offers, as well as many different scenarios with varied difficulties and objectives. This is a game that's very customizable if you like making your own rulesets or scenarios. The learning curve is pretty steep but the game includes a beginner scenario that does a good job of explaining the different phases and structures without being too overwhelming.

RATING: 7.5
soloed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Based on 1 play with 4 players on the starting scenario:

Let me be clear up front: Hours-long, complex games with steep learning curves are generally not my cup of tea. I love the themeatic aspect to adventure-y/dungeon crawl-y games, but very rarely do I love the mechanics.

And so it is with Mage Knight. There is a surprising amount I like about the game, so perhaps my rating will rise with future plays (which for once I am not opposed to), but my first play even guided by two experienced players resulted in a lot of confusion, questions, and rules-referencing.

First: I like the deckbuilding component and the way it ties into your character progression. I like games where cards have multiple uses, and it works brilliantly here. I don't know why more deckbuilders don't do this.

Generally, I enjoyed trying to manage my hand such that I could work my way toward bigger and better monsters.

And yet... it feels like maybe this is too long a game to rely on such a luck-driven system? It felt like it was pretty easy to get screwed several turns in a row with bad draw after bad draw. I found my interest waning as the game went on.

This is probably scenario-specific, so I'd be interested to try more scenarios (especially the co-op ones), but the endgame felt just anticlimactic. There isn't really an interesting goal, especially since everything is so procedurally generated that long stretches of the game simply feel aimless. I'm fine with games where you spend the early game trying to beef up your character, and then do something cool, but here it didn't feel like we were moving toward anything interesting.

Player interaction is also surprisingly light. Again, this might be improved in the co-op scenarios. But I prefer something like Descent, where strategizing together is core to the game. Here, I felt I could largely ignore other player's turns. Perhaps this would be better improved if we'd tried any PvP, but generally just beating other people up to try and hinder their progress, at the expense of making progress for yourself, really doesn't sound compelling.

I would love to see a simplified version of this game. There's so many moving pieces that connect, and so many of them feel superfluous or overly complex (the way you calculate damage is a mess) that it is just not the kind of experience that appeals to me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Played twice, 3-player intro game both times; one lasted over 4 hours & the 2nd clocked in at slightly less than 2 hours.  The time did go quickly, but ye gods!  There is a steep learning curve and the rules are not easily referenced (we were constantly retrieving the many cards scattered across the table which laid out the actions available for the different locations).  Gameplay, as another reviewer commented, felt like 3 solitaire games going on at once --- just a man and his deck, silently making calculations to see if he can successfully attack some nasty critter.  Perhaps player vs. player would change this, but I suspect this also adds considerably to an already long playing time.

I am not a RPG fan, and I tend to stay away from fantasy games.  I suspect any rating I gave would be unfairly influenced by this.  I suspect this plays much better as a solitaire game or as a 2-player.  I wouldn't mind playing it again, but I shudder to think of the time required to play a longer version with 4 players.

Having said all this, it is a big step up from the all the dice-rolling orgies I remember from years gone by.  I can understand why a lot of people are pretty excited about this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Woah, this game is very complex and very long. As in very, very long (not compared to many wargames or “epic” games like Twiligt Imperium or Civilization, but compared to almost every other new game). At least that’s the case with “the long game”-version and 3 players. I think it’s much better with two as the third player doesn’t add too much to the game, and I would never try it with 4! The short game (2 days and 2 nights) works well and I’d probably prefer to play it that way going forward.

MK features some intriguing mechanics and LOTS of small rules which you are almost guaranteed to forget during your first couple of plays. But it’s quite satisfying nonetheless; it’s one of those “semi-epic” games because it’s so long. The overall exploration/moving/fighting/deckbuilding mechanics work well as far as I’m concerned. Sure, you might not draw a lot of “move” cards and be limited that way, or you don’t have enough attack cards to attack the creature you want etc. (which by the way is very neat as you can see its strength and abilities, so you can plan ahead, which you need to do in order to keep up the speed), but you can always use other cards for the attributes you need.

The deck-building element is cool, although it’s certainly not a hardcore deck building mechanism; you usually cannot really trash a lot of cards or recycle your deck quickly. Other cool features are the night and day; it doesn’t change the game fundamentally, but it still brings a nice flavor to the game. The sort of “level up” mechanic is also neat – I like that you gradually become stronger as you get room for more mercs and acquire extra cards with special abilities for your deck. The way you hire different mercenaries in different places (cities, keeps, towers etc.) is a good idea, although I once again have to mention those rules… There are a lot, and they mostly aren’t too troublesome, but there are so many of them, and I’m sure that you could have removed some of them in order to streamline it. Yes, the game wouldn’t be exactly the same, but I think it would be better and still feel “epic”.

The spells seem very strong, and I actually feel that they vary quite a bit in strength (not that they’re broken, not at all, but some are simply much better than others. I really like the spell which outright destroys a monster)… The many rules and how hard you need to plan your move in order to move and attack units etc. definitely make your head hurt, and it really sucks when you need to backtrack because you forgot something and cannot do what you wanted… This will happen a lot!

I understand those who claim that MK works as a solo game; I think I might try that one day, and I’m normally not a solo gamer at all. But I will never try it with 4, and even with 3 I think it’s rather boring (as is the coop variant), and because it takes so many hours to play I cannot justify to give it a higher rating; I won’t play it too much because of the fiddly rules and long play time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.6
A great role-playing game with well-painted miniatures and interesting hands management. The best part of this game is whenever the player levels up and takes the new cards/skills/rewards, you can actually feel your character is growing stronger, learning new stuff and become stronger to conquer whatever enemies lied ahead. 

Despite the RPG elements the game is also highly strategical. In long term strategy, the players need to plan which card/skills should they take in order to build a strong character(deck), while in short term they would need to optimize their actions depends on their hands. 

Having a strong character can easily interfere other players' plans by attacking them, hiring strong mercenaries before them or rapidly clear the monsters on the board to prevent other players getting the rewards, which make the game strongly interactive. All the scenarios are really fun to experience and if your friends don't like the scenarios, you can always use the house rules or settings to maximize the utility. 

The only setback of the game is the playing time, since there are so many possibilities and things to do in this game, every player needs tremendous downtime to plan and act which results in an average 3-4 hrs or longer playing time.

RATING: 8
Mage Knight hasn't aged well.  As the queue for our table has lengthened, our tolerance for Mage Knight has diminished.  I believe that this is caused by Mage Knight's card play and overwrought rules.  

Take movement for example.  Almost every boardgame requires us to make decisions about how to move best.  In MK we always seem to struggle to move at all.  I'm a big fan of games that reward meaningful decisions.  But struggling against a crappy hand of cards in order to move from point A to point B is neither meaningful nor rewarding.  

Worse for MK, we've discover other titles that present the fantasy genre, require deck management, and have meaningful decisions.  Games that don't require you to look up cryptic symbols time and time again either.  

I still like MK, but it's overwrought.  It's long for what it is, and it's fragile.  A bad hand of cards makes you feel like sweeping it all back in the box.

I'd probably give MK a 9 as a solo game ... but only a 6 or 7 as a two player co-op.  I don't think I'd play it with 3 or more gamers at the table.


-------------------------------------------------

After taking the game off the shelf yet again, and finding it as enjoyable as ever, I've bumped its rating to a 10.  True expansions aren't worth much, the rules are terrible, and I definitely prefer solo play to multiplayer competitive.  Yet as a solo game, Mage Knight is a true 10.

-------------------------------------------------

I'm enjoying exploring this game solo with the occasional co-op game.

The rules are a definite weakness.  We've all played wargames and other games with complex, exception filled rules.  MK's rules seem to have been approached with a bizarre mentality which I'm going to refer to as "brevity diffused".  They seem very resistant to repeating themselves, yet at the same time they are spread out across two full books and numerous reference cards.  The result is chaos.  

I have to believe that as popular as the game has proven, it would have been even bigger hit if the rules had been better structured.  Structured, not written.  I think the rules are decently written, but they are -horrifically- structured.  I was lucky that in coming late to the party, I had a wealth of demo videos to watch and experienced players to learn from.

RATING: 9
The grown up, thinking man's fantasy game. Oodles of tough decisions to make every turn, with pretty deep combat (no simple modifiers + dice roll here, no sir). Console/PC RPG gamers will feel right at home with how the status ailiments and physical/magic resistances work. 

Your deck/hand of cards dictates what you can do to a certain extent, but each one can effectively be used in three different ways (normal, powered up, or played sideways for a completely different, weaker effect). You can also keep unused cards from one turn to the next, to build the perfect hand for killing a tough enemy or sprinting across the countryside (though you can be punished if you go through your deck much slower than the other players).

 How hard can a game be to learn? i asked myself.

RATING: 7.5
Very impressive.  Definitely scratches my Magic Realm itch.  Rating will hopefully go up as we explore it. 

Update: 

Well it's been about five games and I thought I should revisit my feelings on the game. It remains an impressive update of the Magic Realm genre.  Granted, Magic Realm is in a genre of it's own, but Mage Knight is the first thing that comes remotely close to approximating it.  I find myself deeply conflicted about Vlaad's designs.  I think they are smart, but too procedural to be fully compatible to my taste.  The little subsystems begin to feel rote after a game or two and their clever veneer wears thin.  I say this as someone who has affectionately played many games of Galaxy Trucker, Space Alert, Dungeon Lords, and Mage Knight.  But I think MK is also something more.  The game manages to capitalize on the excellent aspects of Vlaad's design tendencies without bogging itself down.  This is partly successful because the game space is so damn open.  There's still plenty of bog out there but you simply don't need it.  

In other words, this game gets a little bump.  I'll let it sit at 8.5 for now and see where it is in 5 plays.

Update:
Well 5 plays later my feelings are starting to cool.  Once players know what they are doing much of the games charm starts to wear off.  It's still a good game but it's hardly a replacement for Magic Realm.  Vlaada's procedural puzzles just don't interest me.  Down to a 7.5.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
Epic game. Two playthroughs so far (in two player), the second of which I managed to win by employing some masterful sorcery techniques.

EDIT: I've since played with 3 players and had to alter my opinion drastically. When an additional player is added this game suffers very seriously from down time due to the nature of the deck-building mechanic (like a mini arithmetic puzzle for each player). Whilst I'm more than happy to sit and watch someone map out their turn in a two player game, it just becomes an absolute slog with three players. The problem is compounded if someone ahead of you carries out an action (or actions) that you intended to carry out yourself, because you'll often find yourself with a hand of cards that will only allow you to move a couple of spaces and...erm...that's it. So sometimes you'll wait 15 or 20 minutes (no exaggeration) for your turn to come along only to quickly spend all of your cards on movement, then it's back to waiting again. Rinse, repeat.

If I'm going to dedicate an entire night (easily 6 - 7 hours) to playing a game I'd want much more player interaction and a great deal less down time.

Having said all that, I can comfortably say this is one of the best games I've played in a long time. I just don't know if I'll ever play it with more than two people again.

RATING: 10
When I first played this game, I rated it an 8.5.  I really liked it, but I wasn't quite sure I understood it enough and didn't want put it too high.

I played it a few times solo to get a better understanding of the rules and, wow, the game really opened up to me.  This game is a complex puzzle of hand management and presents a number of agonizing decisions.  I will say that it is very math-y game, but that's exactly what I was looking for.

Some same the theme isn't rich and some of the rules are not intuitive, but I find that, once you get a hang of the game, the rules make a lot of sense and the theme really does come through.  Do I burn a monastery to the ground for a quick boost or will the loss of reputation hurt me too much later for recruiting elite units?

I love playing this game with my friends, but what really makes it a "10" in my ranks is that it is the first game that I actually enjoy playing solo.  Vlaada's finest work, and that's saying something.

RATING: 9
Epic carddriven fantasy game! You need to enjoy reading rules to appreciate it, you actually get two rulebooks with this game, one rulebook proper and one walkthrough. I think the rules are well written and the walkthrough is a great idea and almost a must for learning the game. Components are generally great but i don´t like the hero miniatures, not much detail and the faces look very weird on two of them (Arythea looks like a intergalactic xeno and Norowas seem to have some kind of nose birth defect). They are pre-painted and that's nice but to be honest I could have painted all of them myself in less than an hour. The cities however are great looking once properly painted. I think this game works best as a solitary experience and My rating is for the solo variant. I haven't had a better solo experience with any other game. Because of a very steep learning curve you need to dedicate to this game. However, the more you play it the better it gets.

RATING: 8
I should say off the top that this game is brilliant. There's so much good to talk about - the brain-busting deck and mana management, the endless variety of randomization and customization, the sheer beauty of the thing, the fact that you can BURN MONASTERIES(!) - so let's determine what's holding the game back from a perfect 10. RATING: 8
2010 Played two incomplete solo games after reading the walkthrough and watching a video review or two.  Still having moments of discovery with the rules.  Looking to play to completion this time.

After 6 plays: The puzzle aspect of this game are working for me at the moment.

I always give negative reviews a gander and noticed the thing about resolving combat differently on enemies, allies, yourself and PvP.  Its true, annoying and not intuitive but I suspect most players are willing to overlook this and other faults because this games strengths are evident.

Reminds me of Decision Games solo D-Day game (also had a significant puzzle elements) which I like alot but this is considerably less frustrating.  The character advancement and exploration elements make sure that even if you are having a bad game you have a sense of progress.

2013 For people that have not been playing CCG, LCG alot in recent years the barrier of entry is quite high.  I have a pathfinder card game that you can take straight off the shelf and play the same night (missing the smallest nuances of the game does not seem to be a game breaker with Pathfinder).  I suspect that I will always have to give myself a week of study (reading rules and playing the basic scenario) before I play this game.  I have even set up the walkthrough scenario despite having played the game before.  Hoping to teach someone else the game a week Thursday and have only just got to the point where I think this is possible.

Reminds me of Magic Realm but ulimately I favour this game.  Both have lot of sub-systems and replayability but the Euro/CCG genetics have produced a game with a much better rule set.

Upsides:
Fun subsystems
Character advancement and variety
Re-playability
No dice rolling
Feel like you can always play the game better
Emersive

Downsides:
Lots of subsytems
Characters lack initial variety
Combat lacks elegance
Victory feels like a separate element to progress
You can either beat an an opponent with your card hand or you can't no element of tension

I always had a problem about timing a change from general game play to banking a victory.  A lot of games require a change in gameplay from say accumilating wealth etc towards victory conditions.  This game has a similar turning point where the city/s should become the entire focus of your gameplay.  As a solo player I am totally incapable of breaking off from general play early enough or forming a sensible plan for the last turn.

I'm hoping by teaching someone else how to play the game I can use competitive urges to focus my gameplay at winning rather that the accumulation of cards, fame, units etc.  I suspect I will not get better at the solo game without a bit of player interation.

2015 The game does require a bit of investment before you can play (mostly re-reading the rules).  This has kept this game off my table for a while.

This is the greatest board game I have ever played. Ever. I've played solo, cooperative, and competitive scenarios. They're all incredibly enjoyable. After reading negative reviews (mainly by users who I believe were either playing the game incorrectly or couldn't figure out the rules), I had to step in and let everyone know just how great this game is.

RATING: 8
Rating after 6 solo conquest plays 

Great solo game. You have to make a lot of tough but interesting choices (rating +2) and you can shape your hero through skills and deck builing (rating +1). The game is also thematic and progression - i.e. hero power vs challenges - feels right (rating +1). The game rivals Agricola and Le Havre – my favourite solo games - but I suspect it has more replayability.  Like these two brainburning titles much of the gameplay is deterministic and you are trying to be as efficient as possible. However, Mage Knight is much more random: most importantly card draws and mana dice rolls are of crucial importance. I am not against the randmomness [i] per se [/i], as it adds replyability, but I think that movement is too costly: if changing your position was less expensive you could manage the randomness of card draws /mana rolls better.  (rating -2) I guess the problem would be worse in multiplayer as you often have to take boring “move a hex” turns and then wait for others to complete their turns. 

The game can be difficult to learn: there are many details that have to be memorized. However, the rules are coherent and all of the rules seem to have a purpose, i.e. no complexity for the sake of it. The rulebook is well written (rating +1), although there are exceptions (such as not presenting rules for solo play in one place). The production quality is disappointing: misaligned printing of cards and tiles and the material of the cards, which makes sleeving a necessity (rating -1). I am not sure how to rate graphical design and art. Some of it is great but some is rather awful, e.g. color scheme of the lizardman's skills.

RATING: 6.49
Potential for higher rating after more games!

Likes:
- Much to do on the growing map - exploring dungeons and the like is something I always loved in games like Master of Magic or the Heroes of Might and Magic series (eagerly waiting for THAT game, btw). MK does this well, superior to others
- Quick successes
- Not as heavy as it seems; rules are overwhelming, while the game isn't really that complicated once you've got the basic run-down. You'll have to read up on the features of special places occasionally, but that's mostly it. Don't be afraid of the rules, there's worse.
- PvP can be skipped; i hate PvP
- Super material

Dislikes:
- Too much to do for the, all in all, limited time in most scenarios (if there's more time in a scenario, it'll take forever...)
- Downtime (even bad in a 2p, might work out better with more experience)
- Characters are all the same at the start - why? They could have skipped on them altogether and made wooden meeples in different colors. There should have been at least some tiny difference from the start "Ah this is more the magician type, this the healer, that the tank..."; or slightly different decks towards this direction (it's possible to balance this stuff, as other games prove)
- There's not much deck-building actually; everyone starts with the same deck and there's NOT that many new cards to come by really. I don't like deck-building much, but if it's a mechanic anyway, it'd better work well enough to make it worthwhile.
- Deck-building itself makes no sense - why do I have to wait for some decent card to successfully attack something standing right next to me? Having a walk around it fatigues me and my troops too, that's no excuse.

Sounds a bit rough, but I actually do like it.

UPDATE:
It's getting worse (before it get's better...?). Second game was more exhausting than our day job. It's more fun to prepare your taxes (and less complicated). Well...

RATING: 9
Wow. Just wow.

This is a fantastic game.

You've probably read every praises on this game, but they are true.

Here's what I love about it: very puzzle-y (you have to use your hand to the most effective effect on each turn), your character progresses through a deck-building mechanism, there is a little dice rolling, the fights are tough (even brutal), there are multiple scenarios, several playing modes (including solo!), the minis are nice and the artwork is fine.

Beware that this is a complex game, with lot of rules and can last several hours.

If you're into this kind of game, this one will devour your time.

RATING: 9
Things I like about Mage Knight:

* It captures an "adventuring" feel
* It has a good variety of loot (skills, spells, artifacts), while keeping some of it rare/hard to get so it always feels like there is more to discover
* There's a good mix of deterministic calculation (figuring out how to play cards in a combat, for example) along with push-your-luck decisions (should I delve into this dungeon in search of treasure if I know I can beat 4 out of 5 possible monsters I'll run into?)
* Time is of the essence; there are always more things available to do than you realistically have time for, leading to hard/challenging decisions
* It plays great solo

Things I don't like about Mage Knight:

* Theme (disclaimer: never read the books) - the "heroes" are basically big jerks running around sacking the land because some nebulous Council wants them to
* The game sometimes ends just as you feel like you're getting well equipped
* Luck of the draw/hand management can sometimes be frustrating (no Move cards?! I don't want to discard three otherwise-valuable actions for moves!)
* With more than 1 player, analysis paralysis can become a serious bother - much of the game is figuring out how best to optimize your actions. The rules explicitly encourage "reverting" moves (as long as they don't reveal new information) instead of trying to think everything out beforehand, but even so it can be a lot of brain burning to figure out the optimal move for a turn

RATING: 6
I was very excited about this game before we get it and at the beginning. 

The components are great, idea is neat, art work is pretty cool. I really like how the game looks overall. I like the mana system and day/night turns affecting how you play the game. If you have the right cards at hand at the right time, you feel very powerful! I like that. 

When we were learning the game we felt there were so many rules, it was tough and I said we should not try to play this with new people, it takes long teach but things soon make sense, main rules are mostly intuitive. 

Here comes my complaints:

1) My biggest complaint is whenever we play we always get stuck in one or two rounds. It is as if the game is trying to sabotage you at least half the time. 

2) Co-operative play hardly feels co-operative. We need to always remind ourselves that we are not competing, but how is it possible if there is an individual point track system moving all the time? It almost feels like the game is forced to be co-operative just as an additional edge. 

3) Also, it is possible that as you move along in the game you can get some analysis paralysis situations since there could be many combinations to consider, spells to choose from, etc.. While the other person plays, you feel like taking a break or, if too frustrated, start reading a book.

I really wanted to like this game... We will still keep it though. I think I can play it if I am really in the mood for some half sabotaging-half rewarding, good looking game.

RATING: 10
I really love this game.

The rulebook is hefty but the play is logical and after the first two or so plays we haven't had the need to look the rules up again. Draw your card hand -> smack down cards on your turn -> draw up to hand limit at the end of your turn -> rinse and repeat until your deck is empty -> a new day and a freshly suffled deck.

I love how you have to balance the risk/reward ratio. Knowing your deck and what you might reasonably be expected to tackle with it is the key to the victory. And victory points come from so many categories (besides the scenario main objective) that usually all the players have a chance at winning atleast one of the categories.

Sometimes turns can last a bit long as players optimize their moves and fights. A natural result since the combats happen without rolling damage dice or other such luck dependant things. It works very well.

The theme of the game and the components are also solid.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
SOLO PLAY:

1 Player Minimum
4 Player Maximum
The game mechanics are really neat. You have total control. There is a steep learning curve and two rulebooks. This game makes my head hurt.

SET UP NOTES:
-Set Up board and cards as suggested on page 2 of rule book. (Advanced Actions, Fame & Reputation Board, Spells, Wounds and Artifacts.)
-Add three Advanced Actions and three Spells for initial offer.
-Shuffle Silver Unit Cards and add # of actual player +2 to the Unit Offer. (Note: Advanced Gold Units are available at the end of a round after a Core Tile has been placed.)
-Shuffle Monster Tokens, leave them in the Plano boxes.
-Create Tile Deck according to Scenario details. Shuffle brown Core Tiles together, shuffle green Countryside tiles and place on top of shuffled brown Core Tiles.
-Place START TILE, open or wedge based on Scenario, draw 2 or 3 tiles (based on start tile, wedge or open.) Place them oriented to the start tile. Place appropriate Monster Tokens on beginning tile.
-Set Up DUMMY PLAYER, need hero card and place 3 corresponding Crystals on it, shuffle 16 starting cards. IF SOLO use nine non interactive Skill Tokens and skill description.
-Roll MANA DICE, # of actual player +2, set on Day/Night Board.
-HAND LIMIT, Each Player draws up to their Hand Limit.
-SELECT TACTICS CARDS, begin game.

RULES NOTES:
-DUMMY PLAYER TURN: flip over 3 cards. If top card matches any crystals on hero card flip over more cards equal to number of same colored crystals. If Deed Deck is empty at start of turn, "announce end of turn" all other players have one more turn until round is over.
-RAMPAGING ENEMIES: Auto attack if you move from an adjacent space to a different adjacent space to the same enemy. You may optionally attack a Rampaging Enemy from an adjacent space. You cannot ever be in the same space as a a Rampaging Enemy. Maurading Orcs and Draconium are the only Rampaging Enemies.
-REGULAR TURN: May Move, then may do ONE Action. Must Move before you do one Action.

And both sets of wargames are of medium complexity for wargames. That should tell you a lot about the wargame hobby. And that is why I'm hardly a genuine grognard, through and through.

RATING: 8.5
Greatest Hits Remix - This has a lot of mechanics that come from other great games, and they actually work with each other *and* the theme quite well.  This game has a lot going on and won't fit on a card table.

Not enough play to definitively rate yet, but I must say I like it and I see potential for greatness.

Role selection determining turn order as in Citadels
Deckbuilding as seen in Dominion
Card driven action as in Commands & Colors and Elfenland
Resource drafting as in Elfenland
Various terrain movement costs as in Elfenland / wargames
Non random combat with abilities as in Magic: the Gathering
Recruiting followers similar to summoning creatures as in Magic: the Gathering
Day/Night cycle affecting visibility and available resources as in Terraria
Achievement scoring as in Settlers of Catan
Level up system gives different rewards on even and odd levels as in D&D 4E.
Hex tile based exploration as in Eclipse/others

I told you this game has a lot going on!

RATING: 10
A complex and challenging fantasy themed game but once you invest the time to learn it, it's hugely rewarding.

Involves recruiting armies (or "units"), fighting monsters, some deck-building, leveling up your Mage Knight character and exploration to conquer keeps, mage towers, cities and more.  

You can sometimes be unlucky with your hand so your turn can be a little frustrating when you can't achieve what you were hoping for, but I think that can be the case with any deck building game.  Mage Knight is about the challenge of making the most of your hand at any one time.

Overall, a beautifully designed game.  The creators have given us lots of different ways to play as well: solo, cooperative, competitive and also with different types of quests/scenarios.  (There's lots of fan made variants as well).  Blooming hate the 2 rulebooks though... 

This game has a steep learning curve, but it really is epic awesome-ness in a box.

I recommend watching Ricky Royal's (Box of Delights) playthrough videos for learning how to play.

RATING: 6
I think I have played it enough to conclude that, despite its multitude of lovely components, its pretty artwork, its cleverness piled upon cleverness, Mage Knight is still, simply this - bash, collect, improve, bash, collect, improve, [i]ad nauseum[/i].  At the time when a board game comes closest to being RPG-but-not-an-RPG, MK is at its core, just another RPG - bash, collect, improve.  Rinse and repeat.

Can a lot of boardgames we revere on this site be damned for the same sin of iterative processes?  Certainly, but not all are equally guilty of iteration solely for the sake of iteration.  Mr. Chvatil has done well, to tuck this away behind card management, deck-building, shared dice usage, and several other aspects that elicit oohs and aahs, but play it enough, and you'll find the man behind the curtain.

And while some will find that man a very likeable creature, I for one find him dull and repetitive.

RATING: 9
Okay, after several plays, I'm upgrading this from a Thumbs Up (6) to Top Shelf (9). It took me several plays to get comfortable with all of the rules and options, so now I can quickly assess my exploration options and rapidly resolve combat. As many have said, learning not to fear wounds (as long as you have enough firepower to complete the kill afterwards) is key. I usually like my adventure games to be less deterministic, but the more I play MK, the more I see dealing with the randomness (i.e., risk management) to be an important part of the game. 

It could also be that I was only truly satisfied when adding the expansion, so I'm not sure that the base game itself warrants this high a rating.

RATING: 10
A highly recommendable game for solo-players who like a fantasy setting and do not mind playing a somewhat shady character.

The main characteristic of the game is the interesting mix between randomness and calculation: the situations you face during the game are subject to a lot of random elements (a random map, random enemies placed on the map and in cities, random units for hire/spells/advanced actions changing from round to round) to an extent that each play is likely to be unique. On the other hand, the randomness ends when the player begins to act (safe for entering adventure sites where you randomly draw the inhabitant upon entry). The player knows what they can do in their turn. They can calculate the outcome of any battle before starting it. Thus, with the abovementioned exception, you will never encounter the dreaded situation of a single die roll thwarting your attack.

Mage Knight requires you to think about the best way to use your hand in each turn, how to go about combat and what challenges to face. All of these turn into myriads of more detailed decisions. 

Therefore, Mage Knight can easily become a brainy game. However, I have the feeling that the braininess is still bearable for the average and casual player (borderline for the latter).

Besides requiring thinking about your actions, the other limitation the game provides is the time setup takes (lots of different decks and chit tiles) as well as how long individual plays can take.

Still, I think that the game is very rewarding and thanks to the variability offering great replayability even for solo-players.

RATING: 9
One of the most clever and absorbing games I have played.  It's really a hand management game...figuring out how to play your cards in just the right way to get what you need.  But there are so many different ways to do things that you will often start out planning to do it one way but find a different way of doing it that is more efficient part way through your turn. Somehow the theme manages to come through and produce some great stories, and no game will ever be the same. A fantastic solitaire game, but plays well with 2 and 3, although it starts to slow down with 3--some heavy AP can set in with some players.  Never with four! Highly recommended!

Too bad this is so long and difficult to teach...I would love to play more.

RATING: 9
It seems to be the best game as an adventure-type slay monsters and level up type of game. Magic Realm is just too outdated and overly-complex. MK, while not perfect, is a reasonable alternative. An Ameritrash game that takes a lot of unnecessary randomness out--a hybrid then? What's more is that it is a good game to play solo, although I much prefer it multiplayer. My gripes with it (admittedly minor) are the ugly card art and miniature figurines. The art is good quality, in fact, but the depiction of human(oid) creatures is where it fails. The art on the cards is very colorful and effective, and certainly is an improvement over cards with no art at all. 

I'm not a huge fan of deck-building, but there's enough of the game outside of this mechanic to make it fun. It's more hand management than deckbuilding, since you aren't required to discard your hand at the end of your turn, and aside from Wounds, there aren't any completely useless cards (I'm looking at you, Dominion). The icons work well, and I have to mention that the art and site locations on the terrain tiles are of excellent quality and make for very clear gameplay. This game is certainly heavy and fiddly with a few rules exceptions, but it's worth every bit of the struggle to get there. Everything is thematically intuitive as well as important for game balance. 

Oh, and in case it matters, I know nothing of the original Mage Knight minis game or the MK setting.

I rate it a 9.5 as a two or three player game. I rate it a 7 as a solo and co-op game (I dislike using an artificial timer, plus I'm generally averse to solo games in general). I haven't played it with 4 yet. I imagine I would enjoy it as long as it was with fast players who are very comfortable with the game. Full Conquest is my favorite scenario, but I also enjoy Druid Nights and Mines Liberation for variety. In Full Conquest, I play mainly 2 player, and use the variant to add 1 extra countryside tile and 1 extra non-city core tile to setup. This allows for some extra Fame to be earned. We were conquering the cities well-before the end of the 3rd night because we were running out of places outside the cities to get Fame. 

19 of my logged plays are solo, which don't really count for a game that can be played multiplayer.

RATING: 9
Pros:
- Thematic deckbuilding mechanism that works naturally to show character growth. Progression in a single session is satisfying.
- Challenging hand management puzzle per turn, balancing card efficiency, mana crystals and tokens, and tempo in relation to your opponents.
- Choosing between advanced actions, skills, spells, and artifact cards for your deck is a fun challenge.
- Highly replayable with random tile exploration and multiple scenario types and multiple asymmetrical mage knight characters.
- Plays well solo, but also plays well at other player counts as long as there is enough time set aside to play.
- Has a good 2 rulebook system and rule aid cards.
- Expanded with rebalanced cards and new mechanics and content. Wished they added another set of Tactic cards.
- Prepainted minis and useful castle hero click figures. Good quality for board game level (not miniatures level).

Cons:
- Cards material is of good quality but ink can run and fade with use. Must sleeve.
- Long game, minimum hour per player, and suffers with AP prone players.
- Despite good rulebooks, difficult to play correctly out of the box due to the sheer number of rules and concepts to learn.
- The setup takes me about 15 minutes with experience and without special storage solutions. Not bad box insert already helps.
- No campaign mode for those who desire it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
After a few plays in, rating hasn't really changed. It's definitely better as a 2-player game. With more the game can really drag and the playing time can balloon out of control, all without really adding anything to the game play experience. I'd probably refuse to play with more than 2 in the future except perhaps as a co-op.

There are a lot of bits to remember with this game, more than many wargames really. The deck building aspect is good but only if you play a longer game. Otherwise you just won't see a payoff on your card investment, which rather defeats the purpose. The deterministic combat means that if both players are doing equally well, the game will come down to the luck of the tile and monster draws. If it's NOT close then it will just be torture for the lagging players because there's no catchup mechanism in the competitive game, and they'll suffer for another 2 hours as the game finally lumbers to conclusion.

I dunno. At the end of the day I just don't know how much fun I'm getting out of it. It's supposed to be an adventure game, but one never really gets the feeling of any kind of narrative being generated, and it's too long. I just think there are other fantasy games out there that do a better job.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
There is absolutely no way anyone could get all, or even most, of the rules right if they were just using the printed rulebooks. By printing a player aid, the FAQ, a player made chart for city levels, and referring multiple times to BGG forums I was able to play the game.

Rules are divided between two books for no good reason at all: you can't use the walkthrough without the rulebook or vice versa so looking something up (and you have to look everything up) always means paging through two books. (Edit: At least one rule is only stated on a reference card, not in either book. Mr. Chvatil, why not just design a game called 'Rule Hunter'? You could hide rules in Easter eggs, abandoned buildings, under your hat...)

Furthermore there is no logic to the organization of either book at all. Rules that govern basic gameplay are buried in a wall of text with every possible exception. No attempt is made at all to differentiate between major and minor rules.

Not only are the rules buried in exceptions, they are literally scrambled. Want to know how to cast spells? Don't look in the rulebook, it's in the walkthrough, under "Revealing the Mage Tower (Tile 4)".

(Edit: Actually casting spells is covered in the rulebook, but there's also a place somewhere in the rulebook that refers you to the Walkthrough for the explanation, which is how I ended up there.)

Added to the problem is endless repetition and lengthy explanation of the patently obvious:

"Overview: ...each round represents either one day or one night. The first round is usually Day, which is then followed by Night, then Day, etc."

Four pages later...

"Day/Night Board: The two-sided Day/Night board shows whether it is Day or Night.... it starts with the Day side up and remains like this for the entire first round. When the round ends it flips over to the Night side."

Wow. So night follows day. Astonishing.

If you took a normal rulebook, shrank the font to near microscopic size, made two copies of it, stuffed them all in the barrel of a shotgun, fired it into a blender, and then divided the wreckage in two halves you would get a similar effect.

Rating of 5 includes a -3 deduction for rules.

Yes, it is a good game, if you have the patience to learn it.


Edit: the searchable pdf, found here, would probably help a lot:
http://wizkidsgames.com/wp-content/uploads/mage/MK_rulebook_ENG_searchable-mar2012.pdf

...but I still don't ever want to look at this game again. At this point I don't even like to look at the box. It's in a drawer until my next auction.

Edit: Got a chance to play with a very experienced player guiding us tonight. I thought this might make it possible to enjoy the game. It was much better to ask him 3 or more questions every turn than to search the rulebook for answers, but the end result is the same: Mage Knight is unplayable. It would make a fine app. As a board game the rules and exceptions are far too numerous to adjudicate. Unless it is intended as a gift for obsessive pre-teens with countless hours to fill, this is not something I would recommend.

RATING: 8
Magic Realm light.  You can see all the pieces of Magic Realm redone here.  There are quite a bit fewer rules here both due to simplifying it down plus all the cards.  Instead of looking up things on charts, often you are reading cards.  Which is better is debatable.  The cards replace the chits and add an enormous amount of luck of the draw.  Sometimes you want to fight and all you have are move cards.  Sometimes you need to move to a new area of the map and all you have are fight and mana cards.  However, the combat is now more deterministic.  Some Magic Realm battles were determined by dice rolling for tactics & repositioning.  Using magic is simpler but less satisying in Mage Knight.   Chit fiddliness in Magic Realm is replaced with card and mana fiddliness in Mage Knight.  Both have complicated combat.

What Mage Knight does better :  Fewer lookups..but still a good amount.  Less harsh for finding your character in a battle he/she cannot win.  Wounds can be discarded at the cost of a turn (or so I hear).  Less complex.

What Magic Realm does better:  Everything else.  Map, Treasures, win conditions, simultaneous action (most of time), characters, non-deterministic combat, spells, etc.

Ultimately both are excellent game, but given my choice, I'd much rather play Magic Realm.  The game offers a richer experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Players are Mage Knights, roaming the land and having adventures.  Intriguing exploration and adventure game set in a sword and sorcery world from Vlaada Chvatil. Players on their turn play from their hand of five or so cards, moving across an expanding board of hex tiles, and interacting with the spaces they end their turn in.  An amazing adventure game, driven by a deck of 16 cards, which can be used in a myriad of ways to accomplish goals for the turn - moving, fighting, influencing locals, healing, recruiting and so on.  Combat is a dice free card playing exercise that reminds me a lot of the threats you have to deal with in Space Alert. It is impossible to go into detail in the space available here, but wow, we have a rich fantasy space here to explore full of allies, foes, dungeons, monasteries, etc. you can recruit, be a noble savior or a plundering vandal ... it's up to you.  Stuffed full of scenarios and options.... Magic Realm may be finally matched.  Don't expect to quickly inhale a rulebook and leap in... there is a lot to absorb here, but every turn is a delightful puzzle.  Engrossing game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very interesting RPG boardgame with more in common with Dominion than it's namesake, Mage Knight. Could seem daunting at first with a fairly bulky manual, but the game at its heart is actually quite simple and could possibly be explained in less than 10 minutes. All the more complex/additional bits can easily be explained as they come up on the new boards (as you explore the map, additional map pieces are added) instead of trying to explain everything right away and confuse the players.
Seems to scale fairly well. 
Interesting and will definitively take it out for a spin again soon.

RATING: 6
At the moment I'm  not a believer.

I've played 5 games.  Seems like a game of Magic or these deck building things disguised like a board game.  I think this game has beautiful card combos and the mana dice are very neat, but a hand seems to really force choices.  I don't feel like I can do just anything.  It seems like one turn I can clearly Influence a unit much more than i should fight and the next turn I could become a kick ass fighter and i shouldn't try influencing units at all.  It doesn't make sense to me thematically.  

The story that this game seems to tell me, in my brain, looks like a Disney/Pixar world which isn't a thematic world I want to hang out in.  The characters and events haven't spoken to me yet, I'm hoping my relationship with the world strengthens, but after 5 games all story elements seemed to be overshadowed by procedure.  

While the card combos are fun to make and I like how it seems like a nod to Magic Realm, it just doesn't grab me as a story.  I will keep playing but so far not for me.

I'm not a fan of CCGs and deck builders so that style of play does create a bias in my opinion.  Due to this the game feels like a 3 hour version of a very slow deck building/card combo action style game with the illusion of an adventure game.  My 5th game is when I finally felt I could not lie to myself any longer, this was really a deck building/card combo type game.

Ratings may go up now that I approach this game for what it is.  Maybe I'll appreciate the game play as a deck builder next time.

RATING: 8
Challenging in a fun way. There is a palpable feeling of urgency to rush and find the end-game areas whilst also beefing your character up along the way. Building your deck via your in-game choices is very satisfying and quickly makes the hero your controlling feel like your own creation. The hidden information in the fog of war terrain and encounters makes for suspense and a sense of adventure as you quest for better gear or allies.
 The combat is good but more difficult baddies can take a lot of time to deal with. You may spend 10 minutes puzzling over an encounter, analysing your hand of cards/abilities only to learn that you actually cant kill them after all. So there is a chunk of downtime involved. 1-2 players is great but i'm worried about playing with more - as much as i really want to! The game has so much variety added by the different modes given in the rulebook.
   One of my favourite games but doesn't get higher than an 8 because of the clunkiness of some of the rules and the down-time with more than 1 player which prevents me from always wanting to play.

RATING: 5.75
I've only played the introductory game of this, so I may warm to it more when I go back for another try, but my initial thoughts aren't so kind.  I really want to like the game, as it has so many things going for it, but I found it too obtuse.

Being able to explore this world filled with fantastical locations is great.  You have all sorts of options: buying new cards, hiring followers, collecting crystals, sieging castles, sacking monasteries, exploring dungeons, etc.  You can decide to be a renowned hero or reviled villain, and both give you advantages.  The chrome factor is huge, with bits & chits of all kinds.  The day and night phases with different rules are a neat addition.

My first complaint is that combat is really odd and unintuitive.  There are the expected ranged and melee phases.  Instead of just dealing damage and subtracting armor, you have to go through this arcane procedure to block and see how much damage each participant takes.  Then, you can assign some, but not all of it to your followers?  
The rules are so generally massive and fiddly that you'll be referring back to the book for lots of questions.  They do a good job of putting many things on player-aid cards, but it just isn't enough.

The big problem overshadowing all others, though, is the deckbuilding style.  It's a neat idea, but it it doesn't entirely work, esp. not in a game of this length.  Remember when I said you had all those cool options during your turn?  Well, it turns out you actually don't.  Oh, you can gaze at the map and imagine all the stuff you'd like to do, but then you have to look at your hand and discover how little of it you can feasibly attempt.  It's great that you can exchange any card for a 1-point action of any type, but this doesn't really solve the problem.  You can easily be staring at a bunch of move cards when you're sitting next to the fortress you want to attack.  If you move away, you can do something else, but then next turn you'll likely be in the opposite state: with a handful of attack cards and no move to get you adjacent to something to attack.  The game is very tactical this way, asking you to decide what the best thing is that you can accomplish this turn.  Of course, you can save over cards from turn to turn, so you can plan ahead and spend only some of your cards, saving the rest for a more potent turn next time.
All of this would be entirely fine, if not for one more rule.  The day ends when one player exhausts their deck.  This means that instead of having the option to take your time, mitigate bad draws, and advance slowly doing incremental things, you're forced to keep pace with the fastest player.  Someone is going to get all his/her cards in the perfect order, be able to make best use of all of them, and burn through his/her deck like lightning.  If you get your cards in the wrong order or all clumped together, you'll be forced to discard many of them for the generic low-power option, and will fall further and further behind.  If you try to mitigate this by playing cautiously and doing small turns, you'll end the day with half your deck left and be no better off.  Again, this sort of luck-of-the-draw is entirely expected from deckbuilders, but the problem is that those games generally A. play quickly, not as multi-hour affairs and B. see you cycling through your deck many times (hopefully evening out the luck aspect), not just 3.  This even means that adding cool, powerful new cards to your deck isn't that good, since you're still slaved to the pace of the person with the smallest deck and you won't see them more than a couple times max.

We also turned off PvP, and I'm damn glad we did, since continually having to watch your back would make the experience even [i]more[/i] painful.  It seems like turn order would become king, as it'd be really easy to ambush someone who had depleted their cards and couldn't fight back.

Again, I'm going to have to try this a second time, as there was enough there to really intrigue me.  But this stuff really stuck out and hurt my enjoyment of it the first time through.

RATING: 9.6
A game like no other, one of the masterpieces by Vlaada Chvátil. You are a powerful Mage Knight on a mission. Explore the land, kick monster's ass, assault mage towers and recruit followers and/or rest in a village. Or plunder that village if you wish! But your popularity will suffer if you do.

To act and fight you gradually build your deck of actions and use the actions you have available in the best possible way.
In this sense, every turn is like a mathematical puzzle, but the theme is very strong and you really feel your power growing. 

Edit: With the coming of Gloomhaven, the deep and Satisfiyng RPG/Fantasy/Adventure feel has been brought to another level, that I think will appeal a wider group of gamer than MK. Nonetheless, this remains a staple for me, it's harder and thinkier, and an unsurpassed work of genius. Plus Gloomhaven spawned from here.

RATING: 7.78
Epic fantasy adventure RPG deck building exploration conquest game and whatnot!
You can go to a mission solo, together with a group or against other players, exploring ancient ruins, monster dens, dungeons, battling orcs and dragons, conquering keeps, towers and even huge cities in an amazing board game world of the Atlantean Empire.
The game is best with two players, although I had some epic experience playing solo. I know it sounds sad, but it was no different than playing Skyrim or Heroes of Might & Magic 3 campaign. With 4 or even 3 players it can drag on too long, which is ok if you are ready to commit to it, but for me, downtime in that case is unacceptable.
I love the way deck building system in Mage Knight offers tons of options and strategy and really rewords the effort.

[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.
[b]Update:[/b] Raised from 7.64 to 7.78 due to the great mechanics.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Deckbuilding where each card serves multiple purposes causing major decision making every turn.

RATING: 6
Soured a little after 6 plays. Competitive play means you can do less of what you want, either because you take opportunities from each other, or because you get spells that sabotage each other, or due to open conflict. At any rate it can become a game where you simple do less interesting stuff each turn. It can also miss fire a lot if your map comes out badly. I played a game where no monasteries came out, so little recruiting happened. The randomness of the offer decks and the tiles can determine how fun your game is going to be.

3 solo plays down, a few thoughts; The main appeal of this game is character development. If you like getting new stuff(skills, spells, items, etc) in RPGs and video games this game will be cocaine for your mind. The second major attraction is problem solving with your cards; how can i move 3 spaces, block 5 attack and deal 4 damage with the 5 cards i have in hand, my unit card and my skill tolkens? And how can i do it with maximum efficiency and set up the next turn?

The main draw backs are; its very numbers and mechanical, and so it doesn't have the magic feel of say Wiz-war. Some turns feel like the game plays itself, you look at your hand and the board and there is one optimal solution for the turn.

Whilst these draw backs are issues it stays at a 9 because it does what it does so well. Still need some multiplayer though

RATING: 6.5
Rating lowered from 8.

I have played this several times now, and each time, my opinion of it lowers just a tad.  Mage Knight is a fantastic game that covers all the grounds of what an adventure game should do - it's engaging, has lots of strategy, a good dash of luck, and is crunchy... in fact, I sometimes feel like it's a little -too- crunchy.  Considering the fact that I love wargames, that's a bit of a bone to chew on.

Overall, every piece of the table-eating game works very well with each other.  From the cards in your hand to the map tiles to the enemy tokens, it all makes sense, but to get to that point can be a daunting task.  Unless you're going to bring this to the table several times in short succession (which is a tall order given the time investment required to do a full conquest game), like most wargames, you need to sit down and re-learn this every time.

Don't get me wrong, I really like MK.  It's a very, very good game (and I'm not really sure why it got a re-theme because it stands on its own - licensing, maybe?), but when I look at the box and think, "Hm, maybe we should play this tonight..." I quickly decide not to.  There's just so much in that box that I don't wanna.

Perhaps it's my desire lately to steer away from epic games, but MK scratches a very specific itch that I don't seem to have anymore.  At least not lately.  It won't ever leave my collection because I'm sure it's one I will come back to (in fact, we always go back to it eventually), but there's something to be said when just getting the game to the table feels like an uphill battle rather than a delightful need to devour the rules and get the ball rolling.

RATING: 7
This is a superbly designed adventure/level-up sort of game.  There is a high amount of variability between plays due to: multiple scenarios, randomly generated board, multiple characters to try, multiple variants when you're familar with the game, and many different artifacts/units/actions/spells/monsters.  Sometimes these random factors can lead to a poor situation but that's definitely in the minority.  This also has a very neat day/night cycle which ties into the communal mana system.  This game also features deckbuilding as a way of doing the things you need to do ('attack' enemies, 'block' damage, 'move' around the board, and 'influence' the locals for help).  You'll go through your deck approximately 4 - 6 times in the game which is not that much.  In addition, cards you acquire go to the top of your deck rather than your discard pile similarly to the non-Freebooter Star Player cards in Blood Bowl: Team Manager.  The only reason I don't own it anymore is that It's really long and there are some fiddly rules that are easily forgotten if you don't play it frequently.

RATING: 8
1 play - 7: kinda liked it so far, we'll see i guess.


8 plays - 8: as i learn the game and get to play it more and drudge through rules less, this is getting a lot more fun/a lot less painful.


20 plays - 9: loving it!  Have a few complaints though.  Length, which i'm working on improving with timed variants.  Otherwise i dislike the ungodly number of things to keep track of.  You're bound to miss something every game, and have to rewind, assuming it's even fixable.

The game can also be frustratingly swingy at times - high variance in the cards, tiles, summoners, etc.  Some ambiguous and tedious card interactions reminiscent of Thunderstone are also occasionally annoying.  I don't like when a search doesn't turn up a clear answer.

Remains to be seen if this can get past the magic 30 play mark and beyond, but 20 plays in it's pretty damn good.


42 plays - 8: i don't think this will ever reach 10 for me after all, but it might get back to 9 sometime.  The "body buzz" has died down somewhat.  Still play it a ton, but there's just something missing...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Mage Knight is my answer to the proverbial question “If you could only keep 1 game…?” not only because of how much I enjoy playing it but for how robust the game is. I enjoy it competitively, cooperatively, and solitaire (if you’re not aware, it’s the highest ranked solo game by the BGG solitaire community). Heck, my friends and I even have an idea to play a 2 v 2 team match and I’m quite sure it’ll work just fine. 

There’s a pretty clear “on-off” point with the game in how you use your cards to puzzle out the optimum move every turn. Either that is gaming crack or you just don’t get it, but if you’re wondering why the game is such a hit with a lot of people, it’s because Vlaada has made the strategic deckbuilder [i]par excellence[/i] in the hobby. 

Admittedly, there’s a steep learning curve and new players may feel like they’re flailing and downtime may seem severe. These are both curable with repeated play. Those that stop at this place miss out on breaking through to the sublimity that lies beneath. My advice is to introduce new players via the cooperative mode and help them play their hands until they get up and running.  

I strongly recommend getting the Lost Legion expansion for the updated cards and tokens alone. The Volkare element is just a bonus variation for coop or solo play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1.5
[b]Traded[/b]
Yeah, Mage Knight is one of the worst games I've ever played.  I happily traded it away for all the reasons listed below.

[b]previous comment:[/b]

Note:  My "plays" count is misleading - I've attempted this game many more times, and have quit in boredom partway through for most of them.  I only logged the first time I ever played it solo, so I'd remember exactly when I first tried it.

This game feels super fiddly.  I've gotten bored and quit partway through almost every time I've played.  If I am going to spend this much time memorizing this many rules, I'd rather just play D&D, which is at least engaging.

I'm kind of baffled at how highly this is ranked, when opinions seem to be so thoroughly split on it.

I'm even more baffled that people argue that this game is thematic.  It's not.  It's slightly more thematic than Dominion.  The entire game is nothing but an optimization problem.  Use what you know about your hand to do some card counting, and plan out your round accordingly.  The so-called "thematic" mechanics lose their theme the second you use them, because all you do is optimize between the positive and negative numbers for each action.

This game feels more like I'm creating a spreadsheet than playing a game.

It also has one of the worst rule books I've ever seen for a game.  In a lot of games with a lot of complex rules, there are some sort of reference documents - a convenient table, or better yet, a great player board which includes little summaries.  Mage Knight leaves me thumbing through the manual more than playing the game.

I'm convinced that AT LEAST half of the people who praise this game are getting at least one of the rules wrong.  There are so many poorly explained subtleties that I simply find it implausible to believe that the majority aren't missing at least one of them.  I've caught a new one in every game I've attempted - that's usually the part where I say "screw this!" and move on to another game that's actually fun.

Other metaphors for the game play experience: doing my taxes, organizing a stamp collection, and extreme couponing

Another amazing metaphor (from http://www.quartertothree.com/fp/2017/02/14/10-reasons-mage-knight-worst-boardgame-time/):  A bucket into which numbers are dumped.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
[u]The Good[/u]: 1) Deep, intelligent. Some games play themselves; this is not one of them. 2) Will continue to challenge you regardless of how good you get at it (and the spread from being a "bad" player until finally becoming [I]good[/I] is vast and long and fraught with many many hours of brain-burning.. hooray-ness).

[u]The Bad[/u]: 1) Limited number of Scenarios (ie: game modes); an incoming Expansion will be adding at least 4 new ones, which may end up fixing this. 2) Doesn't play well with more than 3 players.

[u]The Bottomline[/u]: This game is an absolute must-buy if you go into it knowing that it will not deliver if you're looking to make an RPG/Adventure game out of it. Rather it's a puzzle game first, with facets of deckbuilding, all tied to the foundation of a really theme-y map with lots of RPG/Adventure elements sown throughout.

2p - intro, 1p intro

July 2014: I went into this playing excited to finally try Mage Knight, but it did nothing for me. The trappings of exploring a fantastic land and engaging in battles gave way to a (finely tuned) Euro that offered me no sense of narrative. Orcs here, orcs there; these ones stats are 4-5-4-poison, these ones are 4-4-3. I'd say I'd give it another chance, but with such a long playing time, it's hard to get excited about a second playing. It's a deep euro which can be played well (no concerns about mechanical soundness). If it was 90 minutes long, I'd give it a few more plays to explore it. As is, I'll pass.

It's not a terrible game, but it's not my sort of game.

RATING: 8.2

I must say I am certainly impressed with Vlaada Chvátil.  I have yet to be disappointed with one of his games.  

3rd game played was in co-op with 2 others. The play is much different.  An enthusiast of the game said the expansion Lost Legions is a must for co-op play.

RATING: 10
Card driven puzzle adventure game about character growth and conquest

Pro
-Extremely tight and well designed game with very rewarding/narrow combat elements
-Deeply brain burning, but great for people that enjoy puzzles and optimizing their resources (cards in hand)
-Has a good sense of exploration, character growth and also liked that you could perform good deeds or evil deeds in game (e.g. burning down a monastery)
-Can be played competitively or cooperatively with different scenarios
-Streamlined the book keeping in some ways - next player can fully take their turn while the previous player does all their level up/loot collecting etc.
-One of the best solo games I've played

Cons
-Long game length (3+ hours) is not for everyone
-Steep learning curve
-Somewhat anti-climatic end game fights
-Long game rounds for players prone to AP (especially in "boss" fights)
-When playing with others, you will feel rushed to act and may not be able to look through all the options (often quite a few) available to you
-Miniatures and some component qualities (aside from cards) are average

RATING: 8
My god this game is long, and has a tonne of convoluted rules! However unlike Arkham Horror, the chrome is pretty coherent and affect the gameplay. There are a lot of important decisions, and despite the die rolls, tile flips, card draws and chit pulls, you have considerable control over what happens.

Over 3 games (and a peek at at PBF game) I became a much, much better player. However the rules are insanely fiddly, causing me to spend a lot of time on bookkeeping and rules-lookup (even though I push through the smaller gaps), breaking immersion. I really wish they were simplified, made more consistent, or better cued graphically.

For example, elemental resistance works differently between your units and enemies; there are 3 different types of monster dungeons (in addition to settlements, fortifications, and roving enemies)

That said, there's huge variety with all the different types of monsters, units, spells, actions, and so on, which provide a level of "emergent narrative" and bricolage gameplay. It is perhaps the exploration adventure game that I've been looking for, but covered in so much mechanical bookkeeping that I'm finding it hard to recognise.

It takes forever solo; I can't imagine playing with 4p, and teaching is sure to be crazy. The interaction appears to be almost entirely of the annoying, negative, swingy kind, making me think that it's not worth the effort.

I'm not sure how much variety the setup (as opposed to the card and skill draws) provides.

Supposedly Magic Realm is still superior...

RATING: 10
It is a very good solo game, perhaps the first true solo game i have ever played. Even if it is a really complicated game (rulewise), it is pretty easy to get into it : after 2 plays, you are in. I have followed the general advice to read the playbook and to watch Ricky Royal's videos and this help a lot.

The brillance of this game is in the cards : each turn, you will have to adapt to your hand (you have 5 cards in hand at the beginning of the game) and resolve the puzzle. There is room for strategy though :

1) unlike Dominion, you can keep cards from turn to turn (at the end of your turn, you can discard cards and you replenish your hand to your hand limit) : this is why it is possible to plan for the next turn

2) you can always play any card (except wound card) as a 1 point of the action you take

3) cards earned when leveling up is put on top of your deck, hence ready for the next turn

4) mana allow you to strengthen the card effect and as a result, helps you to better manage your hand.

The combat system is really interesting : the enemies always attack first except when you are able to launch a siege or range attack. This prevent the game to become a shoot-them-up-all because you will have to block the attack in order not to be wounded (wound cards go in your hand directly and slow your deck rotation down). Only after the enemies have attacked you and you had a chance to block, you are allowed to attack them.

So each attack must be careful planned : it is certainly well advise to wait the next turn to attack an enemy if you have not enough attack points in your hand this turn. Or perhaps you choose to take the risk (certain enemies are not revealed before the combat) and deal with the wounds because you can get rid of it (you have cards and/or units with curative effects, you are in a village or a monastery). But it is up to you to decide at the end.

The different places, enemies, advanced actions, units, spells, artifacts, scenarios (solo, cooperative, competitive) provided bring a lot of gaming and diversity out of the box.

I must say that the french translation is awesome, consistent, really well written, in very good french. This has to be point out given the complexity and quantity of rules in this game (2 books of 20 pages each).
