RATING: 7
An epic and challenging strategic adventure game with a high entry cost. The most compelling aspect is how every turn is a complex resource optimization puzzle. It is very rewarding to be able to pull off a killer combo but, at the same time, the very nature of the game can easily lead to frustration when you draw the wrong card at the wrong moment, discover (after doing your math) that you are one point flat from taking out an enemy, or when you suddenly lose the one mana you needed not to waste your entire turn. The clock is always ticking and it is unforgiving.

While Mage Knight can provide an epic sense of adventure, with an immersive theme and varied and interesting enemies/encounters, learning to play the game is hard. If you don’t play often you will find yourself referencing the manuals constantly. Downtime can be brutal, and even playing solo can span multiple nights per game due to how much you can end up reconsidering your next move. Also the cooperative variant is barely so. Not recommended for more than two, and good luck anyway trying to convince a newcomer to take the time to learn it.

So, if you think you have the time and patience to commit to learning this game and step up to the often-frustrating challenge, there is much to love in Mage Knight.

RATING: 6
Extremely complicated and requires a ton of set up. Would honestly be better served as a co-op/competitive RPG for iPad and/or PC. Combat is also too deterministic (as in: completely deterministic apart from a few situations where you'll face a random monster from the pile). So most of the time you can calculate exactly which fights you will and won't win, which saps a lot of drama from the game. 

The rule book is badly done, which is rather unfortunate for a game like this. At the most fundamental level, required information should not be split across what are obstensibly the "new player's starting guide" and the "comprehensive reference." Somehow there is quite a lot of information in the "new player's" book that is missing from the "comprehensive" book- including information about the same topic, e.g. combat. You will be paging back and forth between them for quite a while. More rules are hidden on various location/monster/doodad cards so you will be paging through those as well. 

Apart from that, it's a reasonably well-implemented game. Unlike games like Arkham Horror, Mage Knight actually has some interesting gameplay under the pile of excessive bookkeeping. There is a massively overcomplicated system of leveling up that still manages to be fun. 

Don't try this without 1+ other people willing to slog through a 3-4 hour marathon, though.

The reference cards help with remembering all the little details though.  Just go slow at first and give yourself time to get good at the game. RATING: 9
Wow. It takes a while to learn Mage Knight, but once you do you are in for a fantasy treat. Rampaging across the countryside and mowing down orcs and dragons? Check. Showing up in a village to recruit its ablest young men as battle fodder with a solemn heroic promise and then turning right around and pillaging the place to add a power or two to your next turn? Check. Taking a small detour to lay siege to a mage tower and pilfer a powerful spell to make your grim march toward your objective a little easier? Check. And you have to do all that and more, because when you finally get to those cities you are fated to conquer at all costs, it'll take every last drop of blood and magic you can muster to topple its defenders. This game manages to scratch just about every epic fantasy itch you might need a board game to scratch. It does solo, co-op, and competitive, whatever you want. The potential turnoffs are that it does take hours to play on top of the steep learning curve. It's the most absorbing solo game I have, though, and I love burning through a few hours to try to conquer the land.

RATING: 7
Mage Knight is first and foremost a solo puzzle game. In a way that is not too dissimilar from e.g. Dungeon Lords where the apparent core game (there Worker Placement, here Deck Building) merely serves as trappings for solving the challenge presented to you on the board. Mage Knight is probably a little more successful in hiding this simply because of the wealth of trappings thrown in the way of the players.

That said, all those trappings come for a price. Even though most of the rules are fairly intuitive there are many of them, and that results in a steep learning curve at the beginning. This is clearly a game that rewards repeated plays and benefits a lot from not having to learn the rules from the rulebook. The wealth of options provided by those rules on one hand creates lots of interesting choices and opportunities for clever play, but on the other also provides lots of room for mental breakdowns and excessive downtimes, so it's no wonder the game is usually considered better with fewer players. Since it's mostly solo play anyway, that doesn't seem like too much of a disadvantage, though.

What kind of impresses me most about Mage Knight is how the designer succeeded to make this mostly mechanical puzzle still feel like a very thematic fantasy romp. It obviously has a lot of appeal for both gamer factions but I'm still not quite sure how he managed to pull that off.

RATING: 10
Easily my favorite game. Only con to this game is hard to get others to play because of the long games. I love long games though so it doesn't bother me. Tons of replay value, even for solo play, and requires a lot of strategy to accomplish scenarios. Mage Knight isn't as tough to learn as people say it is in my opinion, it just takes a few play through's and you'll get it.
I have the Lost Legion expansion and highly recommend getting it, it adds more uniqueness to the mage knights and fixes some mistakes made in the original print.
I highly recommend if you like games that require thinking and strategy and don't mind 2-3 hour games. I'd stay away if you only enjoy short party games with little depth.

One last thing to add is the replay value of this game is almost infinite. I have over 15 plays and each time was faced with different world to explore with different challenges. Also, I highly recommend getting card sleeves, a plastic token box(6$ at Walmart), and printing out some of the optional card boxes and map cards found in the forums for this game here on boardgamegeek. They increase the longevity of this game and make set up and putting away much smoother and faster.

Keep on hunting fellow Mage Knights!

RATING: 9.5
The best RPG boardgame out there. When you level up and get new skills and advanced actions you feel more powerful (unlike other RPG boardgames where I've seen "hi-level" heroes being trashed by low-level monsters). All the mechanic fit well and this game feels very thematic to me, so I don't understand why other people are calling it "unthematic" and "a soulless euro". I can see the luck having an impact on players turns, but I have found it managable in all the games I played so far. Never have I felt screwed over by luck. The only problem I have with Mage Knight is the lack of quests - i.e. some way of acquiring quests from the village and fulfilling them getting fame and reputation to make the game more diverse. 

Edit: After over 30 plays of the game I can see why people get frustrated while playing this. There IS a lot of luck involved (the tiles, the monsters) which can screw you over. But since I'm playing it strictly co-operatively now, I don't mind the luck as much. It remains as one of the most thematic games I've played.

RATING: 9

For thematic reasons (like the fortified spice worm stolen from dune:) - 2. For gameplay reasons, since all those rules add to the variety and complexity of the puzzles the game presents to you.

RATING: 9
Mage Knight reminds me of elements I enjoyed from a high school algebra class or working in excel. I would describe this game as thematic algebra, which is strongly appealing to me. It is a mathematic puzzle of how to efficiently use the cards in your hand (and troops you buy, skills you acquire, reputation you earn, magic enhancement (via dice, stored crystals, and short term gains)) against your location on the board. There are often three or four ways to earn fame (VP) at your location by applying a dozen different variables that reset each turn. All of them can be viable, but one of them tends to be best. The genius of the game is that the math you apply to solve the puzzles feels thematic and relevant to what you are doing.

Mage Knight is, essentially, a highly replayable set of algebraic storybook problems themed as a very slick RPG game. the mechanics remind me of a deeper puzzle solving version of Troyes, but with a theme near and dear to my heart. The design is genius, but if spending hours playing around with IF statements in excel is not fun for you, don't ever play this game.

IF(3*B3+C4/2>A3,"KILL THE DRAGON","DRAGON KILLS YOU")

For the price of this game, there are some disappointing component issues. The tiles warped notably during our initial play and the printing at the edges was loose. The warping supposedly resolves over time, but the loose printing is terrible.

Some cards showed wear/minor damage IN THE SHRINK. I threw them in clear Dragon shields and am less concerned about the card issues.

NOTE: I would not recommend this at four player.

RATING: N/A
This is a game of non-decisions based upon random hands of cards dealt from decks far too similar to one another. Though one can perfectly well keep track of what cards are left in his deck due to its small size, that won't help anything if you have a wonderful combat hand but no way to walk to where any combat is possible. You might draw a lot of movement for your first hand and then you have no idea where you'll need to be to use your next cards. You can hold on to cards to design your hand, but then you've effectively crippled yourself with a smaller hand-size. Unfortunately, building your deck to differentiate yourself from other players is so slow as to be hardly worth mentioning. The way the powerful part of cards is locked behind mana barriers is the only interesting design decision here.
Combat is dull because there's so little surprise to it. You'll never put yourself in a combat scenario without a hand of cards that can handle combat.

(1 play)

RATING: 8
When I saw this at BGGCON 2011, it was on my list to try but was never able to play it due to the vender's availability; gone to lunch, got the crud, and then went home.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Finally got to play Mage Knight - a game that has actually become a sort of joke to end a night of board gaming, "So... anyone for a game of Mage Knight?"  It was intimidating to be sure, but I managed to borrow by brother-in-law's copy and read the rules and played a couple of solo turns to get a feel.  Played a 2-player game with Brendon tonight to see how it actually shakes out.

There is a lot of interesting stuff going on in Mage Knight.  The card play is the meat of the game and is actually quite puzzly and feels very open.  Play your cards one way and you get an entirely different turn than if you play them the other way. Even playing them in a different order can garner very different results. So there's a lot of humming and hawing about how exactly to play your turn out.  This can lead to an almost silly amount of downtime and resetting your turn multiple times. But I think that's mainly a product of the uninitiated.  I can see familiarity with this game ironing out those issues, though I would never want to play this with 4 players, even if they all had a couple of games under their belts.  Even though I think the card system makes for many choices, you are still frustratingly cut out of what you want to do at times, as the cards may simply not be there.  And you may be in positions to really kick ass (and there's rarely if ever any hidden information on monsters) and you just go in and do that. No surprises.  In the end, I think Mage Knight is fascinating in many respects and is one of the heaviest modern adventuring fantasy games I've played.  I do think it does suffer at times with turns just not feeling "fun".  It's so mechanically heavy that its theme at times gets lost in all the heavy.  Yes, you will suffer, and feel let down, and you can definitely "rest" and hope the right cards come your way, or come up with a different plan with the cards you have.  But the struggle is so deep that it takes a razor's edge to the thrill these types of games generally get out of me.  It is certainly one of the most crunchiest types of these games I've ever played.  So there.  I like Mage Knight.  I respect Mage Knight. I would play Mage Knight again.  But I had a hard time believing in the world of Mage Knight, if that makes any sense.

RATING: 9
Fun - I haven't tried the solitaire scenario yet, which may bump the game up to an 8. Has a great flavor and feeling to it, the mage knights do feel like strong heroes rampaging through the countryside.
Main downside is the length, especially with many players. Additionally there is a pretty high random component, with card drawing, dice rolling, and monster generation all potentially creating large swings. This is compounded by minimal rubber banding mechanics, so that one or two early lucky breaks can pretty much decide a game.
At the end of the day, a blast to play - if you have a day.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
I hated this game the first time I played it... I disliked my second play of it... and on my third attempt... CLICK! Whoa! What is this game!? To make a long story short it became my favorite game and remained there for a long while. It's an euro disguised in AT/RPG clothes. Your brain will melt, for real. Just find someone to teach you the game as the rule book is a monster. 

The character progression (deck building) is so gratifying. I mean when you start the game you can barely defeat a simple enemy and by the end of the game you have such powers that you can kill a dragon with your hand of cards and clever play. 

Each game tells a story. You can recruit soldiers, golems, build catapults. You can be a hero loved by all of you can be a nasty villain that steals and burns monasteries to the ground. The artifacts and spells you can collect are so cool. But to achieve great things you must be smart and use your cards and resources wisely. There is no dice rolling here. You must prepare and evaluate and do the best you can with the hand you are dealt.   

This is Vlaada's masterpiece.

RATING: 7.5
Whoa, this was a chore to learn...and then you play it, and it doesn't seem so bad. Just, fiddly. This is an adventure puzzler. A more mechanical/predictable version of Runebound. That said, for the effort it takes to learn this you must REALLY decide what kind of adventure game you're looking for. Do you want a story, or just to imagine exploring forests or dungeons? With much less effort I get that feeling from Runebound, or the Dungeons and Dragons Adventure games. They are nowhere near as rules fiddly as this. However, this game, while lacking in a progressive story, has much deeper decisions involved in every action. Planning movement, how to use your hand of cards optimally, do I risk checking out those ruins or not? It's a pretty cool game, but you have to be in a special mood to bother with learning it and setting it up. I need to try it with the expansions to see what that adds. Also, I probably would only play this solo, or 2 players MAX. It would take forever otherwise.

RATING: 10
Others have said much better than I can why this game is pure awesomeness.

Playing cooperative games only, this game is particular because the interaction is quite limited: players need to coordinate at the end of the game for the final assault, but other than that, everyone is pretty much on their own. It's interesting for people that don't want competitive gameplay but still want to make decisions and develop their own strategy without too much impact on the group.

The game also excels at creating a new challenge each game. Unlike many other coop games, even when you know the game very well, it's still a challenge and a brain-intensive process to win (difficulty is also very customizable).

RATING: 3.85
This was a great disappointment for me. As a fan of heavy games and deckbuilding I was ecstatic to give this a shot. I usually love everything Vlaada releases, but for me he was too ambitious on this game. I like a lot of things about this game, but the bad out-weight the good. THE GOOD: The mechanics are tight, and you get the constant pressure of needing to do more in your turn. The game is a sandbox experience, but still keeps a known end in sight at all times. Components are good. THE BAD: The rulebook. One of the worst designer games rulebooks I've read in a while. I love playing heavy games, and I don't mind a rulebook that's 40+ pages long. I do not like a game that has a cluster of various mechanics and exceptions and not having the ruling for them handy. The amount of options and little rules hidden in this book creates slow pace games, and long turns, and gives the sensation that it this games is in desperate need of streamlining. This is one of those games that requires a lot of plays to get the hang of it, and multiple reading of its rulebooks. I love when a game has so much to offer and it takes dozens of plays to explore it all, I don't love when the effort to get to the point to appreciate this game is more than you get out of it. I would only recommend this game to people with very small collections or solo gamers that have the time to dedicate the amount needed to properly enjoy this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My current favorite board game, and probably the most brilliant game design I've ever seen. MKBG is an extremely multifaceted game that offers a rich playing experience. It rates high on both randomness and skill, which is a combination I look for in games. The core of MKBG is a deck-building card game, and everything else is arranged around that core. 

Most deck-builders focus more on choosing the cards you'd like to draw later, and less on figuring out the best way to actually play your hand. MKBG is not like that. The tactics of card play are extremely complex, challenging, and flexible. Every card can be used in at least six ways, two primary and four secondary. There is the card's standard effect, an advanced effect that requires you to spend mana, and four generic wild-card effects that are shared by all cards. And even once you've chosen which cards to play for which effects, there are further decisions about how to apply those effects. Where do you move? What battles will you fight? How will you assign your blocking, wounds, attacks, etc.? How will you get the mana you need? Which cards should you conserve for next round? Are you willing to blow a bunch of these cards for weaker wild-card effects just to get to the cards you need? Or should you just rest and do some discarding so that your hand is stronger next turn?

Also, there is much more to MKBG than just the card play. There is an entire map to explore. Where you travel and where you are positioned are extremely important, because they determine your current and future opportunities. Each location has different challenges, different benefits. There are units to recruit into your army. The units don't go into your deck. They stay on the table, and can provide a variety of services at crucial moments. There is a constantly-changing shared mana pool, with dice showing different colors of mana. There are mana crystals, which allow you to store mana of a specific color until you need it. There are Tactics cards that you draft, which also don't go into your deck. Those determine turn order and usually give you a special power for the round. As you gain fame, you will benefit from special skill tiles, increased resistance to wounds, a larger hand size, and the ability to command more units. There is also your reputation to consider, which affects the way you interact with many of the board locations.

The cards you draw will often prevent you from doing what you would like to do in the way you would like to do it. But with experience, you learn that there's always a way to work around this. There is a great deal of power in planning ahead in MKBG. Novice players probably will approach the game one turn at a time, and may not see the more strategic elements. But the best players are always thinking about their next turn, and the turn after that, and the rest of the round, and the rest of the game. You want to have a plan for what you're doing over the next several hands, but you need to stay flexible and willing to re-order things or develop contingency plans.

RATING: 6
Well done adventure game with upleveling and light deck building and planable fights. A bit long for what it is or with other words don't play with A/P prone players. The game is [i]not[/i] that complicated that one needs 15 mins to take his turn... Moving costs seem a bit high, so with a bad luck of draw (the game is card driven) you cannot move for some turns. But overall it's a clever desgin: many adventure games are like this:  "move, discover, roll some dice for combat, do the bookkeeping", repeat. Mage Knight is different: you have to manage your resources very well: "move / attack / block / influence" all this is very well interwoven with manacost management.
After my second play with 4 players, I had to downrate it from 7, but why? All players were already experienced. Not counting setup in, we played (rounded down) 4 hours for the 4 Cities scenario.
4 hours for a 4 player game. Now do the math yourself: how long did I play and how long did I wait? Yes during 4 hours I played one hour the rest I waited to do my fellow players their turns.
I consider downtime a major fun killer. It seems that the author didn't want to relinquish one of his ideas for this game resulting in a very slow pace with too much downtime. The math you have to do later in the game when sieging Cities is too much.

RATING: 5
Tentative rating after one play. 

I believe that the downtime of this game is significant and quite frustrating after a while. I also believe that that may be because we had to check a lot of rules now and again. 

This looks like a computer game in boardgame form. It has some deck-building mechanics and there is little you can do each turn. If you get all the movement cards or the attack cards together, which can sometimes occur, you're screwed. The problem is that the discarding is penalizing in this game, so the types of cards you get are going to make a big difference. You just cannot spend cards the "any cards" just to have 1 move, 1 attack or 1 influence, because that is going to impact a lot on your overall game. 

This starts as a quite simple game, and becomes very difficult as it goes on. I would compare it to Le Havre: you have so many things that you need to do, and only little that you can actually do. The other players' actions are very relevant since they can make and brake the game for you. 

DO NOT play with known AP people. 

UPDATE
I played again. The first impressions stand. 

This game is insufferably long. With just 2 players the game went 4 hours and a half long.

RATING: 7.5
Not actually as complicated as some people seem to think.  The main problem is the difficulty, it takes a number of plays before you really get to grips with how to build and use your deck effectively, and by then you may have given up.  I think it actually works better as a single player game as you have more options that way, and there is considerably less downtime.  Play the game a lot single player and master the mechanics, lend the game to a dedicated friend and get them to do the same, and then try it 2 player.  If that works, repeat the process with 2 more people and Bingo - you've got yourself the most in depth game you've ever played.  Otherwise you just have an amazing idea, well executed and beautifully made, that is just a little too much hard work to be truly enjoyable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I can't praise the game enough. It's theme permeates every aspect of the game: you're a Mage Knight, gifted with nearly god-like powers and supreme competence, out to explore and conquer the map. You can hire natives, interact with dwellings and cities, visit magical glades and mines, or just lie down and heal. Sooner or later, though, it's time to unleash your fury, and you do this by managing your deck of cards and planning your strategy. Under the threat of the round ending before you're done, you've got to be clever and efficient.

The game reminds me of Magic Realm on occasion, but it's simpler and full of action and excitement. MR is a tough game to crack, but Mage Knight lets you in and welcomes you. Both games will capture your imagination and keep you thinking about strategies and failures (and victories!) long after you've put the box away.

I love a game that plays well no matter how many players there are. Play solo and you'll have a blast; add more people and you'll find an even richer experience. Downtime is minimal, and your fellow players can both directly and indirectly affect your turn (this isn't Runebound).

The game is beautiful, the rulebooks are EXCELLENT, and the atmosphere of the game is compelling, engrossing, and fascinating. It gets the coveted 10.

RATING: 5
This game is okay. It's a beautiful game with many cool pieces. But, the beauty of it can't, for me, overcome three big issues.

It's too freaking long. I played a game with four players and it took five hours. There are too may rules and too much that a player has to manage on one turn. Even if you know what you're going to do on your turn you're stuck waiting for the other players to plod through their turns. 

There is no excitement in the game. If you've suffered through getting your hand right, you know the outcome of facing a challenge before you go into it. There is no chance for real risk, and that thrill is absent from the game. Turns are players mumbling to themselves about what they can do or are going to do with their decks. The only real chance in the game is how far or how little you'll move during a given turn. All-in-all, pretty bland. 

There are too many complexities to manage in the game. I know some may like that, but the management of minutia has robbed this game of its thrill. I felt like I was an accountant in a Dungeons & Dragons game gone bad, more than I felt like I was Tovag the Conqueror.

It's not terrible, though. I don't want to play it again, but it's not Axis and Allies bad. I was just bored a lot during game play and never felt threatened or at risk during the game. And again, it's way too long.

RATING: 8
Rating based on 2-player and solitaire games.  Down to a '7' with 3-player, and a '5' with 4-players.  Downtime increases with more players, without an increase in fun.

For the wargamers, think of city assaults as 'STAVKA' turns; for each player there will be a city, and each city will probably be assaulted twice.  With 2 players, this isn't so bad because the other player can help with the accounting and plan his next move.  With more than 2 players, the others are going to be frequently bored.

Includes The Lost Legion and Krang expansions

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This could have been an excellent adventure game, but it is severely marred by excessive complexity. Using deck building as the core mechanic is an interesting and novel idea in the genre, but it makes every turn a puzzle to figure out, particularly when it involves fighting monsters. Combat is so fiddly, with all the special abilities and resistances of monsters and allies, that the game really drags with analysis paralysis.

Most rule details seem to have a thematic reason, but this game would actually have benefited from more abstraction. The rules for putting monster tokens on the map are a good example: depending on the kind of location, they are placed face up or down, and in some it differs whether it's day or night. For cities, you always reveal them when you are adjacent, but you do it for keeps and towers only during the day, and not for dungeons until you explore them. I have come to expect some fiddliness from Vlaada, but here he took it to a wholly new level, with two long rulebooks to cover everything.

The publisher contributed further to harm the game with errors and a tiny font in the rules and components, not to mention a likely imposition on the designer to include their "clix" dials. They are used in absolutely unnecessary city miniatures just to set their level when they are revealed. Reference cards would have been much more practical and less expensive, but, instead, the important info is on annoying and extremely hard-to-read dials that WizKids have to include in every game they produce, for no good reason.

In the end, the game is just too complex and too long, even in solo mode, and with too much downtime with other players. I admit I enjoyed my three plays (two solo games and one with another player), but I guess I'm done with it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
7 como puntuación inicial.

MK es un juego de aventuras, exploración, aliados, misiones, enemigos y un largo etc, todo ello desarrollado y al parecer muy bien implementado con mecánicas adoptadas de los juegos dirigidos por cartas y los juegos de construcción de mazos.

A primera vista parece que la gestión del mazo inicial es lo mas importante. Las reglas están bien implementadas para la curva de aprendizaje que tiene el juego.

En el lado negativo podemos encontrar que a 4 jugadores puede haber mucho tiempo muerto, algo que el diseñador a querido minimizar en todo momento con diferentes reglas, tiempos y consejos que da en el tutoríal del juego

----------

Nota rebajada por no cumplir para mi con el objetivo para el que creo que está diseñado.
Tras una segunda partida las expectativas sobre este juego como juego de aventuras han bajado bastante en cuanto se refiere a las reglas originales.

El juego funciona muy bien con 2, pero con 4 jugadores para mi y para el grupo con el que quiero jugar a este juego tiene varios problemas que debemos solucionar si quiere ver mesa.

### Efecto líder
Si alguien consigue despegar es muy difícil que los otros jugadores puedan echarle el guante y encima es algo que puede producirse de forma casual al empezar la partida:
**Supuesto 1** Comienzas tu partida y vas a por una ficha de orcos, la das la vuelta y ohhhh, suerte, puedes bloquearla sin mucha dificultad y te los cargas con una carta potenciada con mana, te dan 4 puntos de fama y subes de nivel, en los turnos siguientes te vas a por la torre de mago con tu nueva habilidad  y una carta avanzada en la mano la ficha no es muy tocha y te cepillas a los guardianes de la torre pillas un hechizo y o has vuelto a subir de nivel o andas cerca del siguiente, tienes varias cartas tochas en el mazo y puedes ir enfrentandote a lo que vaya saliendo.

**Supuesto 2** El siguiente jugador se va a por la otra ficha de orco, esta es de las que sacas un monstruo de otra pila que pega por el, pruebas suerte pero salen unas ratas que lo devoran todo y te comes 7 cartas de daño, te quedas un turno curandote de la paliza que te han dado y luego sigues tu camino aunque por lo menos subes de nivel.

**Supuesto 3** Los otros dos jugadores se van al pueblo para ver si pillan algo porque no hay mas bichos y los otros dos jugadores ya están en el segundo nivel.

El caso es que como uno logre despegar tiene un mazo mas poderoso que hace que pueda enfrentarse medianamente a los peligros del juego y los demás anden corriendo de un sitio a otro.

### Los tiempos muertos
El grupo con el que probé el juego es bastante agradecido y lo de los tiempos muertos lo llevamos bastante bien si el juego es lo suficientemente narrativo y el tema está integrado (y este es así), pero considero que el juego es absurdamente complejo para jugadores temáticos interesados en jugar aventuras y muchas de las decisiones las tomamos en plan mente colmena, el jugador ponía lás cartas sobre la mesa y entre todos resolvíamos el puzzle en función de lo que quisiera hacer, esto no es malo de por si, pero frustra una barbaridad.

### El enriscamiento o quedarte aislado sin poder moverte.
Para mi lo peor del juego y en algo que coincidimos todos los jugadores: que te veas de noche rodeado por fichas de bosque y wastelands o por el día rodeado de desiertos y mas wastelands ¿Por donde sales? Y ¿Cuanto vas a tardar? Si el tener que salir de un desierto a base de conseguir 5 puntos de movimiento se considera divertido y desafiante apaga y vamonos.

El movimiento es muy costoso y penalizante lo que te niega posibilidades y tomas de decisiones y esto con cuatro jugadores es muy acusado. Cuando juegas a un juego de aventuras uno tiene que ser libre de intentar y de elegir su propio camino pero con un movimiento tan limitado los jugadores invierten un montón de tiempo en optimizar las 5 cartas y no en decidir si voy a un dungeon, asalto el castillo o contrato mercenarios, 
 Simplemente te dedicas a buscar el mejor combo para arañar puntos.

### Conclusión (parcial)
Mage knight es muy buen juego y esta muy bien desarrollado, pero tiene una curva de aprendizaje y unas mecánicas que parece diseñado por Uwe Rosenberg para la franquicia del Agrícola y no como juego de aventuras donde uno explora y machaca a amigos y enemigos, si quiero que vuelva a ver mesa tengo que crear unas reglas caseras que hagan mas fácil el movimiento y de esta manera evitar el enriscamiento, esto reduciría los tiempos muertos e indirectamente creo que acabaría con el efecto líder al dar mas posibilidades de hacer cosas a los jugadores. Tal y como están redactadas las reglas no cumple con el objetivo de ser un juego de aventuras, por lo menos para nosotros.

### Bola extra
Las cartas son de ínfima calidad y se pelan solas, estas hay que enfundarlas si o si.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Ok, had my first play and I have mixed feelings about this game. There are two games: the actual game and the game of ACTUALLY TRYING TO UNDERSTAND THE RULES. What a fiddly game - the designer seemed to want to overly complicate things just.. because. So many things could be simpler here. Combat is horrible. Taking damage? Got damn, complicated as hell - to the point of me mentally regretting entering combat just because I know if I take damage I have to keep remembering how the mechanic of taking damage works. Setup was a nightmare. It took me about 20 minutes to setup the game.

The game walkthrough and rulebook do help - but it is not as well explained and well edited as it could be. The letters are WAY too small, and sometimes there is this humongous mass of text that you need to search for a specific ruling or explanation and you feel like reading the bible. This could be easily solved with more title descriptions, paragraph separations and general hierarchy of information - and BIGGER text. I made a LOT of mistakes because I didn't understand the rules properly. I had to keep coming back to the game walkthrough and it was a pain to find the information I wanted.

Having said that, I was actually in the zone with the game. I really enjoyed it once we grasped the rules and I was eager to discover more tiles, kill more monsters, deck build and enter dungeons and monster dens.

I really want to play it more but the back of my brain is actually screaming "OH GOD WHY", when it remembers the rules and the setup of the game. I hope the next session will be smoother but that is not how a game should treat its players.

RATING: 8
It's interesting, and fun, and it gets a lot of things right. I'm not sure I enjoy the puzzle aspect of how to play your cards, though, and the advancement seems weird--your deck improves very little in terms of card churn, but gains very powerful cards when used correctly (spells especially)--but your non-deck stuff grows by leaps and bounds. The game is thus about bringing to bear those crushingly effective card combinations and milking your deck well. In an actual deck-builder, you'll go through your deck many times--here, you'll go through it six times max. It's weird but intriguing. 
The biggest issue is the length. I'm not sure it justifies its playtime, but I think it does--barely.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Absolutely fantastic. This is a GREAT game. I say this with confidence after aprox 20 solo plays. So replayable, so much to keep you coming back for. As thematic as it is, make no mistake - MK is a euro through and through. 

Had some component issues: 4 cards were missing (3 for arythea and 1 artifact), instead I got 4 duplicates of other cards. Submitted replacement request on Wizkids website on 01/13/2012, received shipping confirmation on 01/22/2012, received replacements on 02/07/2012. Coloring on new cards is slightly darker than originals :(

Criticism of the rulebook is warranted. While not the worst I've read, it definitely over-complicates and intimidates. Much has been said about people's preference regarding walk-through and rules being seperate. To this I'll add that things are often repeated and/or restated in different ways and places. Rules writing is an art; look no further than a Chad Jensen game to see how complexity should be distilled. (Don't let this scare you; the rules aren't terrible. They just could have been done better.)

So what do I like about it? Beautiful to look at when playing - modular board, cute dice, minis (some with click bases), cards with great art, consistent iconography. Nice mechanics - deck building, choices choices choices, resource mgmt (crystals). Note that the game is VERY stingy with resources and new cards for your deck. Engine building - your mage knight starts out with great power and ends up with INSANE power.

Game is great. Awesome for solitaire play. 

Warning: High levels of AP

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Mage Knight is mostly touted for its suitability for solo play and that's inevitably where it shines. I absolutely love the rules, which many here have complained about. They are extremely thematical and intuitive and they give solo players enough options to ponder to really immerse themselves into this world. 

However, I would never ever play this with a friend. It's too heavy a game for that and in retrospect I'm glad that this was one the first board games I bought when I got into the hobby since now I know to stay away from heavy games not intented for solo play.

Mage Knight is very pretty and I like the depth of rules but the base game doesn't really have the appeal that modern games do. These days you've got legacy games, different missions and all that. MK really only has 1 mission. This comes with different variations but the changes are tiny. Basically you're just roaming the world quite aimlessly. The Lost Legion expansion introduces a much needed boss to fight but it's quite expensive for what it is. Another thing I have an issue with is the card drafting process. You're constantly in the position where you just wanna move but your cards only aid you to fight. There's nothing brain burning or puzzling about this, it's just frustrating. The battles on the other hand are delicious and that's where the puzzle reveals itself as you're desperately trying to optimize your hand and thinking how many wounds you want to take. The deck building aspect is beautifully designed aswell, although the magic cards are rarely at play.

All in all, MK is a very good game but it needs an update to introduce different missions etc. In comparison I would whole-heartedly recommend Mechs vs Minions for solo play. Tons to play with a cheaper price tag and it works with larger player counts aswell. It's a whole different genre but it's just as puzzly.

RATING: 8.25
Very good fantasy adventure game. Rules are surely complex and game has myriad of components, but making epic feeling adventure game elegant is probably impossible.

The gameplay is not shallow dice-throwing, but action optimization by deciding with cards use now and which save for later (as basic card powers are cumulative). The pressure of opponent using cards faster than you add the necessary incentive to make hard decisions on how to use your cards. My only negative(ish) argument is: the pressure could even be a fraction higher. (Getting full extra turn after opponent passes, feels quite generous: really hard to rush and punish opponent much).

Playing time requirement is truly grand, easily several (4+) hours, especially with people who like to think and try to play well (like me). But if you find opponent who prefers playing pace similar to you, playing this is great experience.

RATING: 9
Mage Knight: The Board Game is primarily an adventure game. You get a hero and wander the countryside killing monsters and getting treasure. It's a fun theme, if not particularly original. What really sets is apart though is its use of deckbuilding mechanics to customize your character as the game goes on. Upgrading and learning new skills are ubiquitous in this type of pseudo-RPG, so it's a perfect fit.

Each player receives a pre-painted figure and their own deck of cards. The figures do seem to play rather differently from each other, but none seems to have weaknesses to the point that they cannot succeed at certain tasks. This is a good thing. Each card in a player's deck has a couple different uses and the game really forces you into some tough decisions about how to spend your cards and resources. Even when you get to add new cards to your deck, you will have some tough choices to make about which one best fits your deck and your overall strategy.

The components here are of notably excellent quality. I suppose the price reflects this, but it really shines. The tiles are of thick stock, the pre-painted figures are easily identifiable and look right at home in the world. Even small tokens are nicely illustrated. The lone drawback may be that the colors of the plastic crystals can be tough to distinguish from one another.

This is a really solid effort that ends up being a lot of fun to play. The very minor complaints I can muster are that it tends to bog down the more players there are, and that I wish there were more opportunities to add cards to your deck. You add cards to your deck about as often as you would expect to find a treasure or learn a skill in an adventure game. Since you use your deck for everything from moving to fighting, you will sometimes cycle it without even adding a new card. Again, these are very minor complaints it what is ultimately a really fun game.

RATING: 4
DECK BUILDING???

Horrible rules.  The game is not half as complicated as it seems by reading the rules.  And where the game is "complex", it feels like it is complexity for the sake of complexity. Also, the game is the same puzzle repeated.  It is *not* a deck building game in the least: you don't have the leisure to alter the odds of having one card or the other, and your deck is not cycled that many times, which leads to another problem: randomness.  Unlike most people think, the more you throw the dice/draw cards, and the less random things feel because odds even out.  This game is a thinky luckfest, not a great combination imo.  
As a solitary game, it is a decent adventure game because you don't suffer the downtime; if you want a solo, fantasy game this might be a fit.

RATING: N/A
Mage Knight is... well, it certainly proves to be another typical Chvatil game (if there is such a beast), with (a) lots of different pieces needed to track exactly what is going on, (b) required playtime greater than usually expected, (c) very nice graphic elements, (d) plenty of theme, (e) well-written rules which, (f) are always still extremely complicated to read/learn/use.

FWIW, I'd have to say that the bits in Mage Knight are among the best I've seen in any non-collector edition games.

Nevertheless the whole thing seems a little piecy on a first play- which I guess is also typical of Vlaada's games.

I own/have owned Prophecy, Through the Ages, Dungeon Lords and now Mage Knight; I have to say that not one of these has played simply yet deeply enough to catch on here with my family, and that this is the single biggest problem I have had with Chvatil games.

Still there's a lot of promise in this one, that beyond the artwork there's a lot of solid game, if you can find the time for it.

I am reserving a rating until after further plays- like other Chvatil games this one needs a bit of effort to really know and appreciate, and unlike Dungeon Lords I am hopeful that this one will eventually get familiar enough to catch hold.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ask about the best solo board game and Mage Knight will be the top answer. 

It is really good. It is really long. Even set up takes a lot of time and you need quite a lot of space. The game itself is complex. But once you get your head around the rules, it becomes more intuitive. And the complexity allowes for depth of play. 

The mechanics remind me quite a lot of D&D Dungeon Command. You use cards to do almost anything, e.g. move, attack, etc. This isn't altogether a bad thing as I really like Dungeon Command. It's also funny how there's no combat dial (except on castles) which is what made the original Mage Knight unique.

Thematically, it's a lot like Runebound, which (although not specified as such) is also easy to play solo. I like the uniquness of the token combat system in Runebound, but Mage Knight has a modular board that can change and I like Mage Knight's mana generation system. Both games are currently 9s for me. 

While Mage Knight's 99% great, there are a few minor downsides. So far it doesn't feel like I'm playing a board game so much as a card game; I spend most of my time looking at and using my cards, not so much time looking at the game board or interacting with my figure. Speaking of the figures, they are very poorly painted. It would have been better if they came unpainted. I'm going to repaint them.  

Overall, a great game, but I only just got it. I'd like to see its longevity.

RATING: 3
This is actually a computer game masquerading as a board game. It is bursting with character special skills, elemental enemies, alternate card abilities, random encounters, mana types, terrain, locations, followers etc. 

But take away a clean video-game interface then re-imagine all this laid out on the table. Evaluating moves involve juggling between skimming stacks of iconography and performing draining maths. Basic things such as how far you can walk or checking what dangers will kill you, take too much mental arithmetic. Repeat this turn after turn for the fiddly and slow-moving experience that is Mage Knight.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
After my first game of Mage Knight, I thought it might be interesting.  I wish it hadn't taken 3 hours (It suffers from painfully lengthy downtime waiting for other people to take their turns), and the frequent interruptions of my plans to discover yet another rules exception were annoying, but I thought both of those issues would diminish with repeat plays.

Game 2 was...worrying.  Game 3 cemented my opinion that it is in fact a terrible game.

If you don't draw your movement cards at the right time, you will be miserable.  Yes, at first the idea that you can spend any card to do anything at reduced effect seems like it would help, but in practice it just means that you end up spending your powerful combat cards moving to the combat, and then can't actually win the battle when you get there.  

If you fall behind, you are doomed.  This means that if someone else beats you to the easy fights (see issue with movement cards), you are doomed.  You will never catch up.  Worse, you will fall ever further behind, as the person who won the early fights will be powerful enough to beat the next difficulty of fight and grow more powerful, while you will languish in obscurity.  

Combat is too complicated and not actually exciting or fun.  There are so many exceptions and special rules that new players are guaranteed to think "okay, I finally have all the math worked out so that I can win this battle and not be wounded" and then find out that they can't even win the battle, let alone walk away unscathed.

I don't understand why this game is rated so highly by so many people...well, I understand some of the ratings - they are from people who admit that they have only played it solo so far, which means they haven't experienced the crushing misery of having someone else beat them to the thing they want to do and then not being able to do anything.  But the people who have played it multiplayer and still think it's great...I just don't get it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is, in my opinion, an absolutely perfect board game. 
The mechanics are rock solid. The rulebook, although dense, is put together in such a way as to make any rules questions easy to answer. The complexity of the game is handled in an easy-to-absorb fashion via the Introductory Scenario, and the continuing complexity of the game either makes an intuitive, logical sense, or is found where you would expect it to be in the rulebook.
This game makes sense after you play it the first time, and additional playthroughs reveal the depth of strategy and mechanics that this game has. I have never played this game the same way twice (due to how the cards are dealt, and the map tiles revealed), and yet, I have never felt that my chance at winning was destroyed due to not being able to do "the only winning strategy".
This games rewards tactical thinking without encouraging Analysis Paralysis, and always gives players an option of what to do, as long as they are willing to see what the best option is.
It is fun with any number of supported players, and fosters creativity in either a competitive or cooperative fashion, depending on how you are playing.
This game creates a real sense of adventure, and makes you feel like you have truly earned your victory with a sense of growth and challenge, without the looming specter of unfair failure that some "challenging" games have.

This is a heavy game to get into, but the combination of competitive, cooperative, and solo play; theme, mechanics, and endless re-playability make this game an absolute must have.

RATING: 6
My score is a little misleading, because I REALLY do enjoy Mage Knight. However, there is good reason for a lower score here:

This is a gamers game. It is hardcore, and unless playing a hardcore deckbuilding/RPG game gets you excited as hell immediately, it probably isn't for you. As my wife is my main game partner, I don't get to play this a lot. Being so niche hurts the ability to get it out with a group that will actually enjoy it. 

Other than that, learning the rules is a BEAR. Vlaada has some crazy big rule books but this takes the friggin' cake. You'll spend hours with the rules and still not have them down. The game is also fiddly, though not to the same degree as something like Arkham Horror.

All that said, if you get the right group down and you all know the rules, this game gets DEEP. Some seriously satisfying strategy can take place, and the fantasy RPG leveling element is fantastic for giving you a sense of progression and pace.

Overall, this is a great game but it is limited by having a small audience that would agree, and being such a pain to get into and learn.

RATING: 8
Somehow, this has become our go-to two player game. :)  Yes, it's long, fiddly, mathy, convoluted, and swingy, and that doesn't bother me at all.  The card combos are great; even if you only get to execute a particular combo once or twice, the game goes out of its way to make sure you will get to use it and it will be awesome.  And in fact, that's kind of what the game is about--balancing set-up turns with turns of awesome, the turns where you march into a city and find out you have to kill the medusa and a dragon, and voila! you have the magic card that somehow lets you pull it off.  There's a lot of information that's available in advance for planning and figuring out the cleverest way to use the special cards. And because it's a Chvatil game, you get a little credit for everything you do.  

I probably wouldn't want to play this much with more than two, because it has really long turns and the downtime would be massive. But as a two player game, I'm kind of addicted to it... (4 or 5 plays?)

TLDR: Only game I've ever played that took over two hours, that I wanted to immediately play again.

RATING: 8
WOW!  Everything you want in a fantasy-themed game.  Excellent core rules, lots of advanced rules and options, several scenario types (solo play, co-op play, competitive play) and terrific card-driven mechanics.  Can't wait to play this again.  The only downside is I suffer from analysis paralysis with this game more than any other.  Every hand of cards you draw is a puzzle to solve, and sometimes it takes a while to go through various permutations to figure out how to play your hand for optimal efficiency... to get one more point of blocking or one more ranged attack... or to decide if it's worth taking a wound in order to clear those ruins this turn, or play it safe and finish it off next turn...

Played at WifeGonCon 2012.
Purchased from German Games, June 2012.

RATING: 8
OWNED SINCE 2012
This is a great game. It is a fantasy game, where you tile explore and fight baddies, but the mechanics do not feel like the standard tile exploration/ kill baddies game. For me, one of the best part of playing a RPG Video Game is leveling up, and when I play Mage Knight I feel that excitement; like my next level is just within reach and I want to get it. My wife and 2 older kids, ages 9 1/2 and 11, also enjoy this game. My kids seem to understand the rules well enough, although they still need guidance from the parents, and the specific rewards/interaction at locations/and other less used rules require a player aid. I want to point out that this game does not feel like other dungeon crawlers. It does not capture the feeling of running for your life, constantly being assaulted from enemies and just trying to survive, like Castle Ravenloft or Drizzt (which are great by the way), but that is OK. I have several board games that fill different roles and I play the game that matches my gaming group's mood; MK is a great game that has a unique place in my game collection. I am glad I got this game, but after several plays, it does lack some of the excitement that it first had because there are no surprises when I fight or explore because there are few unusual surprises.

RATING: 8.5
This game is amazing, I think that it has all that I look for in a high strategic board game. For me, the best thing, is the combination of one of my favorite mechanics (deck building) with a board game. It is kind of minor deck building as you are not going to buy/win that many cards during the whole game, but it is enough for having the feeling that you are building your future for the next rounds.
The artwork is amazing (no, the miniatures are not), there are so many interesting mechanics that I cannot highlight all of them (in part because the last time I played was some time ago). One thing that can be conflictive is how long the game is. It is one of those games where the duration of the game is increased for every player. But it is so strategic, so complicate and there are so many things that can be done for wining the game, that I have to say that I love the game
Positive:
1. Highly strategic
2. Many amazing mechanics
3. Deck building within a classic board game
4. It is very thematic
5. The artwork
Negative:
1. It may be too long
2. Difficult to explain and to play
3. Not recommended for inexperienced players
4. The miniatures

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Sounds pretty good but maybe too long and too complex for the return

Edit - Well I had read all the complaints ahead so was expecting some bumps or even holes in the road but overall enjoyed it, a little torn though as I figured.  Most of everything you want in a D&D type adventure game is here, but some things are done very very differently than any others of this type.  

- First off the deckbuilding.  Normally, plain old deck building and only that just bores me to tears, so don’t like it much at all.  Here though, I think it is a really good fit for the rest of the game and of course is only a small part of the game, it’s a great way of levelling up, picking a nice spell or advanced action which you’ll be able to use in future turns when they come to you.  So overall I like this aspect.  

- Levelling – I think this is the best aspect of the game, and probably what hooks most people on the game. These are some of your most important decisions, and you usually have a few options to choose from, also just getting rewards from battles was nice also improving your abilities in one way or another.  

- Movement and actions – Here we start down the slippery slope.  It can be quite frustrating getting a hand of cards you just can’t use, I don’t care if you have played the game 20 times, you are still going to get a hand of cards that don’t work for what you need or want to do.  So, I think you just have to accept this, and accept that your opponents will suffer the same fate, and when it happens just have a non-turn and move on.  If you can’t accept it, well MK is likely not going to be for you.  

- Monsters and attacks – Well at first I wasn't sure about the way combat was done, seemed a little too Euro for this type of game, but otoh the encounters that are known ahead see reduced luck.  Going into a Dungeon or encounter you don’t know, felt more like an adventure type game, but for the Brown Monsters if you randomly got the Werewolf you’d be screwed. I don’t think I liked the all of nothing defence rules, where if you could not defend it ALL, then you might as well defend nothing because you get attacked at full regardless, this felt wrong to me for this type of game, it’s a design choice and one I don’t think I liked. Its not a biggy though, and you could probably house-rule it in some way if you wanted it more traditional.  

- Mercs – This was another cool aspect, hiring mercenaries to help you in battles. 

- Analysis Paralysis – Probably one of the worst features of the game. The trouble is with the cards, and some of the rule restrictions, so you have this hand of 5 to 7 cards, and there is something you want to do, and sometimes you need to go through all the permutations to see IF you can do it, and how well, like often there is 3 to 10 ways to try and accomplish something with the cards you have, so great you have some options, but the way they are presented to you just creates a bad type of analysis. While after 5, 10 or more games this will improve, its never going to totally disappear either.  

- Strategy/Downtime – If you do play with more than 2, downtime is going to suck regardless, unless you have some really fast players who don’t care about optimizing their turn. With only 2, the mana dice availability is more deterministic and you should be able to mostly plan your next turn waiting for the other player, even with more, when the person ahead of you is going you know most of the dice available and can still mostly plan your turn, so while downtime IS bad you can still mostly plan for your turn, though with more its harder and cards will change more, the map changes more etc. As far as Strategy in general, planning more than one turn ahead is pretty tough, and it sure looks like game long plans are not possible to me, not that “that” is needed or anything especially for this genre, it would be nice sure so just an observation that the way things build up and change here long term planning isn't possible mostly or at all.  

- Player number – due to the AP, the shear amount of rules and the game length, NO way would I be playing with more than 2 people, its probably best a solo game in many ways, but two works good too.  

- Rules – It does seem like there is just too much, and you have to wonder if many things could have been streamlined a little more, boiled down to lesson this burden of learning and look-up etc.  

- Luck – I felt it was okay overall, maybe it’s a little high for the length of the game, but again playing with 2 players I think gives you a shorter game and reduced luck effect so its really the way to go for this.  

- Theme – Between the Deck building, the turn order card draft and a few other things it does take a little away I think from the theme, however I think in the end its still an adventure game and mostly still feels like one.  

My conclusion after one play is I am a little torn on this as you can likely see above, and I'm not sure if I am going to buy it.  On the one hand, it might be the one adventure game with the most meaningful decisions out there (Robinson is another). On the other, I worry that the rules overhead may keep the game on my shelf instead of on the table, and if you ever don’t play it for a few months and want to come back to it, HAH, good luck.

RATING: 8.5
Excellent as a solo game, lots of variability in what spells/actions/monsters/map tiles come out.

It's a bit of a slog to play with playtime easily being over 2hrs, but still fun nonetheless. A lot of the time is spent thinking about how best to play each hand, or deciding which direction to go, which monsters you think you are capable of fighting given the current strength of your deck/units etc; there are a lot of interesting decisions to make!

The best thing is that you defeat enemies through intelligent play as apposed to dice rolling. There is randomness in the game, but where it matters, you have plenty of information in order to plan for it.

This is my favourite solo game by a long shot, others I have enjoyed playing solo such as imperial settlers, caverna etc were fun for a few games, but you get to the point where you've figured the puzzle out, and any more plays need to be multiplayer in order to keep things interesting. This game has the variablity to last a lot longer, and does not need multiplayer interaction at all.

RATING: 9
Mage Knight is a game that I find myself regularly wanting to play.  It has a nice combination of being a fun brain burner, trying to figure just the right combination of cards and crystals to make a spectacular play, and gathering strength and power, while exploring a board.  There is some significant downtime while an opponent is taking their turn so the optimal number of players depends on how long it takes for each of you to plan out your next move.  You want more players if it takes longer and less if you're more experienced and quicker.  There seems to be very little direct player interaction since there is little incentive to fight so mostly it comes down to getting in each other's way.  Oftentimes it becomes almost cooperative as we all kibitz on the best move, especially late at night when our brains are getting sluggish and we need the help.  My main criticism is that it has a bit of a runaway leader syndrome since power begets power and there is little to restrain a frontrunner.  The characters are largely comparable but with enough asymmetry to make for interesting variety.  I expect with enough play it'll start getting repetitive but there's lots of replay value here due to its variety of cards and challenging nature to devise the optimal move.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
While the fantasy table-top theme works fine, this is actually a brain-burning hand management puzzle.

In a full game you're only going to see your deck (which starts at 16 cards) 6 times. You'll add a few cards to it, deck builder style, but you're only going to see them a few times. Everything you do needs to be efficient, and you have to snowball quickly to make maximum use of earned cards, skills, and units (face-up helpers that you can recruit). To be sure, your deck can become super strong compared to what you started with, but that's mainly a thing that you're building up to for use on the last couple rounds.

I enjoy it quite a bit. I would not want to play it with anyone who suffers from AP. There are way too many decisions on a given turn about how to play out your hand, and people can become entirely lost and frozen if they aren't willing to take a risk.

The components are great. Cards are standard poker sized, so regular Magic sleeves work. You can use opaque sleeves for most of the cards, but the reference cards will need clear sleeves. I used clear on the units as well, so that I could tell the two decks apart.

Note: The rules are a disaster as a reference. It's one of those "let's gather 'round and hear a story about how this game is played" rule books. My recommendation for learning is:

1. Read the getting started book.
2. Slog through the intro game.
3. Read and memorize absolutely everything.

Don't subject a gaming group to this if you don't have the rules down cold. It's long enough as it is. You will not be able to "look that one thing up real quick" because whatever you're looking for is guaranteed to be hidden in the last place you'd ever think about looking.

RATING: 5
It packs some clever gameplay, but I am rather sick of the tendency of modern boardgame to replace character attributes and equipement by decks of cards. This feels like a game by Corey Koniezka, and I do not mean this as a compliment, because, while I like his games, they all seem the share the same kind of flaws which I'm really sick of.

It also feels soulless and not very thematic. The game is also not appealing visually at all, especially for the kind of game is it (adventure/RPG).

But mostly, mostly, this game has one of the worse combos of low-player interaction and very long downtime that I have ever witnessed, even worse than Merchants and Marauders!

But, I can see interesting things peeking through, and it is quite possible I may raise my score if I get the chance to play more and better master the game.

In conclusion: Vlaada Chvatil is probably the closest analogue the boardgaming world has to a mad genius. Emphasis on the "mad".

RATING: 6
2012-02-17

Initial Rating: 8.0 (January 2012)

For me Vlaada is the game best game designer out there. He always deliver innovative ideas with great gameplay and lots of theme and this game is no exception. Mage Knight is a gem and one game I believe will continue to raise in my ratings.

The game is dripping with theme, and there is so much to do you will never get bored with the game, with so many options it could trigger analysis paralysis in some people, but I love the sheer amount of things to do :D.

I didn’t knew (until I played the game) that the core mechanic was Deck Building, however you don’t need to shuffle constantly which is my only complaint with Dominion. Unlike most deck building games, your initial cards are quite useful, the components are quite good except for the cards, you need to sleeve them ASAP or they will suffer pretty quick.

The game is a little heavy, with the rules and with the game length, it can easily consume 4 hours of your life and the rules could have been shorter and to the point. Perhaps my only concern is that it seems the player who gets the best couple of turns at the beginning  can be difficult, if not impossible, to stop. This could mean that the winner of the game can be decided within the first 20 minutes of the game but you still need to play hours after that to finish a game.

You need to try it before you buy it, but for me it is a must have. By far the best adventure/RPG game out there.

Current Rating: 9.0

RATING: 7
3/4/16 - Bought off CL $40 Cards sleeved and pieces in a plano case. Included Lost legion and Krang expansion
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Mage Knight is good, possibly very good. Not sure if it's great yet but definitely good - the decks are small, starting at 16 cards each, and cards are added to the decks rather slowly so a deck might end up anywhere between 16-22 cards. I'm really impressed with how well the deckbuilding component works - Mage Knight in no way feels like "another deckbuilding game." There are enough different monsters, units, and spells to provide for a lot of interplay variety and some very fun and challenging decision space. It's not unlike Through the Ages in that the currencies in the game are all relatively straightforward and simple but interact in complex ways.

My concern so far is that it can be hard to do much planning on other players' turns. The board will have changed quite a bit and, significantly, the available mana will have changed. There is a common mana source available and each time players use a mana die they will reroll it at the end of their turn. So even though you see your hand for the entire turn it's impossible to know what mana will be available so forward planning is difficult.

I expect this issue to melt away with an experienced group who can streamline the planning process. So for now I'm giving Mage Knight the benefit of the doubt and rating it 8. I can see it ending up anywhere between 6 and 10 which is a pretty wide range for me after a first couple plays - but the most likely ratings are 8 and 9.

Edit after 5 plays:  much less AP with experienced players.  We actually finished a 3-player 4 round scenario in less than 2 hours.  I'm much happier knowing that 2-3 hours is a reasonable time frame for this title. 

Edit after 9 plays:  I'm settling on 9 as a tentative final rating for this title.  Most of my concerns have been alleviated and I'm finding that the majority of my plays are great mathy hack-and-slash fun.

My remaining concerns are:  first, that the game just isn't very fun in the one in five cases when either the odds or incompetence lead to my getting severely hosed.  I am finding that this happens less and less with experience, but there's still a small chance that any one play will be underwhelming.  Second, I'm finding I just don't care about the scoring.  [user=enzo622] has termed all the scoring categories a "point salad," the point being that they don't necessarily integrate well thematically.  I feel this shows up most in the majority bonuses - I simply don't care if I've conquered more towers than the other players, or learned more skills.  I care if I make conquests, because I get cool rewards, but the three points? Whatever.  I worry that if I get involved in a game with very competitive types, the points will overwhelm the adventure, and that would siphon away the fun.

These are quibbles though.  Mage Knight is an outstanding experience, and a pretty good game.

Edit after 15 multiplayer plays and 8 solo plays:  This is a 10 for me.  All of my concerns have been alleviated by repeated play.  I'm addicted to this game.

RATING: 8
One play only, very enjoyable. Mix of deck building (sort of - you won't acquire new cards at the same rate as Dominion or even A Few Acres of Snow) and arithmetic puzzling in a fantasy, Tolkein-esque setting.

Played competitively, it's essentially a point-grab race - enemies may seem formidable but they're essentially a route to points and powerups, the challenge being how to gather the necessary cards and other resources to beat them as quickly as possible.

In some ways it may be best as a solo or 2 player game as there isn't a great deal of scope for player interaction and (due to the puzzley nature of the gameplay) turns can take a while.

This may make it seem less fun than I meant: I enjoyed it a lot as much as a series of mental challenges as a game. The theme's similar, but a dice-driven luck-fest from the Talisman mould it is not.

Now we have Mage Knight.  It's not quite the same as the mechanics in Dungeon Lords, but it's similar.  My impression after playing solo once is that this will most likely be one of my favorite games. There really is a lot to think about and many meaningful decisions on each turn.

RATING: 10
Rules - there are lots of them. I highly recommend anyone who is willing to try out this game to watch Ricky's Mage Knight Board Game runs. He explains set-ups, and your very first mission as well as conquest missions which is done so exceptionally well. But even then, there are a lot of small minor rules here and there that you might overlook but I don't believe it would be game breaking.

Even through my first mission, this game was amazing. Yes, I watched the tutorial videos to help me out, but that didn't take away any of the fun from me. With repeated plays and after I get the hang of the game to the point that where I don't have to consult the rule book for minor details (oh what does this icon mean? What can I do in Village again?), I can see this one shoot up in my score near 9. 

The puzzle aspect and deck building were brilliant. Trying to figure out how to approach each movement and fight is so well done. I can see that this might not appeal to many people for being so puzzle-like, but the fact that you can play your cards side-ways to gain any action increases the freedom so if you are one of those who hate puzzles, still give it a try. You will be surprised to find what is in this game.

Only downside to this game is the set up time. There are simply way too many components to play this game. Other than that, really nothing much to nit pick on. I got a nice Plano storage and set up time has been reduced dramatically. I just need to find a way to store my cards now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I can see this moving up or down depending on repeated plays.  As I currently think this is an 'experience' game, I think the co-op may go up to 9.  The PVP variant seems a bit random and may not be liked.  If the co-op plays as well as I hope it does, then it's a definite keeper.  The solo game is a great, great puzzle that I enjoy quite a bit!

RATING: 10
Mage Knight is a most unlikely game. The magnitude of its ambition is staggering. The complexity of its rules is frightening. On the surface, its shamelessly maximalist collection of ideas and mechanics looks like it could have been designed by an overeager young wannabe who wanted to start off their career by creating their hypothetical kitchen sink dream game, plausibility be damned. It shouldn't work.

But it's a Vlaada game. It DOES work. It works amazingly well.

It's a hard game to get started with. Every session seems to present a fresh new set of edge cases and interpretations, and will inevitably have the players combing the rules, the FAQ and the BGG forums multiple times. But it's worth it. Slowly getting better at it, session by session, is rewarding like no other game I've played. If my first games began with crawling, a few games in I had built the confidence to take a few cautious steps, then walk, and now, after a couple of dozen sessions, I'm jogging and occasionally sprinting.

Rated 9 initially, upgraded to 10 during a summer spent obsessed with the game.

RATING: 10
This is a rules heavy game! There are tons of icons and special rules for different locations, battling different enemies, coop vs. competitive vs. PvP, scenarios, etc... It can be intimidating. At its core it is a pretty simple game of hand management, action efficiency, and risk management. It presents you with puzzles each turn much like Dungeon Lords and Dungeon Petz do. How to optimize spending your current hand can be a punishing exercise and if you don't like the sound of that you will certainly hate this game.

The theme is extremely strong, and the slow deckbuilding and levelling up is implemented beautifully. You really feel like you're becoming more powerful over the course of the game. There are tons of units, advanced actions, artefacts, and spells so repeated plays will result in substantially different character builds. If you do eventually explore all of the cards in the base game the first expansion adds lots more to the mix.

I play this exclusively as a coop game, the first expansion helps add more variety to that experience. I also play with a rules expert which makes my life a lot easier. I'm not sure if I would have wanted to invest the time and energy to grok the rule-set on my own.

I really enjoy the game, it has an epic feel and presents you with truly agonizing decisions. However, there is quite a bit of luck in the game which can sometimes detract from the fun. Certain terrain configurations can be crippling, drawing the wrong hand of cards can result in horribly inefficient turns, rolling the wrong results on the magic source dice or drawing the wrong enemy (not all enemies are drawn randomly, but some are) can be devastating. Some of this is risk management and some is just bad luck.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
As much as I love playing games with others, playing MK solo is about as sweet a board gaming experience that exists on this plane of reality. The ultimate puzzle adventure, MK will challenge you from start to finish playing somewhere in the 3-4 hour neighborhood for me for solo conquest and 2-3 hours playing either Volkare scenario. For the solo gamer, Lost Legion is basically a must buy.

I've always been a big fan of the RPG. There's just something about taking a character and leveling them up, gaining new abilities, and tackling harder and harder enemies that has always appealed to me. This game has that in spades and with a plethora of options for you to do so. It's a game that when you first play it will seem nigh impossible to complete. After repeated play though you will begin to really see the possibilities of what you can achieve in 3 days and 3 nights and that reward keeps me coming back again and again.

RATING: 6.5
[First Impressions]
I would probably liken this to an RPG version of Dungeon Lords. I don't think its any more complex, but there are a lot of moving parts (small fiddly rules) that make the game seem more complicated than it is. If you've ever played DL, imagine that you're playing the Hero phase (where they try to sanctify your dungeon) over and over again. Thats what each turn of this game is. You need to puzzle out what the best way of using your cards are each turn.

The rulebooks (both) are horribly written, seemingly designed to obfuscate the rules. The longwinded explanations attempt to describing the game instead of just listing the points. I have never had a rulebook show a picture of a card with an arrow saying "You should already know what this number means". WTF!?
