RATING: 7.5
The design on this game is more complex and more immersive than any other game I've played.  I'm a big fan of complex games so this is one of my favorites.  Here is a small list of what I enjoy about it: beautiful compenents including nicely pre-painted miniatures, modular board, interesting combat mechanics, remarkable flexibility of how to play any given hand, diversity of board game elements (terrain, buildings, monsters).  I am not a solo gamer but this is the one game I will continue to play solo.  I find it too difficult to win with the dummy player as specified in the rules but the beauty of the game is you can change the difficulty in a number of ways.  I prefer to add one additional round after the dummy is out of cards.  A mild criticism of the game is that cooperative play does feel like solitaire.  In a two player game you have to split up in order to cover enough space and therefore there is little possibility of cooperating on battles.  I have yet to play with more than 2 or in a competitive game and am looking forward to that.  Vlaada Chvatil, you are brilliant.  

Update: dropped from 9 to 7.5 after 4th play.  Rating is lowered because of complexity and gameplay time.   I often look at the game and don't want to suggest it for play because I'm tired of having to look up and/or explain rules and gameplay can absolutely drag with players trying to decide how to play their cards.

RATING: 4
This is probably very cleverly designed and a fine representative of its kind, but the introductory scenario felt like a lot of granular build-up to an arbitrary cut-off point. Some of the time your draws will simply be bad, as you sit with cards that do combat or recruitment or temporary resource acquisition, but no way to go where they'd be useful: it's not "what's my best course of action given this selection" as much as "what do I sacrifice in an attempt to scramble out of this hole while the others zip by". Add lack of player interaction and this could be a problem. Thankfully, this is not a deckbuilding game. I assume there are scenarios where objectives are more structured and high-end acquisitions have more of an impact on the game - but then what kind of playing time are you looking at?

Playing the standard game mostly confirmed my impressions. It's a design swarming with options and currencies, but it's also a flavourless five-hour snowball heading towards something I don't particularly come to care about.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
So close to being an awesome game, yet is let down by bloated mechanics and fiddliness that absolutely kills any immersion. It feels like the designer crammed in as many rules (usu. governed by oversized cards) for every little nuance he could, even for simple things like player turn order.

Pros
- The Map tiles are gorgeous, (and are just begging me to redesign my own game around them)
- The different locations, random tokens guarding those locations, and choices available to a player each turn at those locations is well implemented and perfectly suited to a fantasy adventure game.
- Some of the other mechanics are also highly innovative (e.g. drawing mana from 'the source' and having different creative options for how to store or wield it)

Cons
- You will need a massive play area for even a solo game.
- Although I believe deck-building could work in a fantasy RPG, I feel it has been poorly executed in this game, with Actions, Spells, and Artifacts all having similar functions, making extraneous elements, like Units and Skills, feel tacked on.
- There are cards all over the place! These are bigger than they need to be, and unless you are impeccably well-organised and have plenty of table space, you will soon find stray cards merging with the wrong piles, (especially since your deck is mix-and-matched with all kinds)
- I suspect the down-time would drive players crazy in anything above a 2-player game, while in a one-player game you're essentially racing against the clock.
- Although there are many decks, there aren't many cards in each (usu. around 20). And since many function very similarly, you will quickly cycle through everything the game has to offer in a couple plays.

However, despite this mainly negative review, I do believe creative players could do a lot with the game components (minus the unwieldy cards). Bring in a few 'character sheets' and various ability scores, item 'tokens', etc, and you just might be able to create that board game RPG you've been waiting for someone else to design for you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The core system has some real fun in it - but the game system is horrible to learn, with a bunch of monster effects that aren't easy to remember (wait, I need fire block to block ice effectively, but monsters need ice to block ice, and then my troops can get either ice block or ice resistance, both of which do different things - and that's without mentioning the totally unmemorable icons for other monster abilities), similar but different places on the board without an apparent reason to include them all, attack can be pooled but block can't, you can hire units anywhere except for some reason not in cities, etc etc. Basically, everything has an exception and everything is fiddly, but most of the fiddly rules add nothing to the game.

Add on that combat is completely deterministic, that the mana effects (which I like the concept of) mean there are a myriad of ways to play any particular hand, and that in typical Vlaada style you are punished out of all proportion for minor mistakes (miscalculated your block by one? take full damage), and you have a recipe for extremely long turns as players have to work out how to precisely optimise their hand for the desired result. As there's nothing to do when it isn't your turn, downtime can sometimes be extreme.

There's also a great deal of randomness in the map tiles you explore (both in terms of ease of travel and the locations present), the monsters you encounter, the spells/skills/units available when it's your chance to take one and so forth, and the order your cards come up (with only 3-5 shuffles in most scenarios) - and I can't really convince myself that player skill has a great deal to do with the outcome. With the same character, a similar scenario, and similar tactics, on one occasion I came first, and on the other dead last. As far as I can tell, it's because the first time round I got an outrageously powerful spell that would just destroy dragons outright, while in the second game someone else did and I got a lacklustre healing spell.

But for all the grumbling above, the core game system is good, and I there is a lot of fun to be had with Mage Knights. It's just necessarily mixed in with sometimes unreasonable frustration at the game system, takes far too long to play and I'm not sure I'm willing to put up with that in a game which just takes me along for the ride, rather than letting me play it.

RATING: 9
Includes the Expansions:
Mage Knight Board Game: The Lost Legion (English first edition) (2012)

Fiddly, fiddly rules in an excellent adventure game. Be sure you check your components when you un-box your game, because my game had some missing pieces. You get a one time free replacement parts order from Wiz-Kids, which was hardly any hassle at all. There are so many things I like about MK: variable player powers, modular board, solitaire play, strong theme integration, and amazing components. The game rules are not that complex, but they are fiddly (there is a lot of stuff here, and everything has its own way of being dealt with) and sometimes difficult to find. I have to dock it full point for its fiddliness, simply because it makes it extremely difficult to get to the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Before I bought this game I thought this will be an adventurous + deck building game. But after a few plays, it kind of fell off for me as my moves on the tile were very limited by the cards that I have, and I hardly can get some advanced, spell , advance units and treasure cards and use them under the maximum of 6 rounds (3 days and 3 nights). 

After reading some reviews and comments in the forum, I finally realize that this game is basically a puzzle game. It is highly depend on how you choose your actions and maximize the effect and usage of the cards in your hand. You probably need to spend 5-10 minutes to decide how you gonna play the 5 cards in your hand, which I don't like it at all. 


People that like puzzle solving might love this game. But I would prefer an adventurous game that is not tightly restricted by the the way to play the cards on my hand, and this game is no where near any deck building game like dominion, ascension, etc. Also, it take a long time to learn and setup this game. 
 
Maybe I need to play it more in order to grab the essence or fun of this game, but after less than 10 solo play, I don't even feel like touching it at all. As a result, I've sold the game and I'm glad I did it. I think this game is overrated.

RATING: 10
A brilliant puzzle-style game that makes you consider your entire deck (cards you've played already, have in hand, and are yet to come) every single turn while figuring out how to optimize every hand.  The game is very, very hard to win and the changing map every game along with 4 different heroes (1 more in the expansion) and a large quantity of enemies, advanced action cards (better abilities of similar cards in your deck), and spells means no two games will be alike.  Fun solo or up to 3 players (4 in the expansion).  If you want a very serious gaming challenge after playing lighter games, this is a great choice.  If you love very difficult games that require extremely deep thinking and strategizing, this is the holy grail.

RATING: N/A
The Mage Knight board game puts you in control of one of four powerful Mage Knights as you explore (and conquer) a corner of the Mage Knight universe under the control of the Atlantean Empire. Build your army, fill your deck with powerful spells and actions, explore caves and dungeons, and eventually conquer powerful cities controlled by this once-great faction! In competitive scenarios, opposing players may be powerful allies, but only one will be able to claim the land as their own. In coöperative scenarios, the players win or lose as a group. Solo rules are also included.Combining elements of RPGs, deckbuilding, and traditional board games the Mage Knight board game captures the rich history of the Mage Knight universe in a self-contained gaming experience.

RATING: 7
[BGCOLOR=#339900][COLOR=#FFFFFF]▲[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR] Great components: pre-painted miniatures, great artworks (with very few exceptions), engraved custom dice, high amount of cards and cardboard/plastic tokens, helpful summary cards.

[BGCOLOR=#339900][COLOR=#FFFFFF]▲[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR] Great replay value: randomised modular board, 4 different characters which all play quite differently because of their unique skills, many different scenarios, playable as a solitaire, cooperative and competitive game, optional rules.

[BGCOLOR=#339900][COLOR=#FFFFFF]▲[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR] Great solitaire game experience: the dummy player is very streamlined and easy to handle and serves as a challenging ticking clock. While the exact total amount of rounds is unknown, the end of a single round can still be foreseen.

[BGCOLOR=#339900][COLOR=#FFFFFF]▲[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR] Custom-made inlay: while I have heard that some people hate the inlay, I think it's great for sorting all the different components in a compact way.

[BGCOLOR=#FF0000][COLOR=#FFFFFF]▼[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR] In my opinion unplayable with more than 2 players: the playtime is already relatively long with 1-2 players, but the real problem with 3-4 players is the painfully long downtimes.

[BGCOLOR=#FF0000][COLOR=#FFFFFF]▼[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR] The rulebooks are well-structured and they do indeed work in teaching the rules: the wording is clear and precise to leave no room for interpretation. The problem is the presentation, as both rulebooks are written in small font size and the full rulebook presents the reader just pages with walls of text. Sadly, an index is also missing.

[BGCOLOR=#FF0000][COLOR=#FFFFFF]▼[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR] The game demands a true time commitment from the player(s): 1. learning the rules, 2. setting up the game, 3. playing the game and 4. mastering the game, as you will be very slow and bad at this game in the beginning.


[b]Mage Knight[/b] is quite different in many ways, and it took me quite some time (5 full games) to actually figure out if I like this game or not, which is quite unusual.

The ambition, different options on each turn, strategic depth, component quality and theme of this game are great and I should actually love this game for these aspects, because it features a lot of elements that I like in board games.

The replay value is also very high: the possibility to play this game in three different ways (solo, cooperative, competitive) and in various different scenarios on a modular board with different characters is just amazing. The solo variant is very enjoyable and almost gives me the impression that the game was actually purposely designed as a solitaire game. It also seems that this game was heavily influeced by the [b]Heroes of Might & Magic[/b] video game series. Character growth feels amazing in this game: it happens slowly, but the milestones of leveling up are really impactful, meaningful and unique, thus really satisfying.

While this all sounds wonderful, here are my personal problems with this game:

The rules are unnecessarily complicated and full of details and exceptions. The combat system feels surprisingly unthematic and does not really seem like combat, as it boils down to (simple) calculations and the impression of doing taxes -- which is something most players will not expect at first when thinking of "combat". While the whole game is relatively complicated, the combat system is by far the most complicated part of the entire game.

Another con is, that the game practically unplayable with more than 2 players, because downtimes will reach painful lengths, especially if players are not very familiar with the game. The cooperative option is great, but there is no real interaction between players besides following a common plan together.

And while the game is often praised for being very puzzley and having a relatively low amount of luck, the game does indeed have a certain amount of luck which can at times hurt players quite badly. The first drawn land tiles and enemy tokens can have a surprisingly big impact on the beginning of the game. There's also of course the luck factor of the random card drawn, meaning that your hand sometimes tells you what you should do in order to have an efficient turn, instead of allowing you to do what you actually wanted to do.

I can see why this game is so popular (currently ranked #9 of all board games here on BGG), but in the end, the problems I am having with this game sadly do harm the fun for me. This game could be much better if some serious streamlining would have happened to this raw diamond, polishing off its rough edges while keeping its rich depth intact. Games can be complex, but they should not be complicated.

[b]Mage Knight[/b] is often described as an "adventure" game, which is really inaccurate in my opinion, since players are not doing quests/missions like in other adventure games: there are no storytelling aspects and going on "adventures" in [b]Mage Knight[/b] usually boils down to more combat or (more rarely) just paying a certain amount of resources at a certain location.

Overall, I would described this game as a sandboxy skirmish game with roleplaying elements (leveling up, skills), since it is very combat-centric and gives players a lot of freedom. Instead of calling it an "adventure" game, I would actually rather categorise it as a "racing game", since players are really under time pressure to travel and explore the land while leveling up as fast as possible through combat, since every new level is very impactful.

As I mentioned earlier, I took me quite a while to figure out if I like this game or not -- and by now, I can say that it is an aquired taste to me, after I understood the game's rhythm, that it's not an adventure game and that "combat" is something quite different here.

:arrowE: The definitive board game for adventurous puzzle solvers and book keepers. Definitely not a game for everyone and I can absolutely understand strong opinions in both directions.

RATING: 9
No game has surprised me more.  I'm generally not strongly attracted to fantasy/dungeon crawl games, but this one really works for a variety of reasons.  First, the deck-building mechanic is simply brilliant, providing only a handful of opportutnities to acquire new cards, but nevertheless providing enough variation in those cards to pursue alterantive paths to victory.  Second, the card play system is punishing but still very fun, forcing players to analyze board opportunities to get the maximum value out of each hand, even very poor ones.  Finally, the game creates fabulous opportunities for risk/reward analysis by making the precise difficulty of each encounter unkown but within a known range of possibilities.  I knew this game would work for me in my very first play when I was faced with the choice of taking on an encounter that I had a high probability of winning with minimal damage for a modest reward and one with a low probability of winning without severe damage for a large reward.  These are just the sorts of decisions that I relish in games, and Mage Knight delivers them on a consistent basis.

RATING: 9
Like most Vlaada games, you pay a price for thematic design with mitigated RNG in very heavy rules with many special cases and exceptions. The rulebook is poorly designed and organized, which exacerbates this. However, there is simply no better 4X game out there. Not only is this the best 4X tabletop game, but the RPG design is possibly the best I've seen as well - the feeling of progression as you level up, select abilities, and customize your deck is extremely rewarding.

My biggest complaints are that RNG plays a large role in the game in the form of exploration of tiles and spawning of random monsters. The game also suffers from snowballing. I have only played three times, though, so I want to get a few more games in before I decide if these problems are truly deal-breakers.

I'd say it's even a bit deeper than Prophecy, which is pretty good for a game of this genre. There's lots of rules but it isn't too bad. Combat, blocking & damage mitigation is messy but it can be explained. The hex map & exploration gives this a small edge over Prophecy, and the solid mechanics gives this a clear edge over Return of Heroes and stuff like that.  Not a short game, but none in the genre really are...

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I remember playing adventure games like Runebound wishing for a decent experience. I think what always killed them was random encounters. Most of those, if not all, are also lifeless dice chuckers.

MK takes deck building and makes it a central mechanic, yet not the entire game. You move, discover, new creatures are put out and you see them from a distance, making planned encounters. You visit locations, and because movement in the game can be fairly liberal, not to mention locations plentiful, there's little "man it's going to take me 5 turns to get all the way over there", it's more like "I can't wait to see what's over here".

Like any other deck builder you can have some soft turns, but because you can retain cards you can build toward more productive combat or purchasing turns. In the interim there are places you can easily sit for valuable resources or places to go and heal; villages are especially nice for the pillaging, IE extra cards for the next turn.

The game will play in about 45 minutes a player, so it's not short yet you are always looking forward to your next turn. There are some seriously creative ways to combo cards and you really do ave to think about the best way to use your hand each turn. One of the best things about hand management is that even is you cannot use a card for its face function it can still be used as a one value of one of four functions. 

It's also wild to see the pacing of the rounds as they are dictated by players. Sometimes you want to burn through your deck to rush other players and harm their progress, other times you'd rather let them end the round (since ending the round means you have to skip a turn). 

My initial rating was an 8. After a 3p, 2p, and a solo I now give it a 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
[microbadge=5][microbadge=670][microbadge=13167]([microbadge=5792])

Mage Knight Board Game is a problem.  There are a few reasons.  One of those is a matter of expectations.  People were comparing it to [thing=22]Magic Realm[/thing] right off the bat, as a large scale sandbox fantasy adventure game.  Some even called it a streamlined MR.  This is not the case.  MR is sandbox-y because you actually have the freedom to do what you want.  MK un-streamlines the process by introducing deck-building which restricts your actions each turn.  No longer can you do what you want (and possibly fail, but at least you can try).  Now, you need to draw the right cards at the right time (more on that later).

Another touted expectation for the game is that it is the ideal solo game.  Again, not really the case.  The reason that it works well solo is that there is no downtime with no other players, and each additional player slows the game down immensely.  Yet without interaction, the game is reduced to an excessive puzzle that plays you as much as you play it, rather than a game with meaningful decisions.

I guess I could note some good things.  The locations are, in the abstract, thematic and logical.  In fact, a lot of the individual isolated mechanics are thematic and logical.  It's the combination that seems like a problem.  The game requires a commitment to learn deck manipulation for each of the numerous situations you get yourself into, and those commitments are full of losses until your find your footing.  This is not to say that games should be easy, but games should be scaled.  MKBG has lots of scale: the plethora of scenarios is impressive and worthy of praise on its own.  The scale of the game requires tweaking, else the commitment the game requires may never be completed.

It's kinda terrible that movement is completely random but combat is not.

I feel like I need to repeat this one more time for emphasis: Movement is randomized.  Combat is predetermined.  When has this ever made sense in an adventure/RPG game?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Don't listen to the negative Nancies! This game is awesome for the right personalities. It may not be your type of game, but that doesn't mean it doesn't deserve every point of the ten that I gave it.

This is my favorite game of all time, if I have 3-4 hours in which to play it. I play with a partner, cooperatively. I understand that more players or PvP are not recommended. The solo/duo coop games are epic and the pace is great; I feel like I advance in power and am challenged consistently.

The heavy theme of the game makes it somewhat easy to remember what the possible actions are every turn. There's a village... what can you do at a village? Well, we can see the healer, recruit, or plunder it (sorry, no taverns). Mage Guild? Recruit, or learn a spell, but you can't heal there.

Each game is different. The random aspect of the terrain makes it like a puzzle - do I want to sacrifice now to push into early power, or take a chance I'll draw the one card I need to be more effective this turn? I might need to find and add more movement cards or skills if this particular game has more difficult terrain. What if I can't find them? Then I have to conserve resources and maybe skip certain sites. The game is well balanced - I barely win most of the time, but not always. It is a little easier now, since I have played so often, so we increase the difficulty of the cities a little bit and suddenly it is challenging again.

The instructions are annoying in the way that some of the rules are only found in the "walkthrough", so you have to flip back and forth between the books until you find that one rule you needed to reference. But they are very clear and the card interactions are immaculately clear. I'd liken it to Magic: The Gathering. There is almost zero ambiguity once you find the appropriate rulebook section. I did go to the BGG after a year or so of playing it and found two subtle rules that I was playing incorrectly. They weren't huge, but it was a little bit fun to learn about them. Everything else I gathered and played correctly from the rules themselves over 2-3 games (my usual learning curve for any game).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Initially, I rated this game a 9.  I love the idea of the game; it includes so many elements of adventuring, from allies and spells to artifacts and abilities.  The integration of light deck-building and hand management also seemed a good and fun fit to the adventure genre.

Ultimately, though, I had to lower my score to a 6.  The game is far too long for the amount of stuff you actually get to do.  In a given game, you will only cycle through your abilities four to six times.  You will get that cool card in your hand, only to either wait around for it to get used, making limited progress, or end up using it as a default "1" of anything.  Those cool allies and units?  You'll use them perhaps three or four times, total.  Those spells you can acquire?  You'll be lucky to cast them more than once or twice.  There is a ton of content here, but actually getting to use it in a satisfying manner is not present.

Moreover, there is a very limited power curve.  Thanks to the vagaries of your card draws, you may be just as unable to defeat an enemy on turn one as toward the end of the game.  The "best" way to play the game seems to be to really milk turns for all they're worth, caching up crystals from mines and using cards very slowly to build up a perfect hand; the problem is that not only is that type of game play rather boring, but it also makes a very long and slow game even longer.

Simply not enough payoff for the effort you put in.  A good design, with good components, and a heck of a lot of variety, but there are other games that hit the same adventuring niche with a lot less time commitment and generate a lot more fun.

RATING: 5
I'm just not yet sure about this game. It's very well produced.  There are several mechanics that I could enjoy, but it doesn't feel very satisfying (yet) when I play them. Defeating the monster tokens is a card puzzle, if you happen to have the correct card draw you kill it. And because you may or may not get great movement cards, you don't really spend much time thinking about what token to go after. I suppose it would be more fun if there were more opportunities to develop your deck and then cycle through that deck several times a turn. Then I'd be "making my own luck" .... But you see each card once per turn. Your character is mostly developed via tokens and follower cards you collect. This is fun....and as you get more power the monster token numbers ramp in a fairly predictable fashion. 

The ice/fire element for fighting is another aspect that could be interesting, but again, it's not really something you can fully develop and then take advantage of in your character. If you develop great cold ice attack ability, then hope you are near a token that will make that useful. It's fairly random. 

Bottom line: I feel mostly the victim of luck in card draws amd occasional blind monster token flips. I don't feel like there are a lot of fun, exciting, or interesting decisions. The increase in my character's power (and the monsters you fight) is fairly scripted, unless opponents take all of the good monsters. 

I wouldn't mind playing this game more with 2 or 3 players to see if I am missing something. But at this point, I'm not as excited as I'd like to be to play it.

RATING: 9
9/2012 Impressed after first two-player game.  It takes a long time, but time flies - usually a quality sign.  It's basically an exploration adventure game; roaming the landscape beating monsters collecting loot.  Gaining experience evolves your character with added abilities; recruiting units, mercenaries, wonderous equipment and the like, means you can challenge larger monsters and ultimately the large city castles.  Mechanics draw elements from several other games bringing them nicely together.  Deckbuilding has been popular lately and there's some here too, but thankfully not too dominant.  With time the constant monster-bashing will become tedious; game-altering expansions will eventually be required to keep interest.

RATING: 6
What I posted here are the posts I made in a local Hong Kong Forum:
Played a 4 player trial session yesterday, and my opinion about this game is quite mixed.
For me, this game is definitely not a good example of RPG mix with boardgame. I agree that the game design has many good points, but it's pitfalls are equally evident. In a RPG game, you're the one who choose what you want to do, even though you may not be good at doing that. In this game your choice is limited by the cards that're being dealt to you. In Thunderstone you're facing the same problem (someone in BGG mentioned it's just like Dilbert in dungeon, can't find the appropriate equipment at the right time), however it's way more evident in MK as your deck won't redraw until the next turn. So in Thunderstone I could still hope to get a good combination after reshuffling sometime later, in MK if you got a handjam early (aka land curse in MtG), your choice in the whole turn would be ultra-limited.
This game also lacks theme. During teaching I'm not sure what should I tell my teammates. I know I'm a mageknight, but the setting? Additionally, the monsters all don't have characters and are being represented by symbols. So even in fighting monsters I'm more like calculating maths rather than rolling lots of dice and fighting with modifiers. After finishing the game, sadly I have the say, the memory is much less fond compared with Dungeon Run, which has a worse design but full of theme. Mind you that I've played lots of old Mage Knight before, and this game reminds me nothing of it. It could simply be renamed as Rune Knight, Mage Quest, Tomb Dweller... or anything you could think of.
In addition to this, I'm the rules teacher so I need to face all those rules problem with little time playing myself
How about the good points? The level up and influence system is excellent. The spell, advanced action and artifact design is extremely clever and integrates smoothly (once you get past the rules) with your ability deck. The mana dice system both gives game a bit of theme about time and efficient.
1 last word: Don't try this game with 4 players. Downtime is just a problem as in other games, you could think about what you can do during other's turns. In a 4 player game the mana dice is going to change a lot and you could have no effective planning.
Overall rating: 7.5
Q1: How's this game compared with World of Warcraft the boardgame?
I just know that someone would ask this question
Both games are actually quite weak in RPG aspect. I'd say it's just like Ninja Gaiden or Devil May Cry in video game, in which there is a story, but the main enjoyment is hack and slash. If you really want to compare, WoW's RPG component is even stronger as in the endgame you either fight the other team (alliance vs horde) or a well known WoW evil boss.
The combat system can be viewed as an excellent example of ameritrash vs euro design. Both uses the 'hero only ranged attack then both closed attack' phase design. (is it a coincidence? I really doubt it) In WoW, the random factor comes from the dice rolling and you know what monster you're facing before the fight. In MK, if you know what's your opponent, then there is no random factor and it's pure mathematic calculation. If you don't know (like fighting in dungeon), then the randomness comes from the tile drawn.
Both games' level up system are among the best of all games I've played. Personally I love the WoW system better as it captures the' 3 specialisation per class' extremely well even in a game with so much dice throw. MK's system is very functional, but is too functional making every advancement you got become 'attack +2' instead of 'fireball' in WoW.
Both games have similar complexity. MK is easier to teach as you can tell others the new rules only when the cards are revealed. In WoW, you need to tell other players every rule from the start and preferrably all players should familiar with their class decks in order to speed up the game.
edited on 9/6/2012: rating dropped from 7.5 to 6. With repeated plays the downside become much more evident: lots of calculations, extremely prone to AP together with lots of downtime even with 3 players, make my copy quite likely to sit on the shelf for quite some time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[Played 30 times]

Convoluted "exploration and combat" fantasy game with a lot of options and bits.

The co-op version is easy and unrewarding; difficulty can be adjusted, but the game still lacks tension: it is a big puzzle to constantly analyze and has a terribly unsatisfying  anti-climatic ending (fixed by the expansion, but a serious flaw in the core game).

I feel as if it was designed for competitive play and yet also sold as "co-op", since it still works decently enough... but sadly it does not feel compelling or rewarding enough. Besides, it is solo play with a common goal, no real cooperation needed.

The competitive version has its issues as well (mainly a pronounced "rich gets richer" and the occasional random element that boosts or kills you; e.g. a summoner evoking the only enemy out of six that you cannot defeat).

It is bloated and variance seems more due to "mass" (multiple similar things) than really different actions to do.
For a game with all those rules and details, it is amazing how it completely fails to "tell a story" (it is just a puzzle that can be interesting to solve).

Lenght and downtime are a worrisome (especially dreadful with newbies and "slow thinkers"; the state of the board typically changes too much to plan when it is not your turn, so you spend more time waiting than playing).
It is way too long for what it offers with multiple players.

The rules are spread over two rulebooks and many reference cards (that are not just a reference, since they mention some rules that cannot be found elsewhere); it may ease the learning of the game, but it is atrocious to use later to find a single rule or clear a doubt.

Improved by the expansion (but I've no intention to ever play it again with more than 2 players).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I love the amount of freedom I get with this game as well as the re-playability.  The world map can be completely different each time and the epic scale of the game is unmatched.  I love the setting: Immortal demi-gods trying to conquer the land with massive armies, powerful magic, and awesome artifacts.  The whole thing climaxes with massive city battles, something I've never seen done in an adventure/role-playing board game, or for that matter, a video game RPG before.

The biggest problem is that all this kind of gets lost in the weeds of the mechanics.  I know I'm sieging a keep, defended with golems with my army of illusionists, and crossbowman.  But I have to continually remind myself of it because all of my energy is spent puzzling over card play.  It's such a waste of a great adventure to be stuck in the minutia of rules.  Reminds me a lot of modern iterations of D&D actually.  

The card puzzling can be fun in itself, but I feel like the game could be run entirely from a spreadsheet and it wouldn't change much.  I feel that the game is overrated just a bit and I can think of more than a few things that could have been done better.  It seems that we Americans get a little too romanticized over European game designers for some reason, I also saw this with the designer of Earth Reborn.  "Hey this guy's name is hard to pronounce, his game must be awesome!".  ER is another game way too consumed with fiddly rules for its own good.

Like Runebound, the game is also almost too unwieldy with more than a couple players, especially when everyone is agonizing over their cards.  But if someone is over-thinking his moves, while someone else is rushing, the quality of the game really goes down and you get a run-away player.  The game works best when played alone.

This ultimately does too much damage to the game's epic world and simply cannot make up for its shortcomings, and for that this is surpassed by Runebound, a game that I hardly play anymore.  I feel that Talisman generates a far better, more pure, fantasy adventure that still provides an underrated and timeless strategy experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Might be my favorite game ever. Certainly the best solo/solitare game ever.  I've actually only played this solo.  Don't frankly need anything more than that.  Just like I've never bowled a 200 score or better (it's on my bucket list; high score is 189, and that was in high school), I've been trying like hell to beat 200 in Mage Knight.  It's hard as hell, but I know it can be done, and I can't wait to have the time to do it!  Speaking of time, the ONLY reason this game isn't a 10 for me is that it's a major time investment.  A normal solo conquest game of MK can take me close to 4 hours, and as a father of 4 in a small house - I have neither the time nor the space to devote to playing this favorite game of mine.  Hoping to make some time this summer for it though.  I'd go nuts if they made an iOS version of this game - PLEASE!
Here's what makes this game brilliant - it's like a giant puzzle. Sure, there is luck involved - with the tile flips and order of the cards in your deck.  But that's pretty much it for the luck - the rest is all using your brain to solve problems of how you search and explore and fight. And beating enemies/monsters is immediately rewarding - your already bad ass character becomes even more bad ass and levels up, and up and up, and gains more cool stuff with each level up. Awesome. The problem solving element is sickly awesome though; it makes your brain hurt sometimes, in a good way.  And time FLIES playing this game.  First time I played, I checked the clock and suddenly it was 2:00 a.m. - 3.5 hours had gone by and it felt like 20 minutes.  Love this game.
EDIT: I've since played a few multiplayer coop games and the game is still awesome.  I've also now broken 200!  (thanks to the LL expansion add-ons like new deed cards, etc.)

RATING: 9
I don’t usually play solo games (unless I’m testing decks for Warhammer Invasion), but in this case I’m glad I did before having to teach the game. The basic card engine is not overwhelming by itself, but it gives you a plethora of possible ways to tackle your choice of challenges on an open map, so it’s a case of option rather than information overload. Now that I’ve got two actual (and extremely enjoyable) two player games under my belt, I’m happy to say that the transition from learning the rules to actually playing the game happens quickly and is helped by the noticable effort to streamline everything without cutting down on the wealth of possibilities.

One example: if you assault centres of civilization, your reputation goes down by 1. I appreciate immensely that it’s not 1 for a keep, 2 for a city and 1 plus a magical curse for a wizard’s tower, and I posit that this demonstrates the advances Vlaada Chvatil has made since Through the Ages, where you spend the first dozen games making new and exciting rules mistakes.

It’s also a bit unusual for me nowadays to buy games without playing them beforehand, so chalk this down as another data point in favor of putting game rules online. From the rulebook, I could not only tell that this is an unusually open game with interesting mechanics (especially the magic-fueled cards), but more importantly that it has an incredible amount of replayability due to a dozen of scenarios with a couple of variant rules stacked on top of them.

So you certainly get your money’s worth if you are looking for a game you can play for the rest of the year without exhausting the possibilities. Card quality could be an issue if you purchase games mainly for stroking them with satin-gloved fingers whilst whispering "Mine ... all mine!", but otherwise you’ll be fine. We noted that they felt strange during the setup and then forgot about it for the rest of the night. The miniatures and cities look a bit garish out of the box, but they are actually pretty detailed miniatures, just with an extremely flat paintjob. Some drybrushing and inking improves them immensely, as I’ve found to my delight, and it won’t cost you more than 90 minutes.

So all in all, this is an unrestricted delight, with a single caveat: I won’t ever play this with three or four people unless everyone has played at least half a dozen games. Even with two, there were some moments where things stalled for a bit – mostly at my end of the table, I gotta say – due to the many, many things you could do. Otherwise, Mage Knight is a rare example of the hype getting it right.

RATING: 9
After 4 sessions. First session lasted 4 hours - none of us realy knew the rules. The two next lasted 3,5 hours. The fourth one took just under 3 hours with players all familiar with the rules.

In a nutshell: This is Heroes of Might and Magic as a board game.

+:  Deck building mechanisms work perfect. Excellent varried artwork (and painted miniatures!!). Fantastic universe that you get to explore. Lots of ways to interact with the game. Fantastic feeling of adventure throughout the game. Lots to think about and plan in between your turnes. Hardly no luck involved - allmost all info is availible to players all the time (that is why you can plan your turns). Very immersive game experience. The VP system is not abstract: what helps your character to grow stronger in the game also scores you VP accordingly. 

-: PvP is not that fun. A lot of downtime with four players. Quite multiplayer solitaire. Some of the spells (ie. actions) just makes the game innesseserily over complicated. Lacks a catch up mechanism - if you fall behind it is very hard to catch up withe the leading player(s).

Advice for playing this game: This is a game that lets youexplore a great fantasy world. It is about boosting your character and maximize the impact of your actions. Pure power play! Wack monsters, level up, take over castles, explore new worlds, maximize the impact of your move, fighting and influence in the country. If you can enjoy that, you'll love this game. Always use the time in between your turns to plan. Don't look for PvP interaction and fighting. Don't expect a smooth 1 hour eurogame and don't expect the grand war and territory control of an american style game. Excpect a little bit of both and an ÄWSÖMË travesty and adventure.

RATING: 8
After 7 plays, very addictive, interesting, and challenging.  Takes a while to get into the 'groove' of what it takes to be score points, kill stuff, etc.  Don't give up after one or two plays as it is simply a hard game to get your mind around quickly.

The rulebook situation is a negative - give me one all-encompassing rulebook.  There are two rulebooks plus little cards describing sites.  There is small wonder that there are many rules questions given there is no way to look up rules effectively and even when I find something I worry that this is not the 'answer' I am looking for.

After more plays the rating moves from a 9 to an 8.  The four player balance is crazy random.  Sometimes it isn't much fun.  The three-player is outstanding, so we will work on something to tweak the 4P until we find something that works for us.  This game is too original and interesting to give up on.  Did I say this game is original?  The most original game I've played in years.

Avoid the 4P game.  After more plays, it very often leaves one person far behind and not having fun anymore.  Seems there are no good ideas on how to balance the 4P game better.  Stick to 3P or less.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I had a real hard game rating this game.  I've played once (learning game) and there are aspects of it that I really like.  Great feel for adventuring.  Good mix of luck, but you can still plan.  Good job of representing character development in a card deck.

Have some gripes though.
1)  Everything is a card and at times I had trouble keeping track of all the decks.  The table we were playing on wasn't large enough for the map and deck; which didn't help.

2)  The monsters are dramatically changed by icons, but the icons do not pop off of the token like the other stats.  Multiple times I thought I had the ultimate move only to be remidned that there was a grey arrow symbols blending in with another grey blob which completely changed things.

3)  Optimal play requires you to juggle both a hand full of variable powers and (to a lesser extent) the dice pool.  You can somehwhat plan in advance, but some elements (dice, hidden monsters) aren't revealed until mid-game.  This led to very long turns, especially if you missed an icon (see #2).

4)  This really needed player aids.  The potential monster list, icon definitions, and game scoring are all in differnet books.  There are helpful terrain description cards, but there's like 15 different unique terrains and a lot of searching and flipping was needed.

The game was too long for me for what it is, but I think after repeated plays it'll play much faster.  I see this likely to go up in the future.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.99
The TI3 of solo gaming. If you had heard about what games I had played during my high school and college years, you would think this would have been an instant get, and it was. This ended up being a game which once I heard about it me thinking it could be the greatest thing ever. For reasons, it just took forever to finally get it played.

In short, it's basically everything it was advertised it was to be. You take a hero and warmonger the hell out of the land. Hell yes. It's big. It's epic. It's a standard Vlaada game and hence an initial rules barrier and likely more of a messy game than many would want. You probably love the hell out of this game or you don't. I'm squarely in the loving the hell out of it.

If there are to be cons, I will say the rules will be on the higher side. Ricky Royal's Youtube series is stellar for getting your mind around the rules. As bad as the rep for the rules is for this game, I will say this. It flows amazing well once you do get a hang of it.

I can't even being to imagine playing this with AP prone people. This is going to be played solo or with a friend. I even warned him that when this gets played it will between him and I even though there is more in our group. I think two-player offers a nice back and forth for giving each player downtime to think things through. Adding players to that is just going to drag things out. Three veteran players can probably plow through it decently enough, but it is still going to be a long haul depending on the scenario.

Components. *sigh* An all too high number of components come with this coating on it that made components stick. There was no real issue separating everything but still annoying to deal with. The cards have this coating on them. I hate the cards and sleeved them asap. All of my cards came with a slight bend to them. They seem to bend back into shape fine enough. Note: any component issues seem to be well known for any edition of the game. Frustrating but true.

Rating:

Game quality: -1 for lack of desire to play across all player counts. 9.

Would I buy this again if I was starting over: Hell, yes. 9.

Do I want to play this if asked: Absolutely although time tends to interfere. 9.

Overall: 9.99.

Rating Potential: 9.99. (Locked)

RATING: 8
Good: 
Unique gameplay mechanics revolving around shared resources and day/night cycles. 

Character advancement is well done and it feels like you are going from a character with a stick, to a overpowered hero/villain that can raze cities. 

You can play as a hero or villain, and the game tracks this and has consequences. 

Turn options are done by drafting cards, and then playing out the turn. Which makes it entertaining trying how to make the most of your turn. Well executed turns feel extremely rewarding.

Bad: 
This game is super complex. If you can successfully figure out how to play it you should get some sort of technical certificate. 

Because this is so complex it is absolutely not new player friendly. 

Playing this game with more than three, heck even two, has way too much downtime. 

The game is pretty lengthy so it doesn't hit the table very often. To further discourage getting the game to the table the long gaps between plays causes the rules knowledge to fade so we always need to go back through the rules to re-learn the game. /sigh.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
For an adventure game it doesn't really look promising at first. Dry, card driven puzzle solving, too few and too similar monsters, very limited space to explore, complicated rules. Yet it works beautifully, despite all this. The rules are easy to grasp, however looking-up the site references can be quite a bother. The replayability doesn't come from the monster encounters, or from the tight scenarios, which all have surprisingly different feel. It's from the wide variety of options, that you can use to customize and optimize your army and hero to reach the goal first. Although there's PvP combat, the game is neither competitive, nor cooperative, yet it's not multiplayer solitaire either- it's a healthy mix of the three. You have to keep an eye on the others, can hinder them without confronting directly, but sometimes it worths to work together to grab the loot for yourself at the final push.

All in all, it's great both as a brainy card game, and an immersive adventure at the same time.

RATING: 9.5
From my wonderful 2012 BGG Secret Santa!
Anyone who has solved a Rubik's cube knows the thrill of mastering a puzzle.  Succeeding at Mage Knight feels similarly rewarding, but more so as the puzzle emerges anew each time players proceed through a game.  Learning to master this range of puzzle with all sorts of different tools and approaches is nothing short of fascinating. I wont speak of mechanics, theme, or even narrative here; the beauty of the puzzle stands alone.

I do often think about "fantasy sudoku extreme" when describing the game... Any part of that metaphor that comes across complementary is what is meant.

RATING: 6.8
Mage Knight is best described as a Victorian-aged steam engine: cantankerous and complicated and requiring all its knobs and valves to be constantly tended and adjusted, but when it moves it does so with a ponderous majesty. It is a mess of different mechanics incorporating almost everything ever done to any fantasy-themed game ever, but pulls it off with them all contributing to the jello-like flow of the game. Beyind the perpendicular learning curve and the simply silly number of aspects to mind its main drawbacks are long play times and long down times. Its principal advantages are a good Heroes of Might and Magic-esque experience and a relatively controlled-random system.

RATING: 5
Edit: I have revisited this game, and I think I like it more than I first thought. Definitely not some successor to Magic Realm, more of a min/ max, deckbuilder puzzle game with at least a fair amount of theme. Has none of the personality of MR, but still a decent game for the analysts out there. Works best, imo, as a solitaire game. Bumped from '3' to '5'. The rules, I'm afraid, deserve their bad rep. Easier to learn the game from videos that helpful souls have made.

Seems ok for what it is, but a little over fiddly and over-complicated (again, for what it is). I don't think it will ever really fulfill the 'Magic Realm Light" niche (for those hoping that it will) because it just seems too generic. In Magic Realm, when you played the Black Knight, you really felt like you were playing the Black Knight. All the heroes were so distinct, and the world of MR has such a cohesive theme. Even so, Mage Knight may fill the role of a hack and slash RPG strategy game for people not put off by the complexity. Plays fine solitaire (in fact, may even play best that way).

RATING: 10
This game makes a great first impression.  It reminds me of all of those role playing videogames I played growing up, but with all of the choices you make a puzzle.  We are still working through the first scenario and have made it through 1 day.  There is quite a lot to learn, and it took us seven hours to get to this point, but I actually like the directions so far.  I really like that he set up the walkthrough scenario and numbered all of the components so that you could be introduced to each aspect of the game methodically while getting a chance to start playing. While there is a lot to learn the rules seem intuitive so that I feel like they will be easy to remember and understand when we get to know the game.  And the game has so many nice small thematic touches, like mana dice slowly getting removed from the mana pool as night approaches and forest and desert being easier or harder to move through if it is day or night, or your followers refusing to help you burn down a monastery.  One feature that I especially like is the victory point track (or fame as it is called) as in other games victory points are the goal to win but you don't get anything for gaining VP.  Here as you gain fame you become more powerful and unlock skills and the ability to gather peasants and wizards and foresters to your cause.  The reputation track reminds me of the Good/Evil type choices in modern RPGs, and I like that I have to weigh the tradeoff between pillaging a village for immediate gain, or improving my reputation so that I will have greater influence later on.  There are so many different aspects and rules to this game, but somehow they seem to work really well together.

I play games primarily with my wife, so I am fine with long games as we can leave them out and go back to playing on a later date.  I have to admit in between plays I get excited looking at this game sprawled out on our table and thinking about our next round.  We like games like Agricola Farmers of the Moor, Through the Ages, Brass and Le Hevre, so this game has just the right amount of depth.  I could see how a complicated game like this would be more challenging with a gaming group where you are always trying to teach new people to play.  I also think it will have good replayability because of the randomness involved in the monsters and cards and tile layout and different game objectives.  It plays much differently than these our other favorite games.  We have reached the point now where a game has to be both well made and different enough than our existing games to warrant a purchase.  What a brilliant game developer, I look forward to getting to know this game better!  

Update:  We are currently playing game 8 and this game is definitely maintaining its 10 rating, if anything I like it more with more plays.  After exclusively playing the full game standard scenario we are branching out and trying the "Mines Liberation" scenario.  This adds good variety to the feel of the game and makes it feel fresh.  I am looking forward to trying out the other scenarios now and eventually the expansion which seems to be well received so far.  Vlaada deserves a special thanks for coming up with multiple gaming scenarios for his game when just the base scenario would have made for a great game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Cory
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[microbadge=1714]

[u]7-Sep-2015[/u]:  Not surprisingly, I really enjoyed this. I thought the game seemed pretty cool a year ago when I played the First Reconnaissance mission twice, but you really don’t see what the game has to offer in terms of its depth. And there is definitely a lot going on here. However, while there are a lot of rules, they are really not that complex. I found them easier and easier to remember with each passing round of play. I had printed out two fan made player aides last year, but I found the two on the back of the rulebook and the walkthrough quite helpful and more than satisfactory. The reference cards with all the different locations can be a little fiddly, but they have all the info I needed, and any question I had was always answered.  So…lots of rules but not difficult to master.

The gameplay is really great too. The sense of adventure and exploration is fantastic. Building the map as you go is something I’ve always found appealing in a game, and there is a nice mix of tiles in the base game with various locations and monsters to discover, fight, and conquer. Speaking of which, combat is basically a puzzle. You don’t always know what monster you’re going to fight but with the aide on the back of the walkthrough booklet, you can have a general idea. So, you know you’re going to need a certain amount of block and a certain amount of attack to obtain success. It’s a matter of what combination of cards and mana in your possession will help you accomplish this goal. Over the course of the game, new cards will enter your deck and new Units will be added to your tableau, so to speak. It’s deckbuilding but on a much more subtle scale. The impact of those cards and Units are greater here than a single card in most other deckbuilding games, and I find that very interesting.

I played one full scenario and two of the shorter ones. I have mixed feelings regarding this. The game is long…in any scenario, IMO. And I’m afraid that will hold it back somewhat from further plays in the future. The full scenario is definitely the way to go if you have the time and space for it. The level up system seems to be built for it. You can take your time, go on several side quests, build your deck up, increase your skills, and add Units to your reinforcements. Then, you head into the endgame ready for action. With the shorter scenarios, I liked…well, that they’re shorter. But they also feel rushed in terms of the game itself. You’re basically focused only the endgame and just hitting the side quests that are close by, hoping to gain just enough to meet your goals. I felt like I am missing out on of part of the game in these two shorter scenarios.

So, overall, a definite winner. The game is a great design of many mechanisms that all work together to give the player a real sense of adventure and accomplishment. Being able to level up your character helps add to the experience and the connection you have with that hero, giving a bit of an RPG flavor to the game. And of course, the game almost seems built for specifically for solo play. It’s deep, challenging, and fun in a way that you want a solitaire experience to be. But it is long. And it can feel fiddly with all those components – tiles, cards, minis, tokens, more cards, crystals, even more cards, two player boards. But if you want that fully engrossing experience, Mage Knight can certainly offer that for those with the time and space for it.

RATING: 9
Why Mage Knight gets a really high score?

Because it's fun. It's an interesting type of brain-burning and tooth-grinding fun that keeps you on the edge. You have a sense of urgency in everything you do, coupled with an almost tangible sense of progression and power as your overpowered hero stomps lowly orcs without breaking a sweat. 

It's modular, it's pretty, it's versatile, it feels a little bit like Heroes of Might and Magic 3-5, and it has an awesome expansion out that adds even more of everything. 

You do need to bear in mind, Mage Knight is also very long (2-3 hours for a good solo game), has a lot of fiddly little bits, a lot of cards, takes a lot space on the table, has some of the ugliest pre-painted minis I've seen, can be extremely tough to beat, requires you to know English (it's very language-based), probably isn't good for big groups, has a lot of rules that provide exceptions to the norm, a lot of symbols and iconography, a very weird manual that is confusing and useful at the same time and a high price point (since you WILL want to get the expansion eventually). Even with all of this, it's a pretty darn great game.

RATING: 2
Short version:

Extremely frustrating. Every turn is "here's why you can't do what you are trying to do." Stupid point salad at game's end feels at odds with the adventure theme. Long and un-fun.

Long version:

Oh, Mage Knight.

I've had such a visceral reaction to the game, it's hard to put my disdain into words. I've been trying to figure out why I hate this game so much, and which aspects of it are present in other un-favorites.

First off, the movement seems to be very restrictive. As in, there are movement cards in your deck that either give you 2 movement points, or 4 movement points if you spend mana of the right color (the available colors are determined by rolling dice, and these dice go into a community pool - you are allowed to use 1 die per turn, at the end of which you reroll it and add it to the pool). There are different types of terrain, and they will cost anywhere from 2-5 movement points to enter. It seemed like I never had enough movement points to get where I wanted to go, or I had a 5-card hand of nearly all movement cards, so I could go a good distance, but had no idea what I could do once I got there (you draw back up to 5 cards at turn's end).

You are allowed to use 1 die from the community pool per turn, and you're never sure whether the color you need will be available or not. There are cards that give you mana crystals of the various colors, essentially you can bank mana to use in future turns, so that helps mitigate the luck there. There was a dragon on the board, and multiple times I had the firepower in my hand to destroy it but I lacked the proper crystals to activate my cards, or didn't have right color available in the community mana pool, or I lacked the movement cards to get back to his location. I can hang on to those offensive cards but if I do that, I'm only drawing 2 new cards for the next turn and hoping to get something that will let me move. You may discard a card to get a generic +1 move or +1 combat, etc. But it costs 2-5 movement points per hex.

I admit that I have trouble understanding the combat system and the various symbols on the monster tiles as well. There are a few times where I thought I had it sealed up only to find out that a siege attack is not ranged (WTF) or that it only takes half damage from fire attacks, etc. So I'd spend a few minutes calculating everything out only to be told why it wouldn't work. Time to start over and figure out what my other options are. Ya know what? Nevermind. It's your turn. In fact, much of Mage Knight for me is being told why I cannot do what I want to do. Not fun for me.

Speaking of not fun, the game is a real bitch for downtime. My turns tend to be long, which I hate. Other players' turns tend be long too, which I also hate. Watching someone take their turn in Mage Knight is akin to watching someone take a long turn in Dominion. I know they're working out how they're going to do whatever it is they are doing, and they are playing cards, grabbing crystals and dice and keeping tabs on it all: "Okay, I spend a blue crystal to activate this card which gives me 5 movement points which I use to move over here to this tower...he need siege so I'll spend a red die from the pool to activate this army and play this card from my hand which lets me take a spell and activate it...spend a green crystal and a black die...now, he hits me first and his attack is 8 so I have 4 block here and I'll activate him for 4 more block, then I play this card, and discard that card to activate..."

OH FUCKING KILL ME NOW.

I don't care what my opponents are doing. Not at all. The main thing that affects my turn is the dice available in the pool, and I don't know what those will be until the end of my neighbor's turn so it is difficult to plan ahead.

To sum up, Mage Knight for me is waiting for my opponents to finish doing story problems with their cards on their turn, so I can make them wait while I do story problems and continually find out that my answers are wrong and I need to start over. I don't even need to get into the point salad, which Kurt already covered pretty well.

I think all of the branching choices tend to overwhelm me when I can't parse the value of one vs another. And I have to sit and calculate out which paths are viable, which is tedious and frustrating for me. I need to throw out the cards I want to use or clog my hand with them while I wait for accompanying cards so I can finally use them.

One guy at the table loved it, and the other is on the fence. I know the game can be played well, and that my complaints here can be overcome - the other players did it fine. The game just feels like a chore to me. It's so mathy (or maybe it's the type of mathy) that it just kills the theme. I don't see a grand adventure of rampaging across the countryside killing monsters, burning monasteries and raping cattle. I just see a big damn spreadsheet. If I played it enough I could probably figure out how to be competent at it, but it's no fun and it takes 3 hours per attempt.

I dropped my rating down to a 2 and will never play that game again. There were multiple turns where I spent my time trying to do something, found out I couldn't, found no appealing options on the board and just did whatever would spend my cards and keep the game moving. "Oh, I can't defeat this monster...I can defeat that one over there...but I can't get there...I can get to that town...but I can't afford to recruit anybody there...okay, fine. I'll discard my hand and move into that forest. Done.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Mage Knight has a number of things going for it. As a fantasy adventure game, it's got it all: exploration, combat, plunder, leveling up--you name it. As a solo game, the game's constraints present the solo gamer with an ongoing series of puzzles, and no doubt this is the most involved solo game I've ever played. Finally, underpinning both other aspects is a solid core of hand and deck management that takes Mage Knight over the top as a fantasy adventure game (so it's not [i]just[/i] wandering around, killing things, and taking their stuff) and provides the challenge in the solo game. If you're interested in all or even most of these aspects, I encourage you to try Mage Knight.

However, Mage Knight's excellence in these areas has me questioning how much these three aspects really matter to me, if at all. I started [rpgitem=44081]"killing things and taking their stuff"[/rpgitem] nearly 30 years ago, an I now find this tiresome theme somewhere between dull and despicable. I have to basically ignore Mage Knight's theme to find any enjoyment in the game. In addition, Mage Knight, considered the pinnacle of solo gaming here on BGG, has shown me that solo play of a board game is ultimately nothing more than an elaborate puzzle. Sure, it might be slightly more exciting than Sudoku, but there's also a lot more overhead, and I'm not sure I'm all that invested in this type of mental exercise. That leaves the hand/deck management as the main appeal for me, but there are plenty of other games that do the same thing in [i]far[/i] less time: Dominion, Blue Moon, Magic: the Gathering, and so on.

The nail in the coffin is the presence of [boardgame=1915]MECCG[/boardgame], which covers a lot of the same ground as Mage Knight. Most aspects of fantasy adventuring are present, and it's all done quite immersively in Middle-Earth, far preferable to Mage Knight's generic fantasy setting. Lacking a lot of Mage Knight's mechanical constraints, MECCG isn't as interesting for solo play, but before and after the game, the deckbuilding process provides plenty of solo enjoyment, especially if you're the keeper of the cards, trying to put together Arda decks and other game "environments." Indeed, I find this process of pseudo-design more fulfilling than puzzling through another round of Mage Knight on my own. If MECCG isn't enough, there's also the prospect of taking on the venerable Magic Realm, which [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/739015/mage-knight-worthy-successor-magic-realm]by many accounts remains the pinnacle of fantasy adventure board games[/url].

Having said all that, it might seem like I hate Mage Knight, but I don't. I'd still willingly play (against a single opponent) and think there's enough variety in the characters, cards, and scenarios to hold my interest for quite a few more plays. I just don't [i]enjoy[/i] it as much as the other options I mentioned nor nearly as much as its fans do.

RATING: 10
Sokáig töprengtem, hogy megvegyem-e, de a szabályfüzet elolvasása után egyszerűen zseniálisnak találtam, hogy a pakliépítés mechanikát felhasználva mennyire nagyszerűen oldotta meg Vlaada az új varázslatok tanulását, a sérülések kezelését! Például a méregtámadás: egy sérülés kártya kerül a kézbe - foglalva a helyet az értékesebb kártyáknak - és egy plusz sérülés kártyát az eldobott lapokra is kell rakni, ez a kártya csak később, a pakli keverése után jöhet elő, a mérgezés később bekövetkező hatását szimulálva.
Éjszaka/nappal váltakozásának bevezetése is érdekes volt számomra: éjszaka könnyebben közlekedünk a sivatagban, ám nehezebben a bozótos erdőben.
Pár egyéni tanulójáték után mertem csak belevágni, hogy másnak is bemutassam a játékot: 14 éves fiam érzett kedvet a kipróbálásra. Nehezen indult be a játék, de 4. fordulótól kezdve már ő is olyan kombókkal nyomta le az ellenségeket, hogy csak néztem.
Sajnos hosszú a tanulási folyamata, mindenkinek magától kell rájönnie, hogy milyen áldozatokat kell hozni: a lapokat néha be kell áldozni, sérülések nélkül nem lehet fejlődni.
A lapok variálhatósága miatt nagyon AP veszélyes, de ezt a szerző is érezte, a szabálykönyv is ki tér rá - miszerint jobban járunk, ha engedjük a kártyák kijátszásának próbálgatását, ha nem történt semmi visszavonhatatlan a játékban engedjük meg a lépések a játékos körében való tervezgetését a játék gyorsítása végett. Én szeretem figyelni a másik játékos lépésének alakulgatását, én végig élveztem a játékot!
Azt hiszem, a legjobb egyedül játszható társasjátékom, élvezhetőek a küldetések szóló módban is, bár egy picit más, rohanósabb stratégiát követel az általam eddig lejátszottak.
Nagyon nagy kedvenc!

RATING: 9

This could easily rise in my ratings with more plays

Update 1/27/2016
Finally pulled this off the shelf after 2 years between plays....TWO YEARS!  Set it up on the table and asked myself "What was I thinking waiting so long"?  

I needed to brush up on the rules nuances again, but this game is a beautiful solo experience.  There is really no need to even carve out two contiguous hours to play, either as I can leave it set up on the table multiple days.  The nature of the game on the table takes care of the bookkeeping.

I have roughly 150 games, but this is most definitely among the top 5.  And....when I look at a solo experience (whether I win or lose) Mage Knight and Robinson Crusoe are my prized options.

RATING: 9.5
Watching Ricky Royal's walk through and solo conquest videos (Box of Delights) really helped me get up to speed more quickly. Still, I had to use the rulebook quite a bit during the first game. 

Played 3 games thus far, 1 Recon and 2 solo conquest. I lost the first solo conquest but won the 2nd with 150 points. Maximizing the effectiveness of your hand is key, that and not being afraid to take wounds. 

After my first game I wasn't sure if I had made the right decision purchasing this game, but once you become more familiar with the rules and your options, it really starts to shine.  

Edit 1: After many more plays I am upgrading this from 8.5 to 9. It is a bit fiddly but a fantastic journey none the less.

This is a game for those who enjoy planning, strategizing, and optimizing each turn. If you are looking for a quick hack 'n' slash dungeon crawler this is not the game for you.

Great solo experience! Avoid playing with those who suffer from AP unless you have infinite patience.

Edit 2: Updating my score to 9.5. I absolutely LOVE this game.

RATING: 8.5
A tough slog learning the rules, but worth it. The fog slowly clears to reveal an excellent game. Every rule and mechanism is there to support the theme, and once memorised, it all makes sense. Probably wouldn't recommend more than 3 players unless you have 5 hours to spare. Also be prepared to play it incorrectly the first few times. Rick Royal's Box of Delights videos are a must watch if you want to learn this game. It's a lengthy, complex game, and can be frustrating if you draw move cards when you want influence or attack, or influence cards when you want to move. At its core its about making the best of your hand and using cards optimally. Combat takes a while to understand. Mana crystals powering up cards is an awesome touch.

RATING: 8
Probably my most demanding game. It's very rare for me to get the opportunity to play this. You need players who can sit down for many hours and digest the complicated rules.

But when you can play it, it's very fun! It feels a lot like Heroes of Might and Magic. You travel across the land, collect treasures and fight monsters. And it's so rewarding to get better at it and watch your hero cut a path through their foes.

Watch out for the risk of downtime here. It's probably best to stick to a small number of players to keep it running smoothly.

Review here:

http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/762682/ninjadorgs-obligatory-my-first-solo-conquest-post

EDIT - took nearly 5 months but Tovak finally arrived.

Awful customer service from Wizkids - I've been waiting over three months for a Tovak figure, which did not come with the game.  The second printing has gone ahead but they still can't fulfil the needs of those who bought the first printing.  But for the game itself...

This game is in my head all the time right now, can't stop thinking about it and playing 2 or 3 solo games a night in anticipation of another multiplayer session when I get the opportunity.  Although abstract and mathematical or 'Euro-y' this has fast become one of my favourite games of all time.

Still learning the rules as I go.  Makes me wonder if I'm ready to get stuck back into Magic Realm again now...


UPDATE 15/01/14:

This is another long, long game, and one session of it took all night, a session which I won fairly decisively.  Sam played Krang and I played Wolfhawk and we played a standard Conquest game with all the new stuff shuffled in but none of the new scenarios and no Volkare.
It has to be said, I love Mage Knight.  The wealth of decisions, the way the world randomly populates as it goes, the effects of terrain, the varying encounters, reputation, influence, the deck building and levelling up – it all adds up to a really intricate and detailed package, with tons of brain burning decisions to be made every turn.  Thematically I’m not fond of it all taking place over just three days, I’d prefer it if each action represented a day or something, and I’m not familiar with, nor very interested in, the MK world, but these are very small complaints.  Between this and TtA I became a huge Vlaada fanboy, and that led to my impulse purchase of Dungeon Lords, which I still haven’t yet tried.  As a solo game, Mage Knight is pretty peerless.  As a multiplayer game, as Sam rightly pointed out, it’s a lot like you’re playing different games on the same board at the same time.  Outside of PvP, much like Runebound – though a far superior game to Runebound - there’s little else you can do to influence each other, and the PvP is of no real interest.  I get that the threat of it might add an edge to the game or whatever, but if you come to blows in a two player game like this it’s going to seriously affect the rest of the game one way or another.  Next time we’ll play one of the cooperative Volkare scenarios instead.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My comments are overdue, but recent experience with Star Wars Imperial Assault, Myth, and Mice & Mystics has made me realize that not only is Mage Knight an excellent deck building game, strategy game, and satisfying puzzle; it is also the best dudes in a hallway game.  In fact, Mage Knight is arguably the best deck building game, a genre I really enjoy.  It has more competition in the strategy game department, but it is easily top ten.  And this game is one of the top 5 solitaire games I own.  Incredible.  Yes, it is fiddly.  Yes the rules could be better organized.  But the effort expended is rewarded in spades.  I also really appreciate that this game is fun for two to four newbies who will grow in their capabilities in this game over time, but will enjoy a balanced experience in the beginning.  I also appreciate that the solo experience gives you a challenge to simply just play well, but also challenges you to be so perfect in your problem solving skills that you will eventually have to take on more creatures with only five cards than it ever seems possible to do.  If you like solo games that stack the deck against you, but appreciate a game that allows you to build up your skill at a game along side others, with a score card for how each of you are progressing, you will love Mage Knight.  Oh, and if you find yourself behind one of your peers in your quest to improve, you can always just attack them to let some steam off.

RATING: 7
As a mage knight, players move around terrain to attack monsters, influence units, or explore different dwellings. Each player has their own deck of cards. At the beginning of the game, they are virtually the same except for one card. You can then acquire spell cards, or other special cards, and wound cards (which fill up your hand) as the game evolves.

I enjoyed my one and half plays of this. I like solving problems, and I have barely scratched the surface of this game. I'm hoping to get in more plays of this game, but part of the problem is trying to find the time. I suspect like all good games, the rating will rise with more plays.
