=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a board game review:

We completed our first play-through of MageKnight the board game, and I have to say it really lives up to our hopes and expectations from the designer of "Space Alert". 

The game if fun and fast-paced despite being long. It's mechanics are elegant and interesting. The systems are thematic, the components are beautiful, and the combination of tried and true game mechanics with a deck-building twist is satisfying and interesting. Despite random elements, no player will win based on luck because the volume and depth of meaningful strategic decisions is so high--furthermore because of the way turns are spaced out, similar in elegance to War of the Ring, there is less "analysis paralysis" that many games of such complexity will suffer from--hence the fast pace.

It's an open world adventure game--I think of them as MMOs from beginning to end in one box and one sitting similar to Talisman, Runebound or WOW the board games. Based on my research and experience, it's better and more gratifying than all of these games and though I'm excited to try more of this genre including "Prophecy" and "The Magic Realm", I already anticipate that Mageknight will be the new and long-standing champion in the open world adventure fantasy genre (To distinguish this from a dungeon-crawl fantasy)

Unlike other fantasy worlds, this one feels truly original and interesting, the setting is interesting and dynamic and the replay-ability is extremely high.

RATING: 10
After the initial learning curve, everything clicks into place. Thematically robust - adventuring, combat, NPC interaction.

RATING: 4
Great take on fantasy themed demolition derbies to level-up  as efficiently as possible with a hand management engine and goût du jour deckbuilding seasoning. Cards basically have different colors to represent attacking/blocking, moving/shooting, healing/boosting and interacting/money or can be laid sideways to give +1 modifiers to said actions.

Since there's no odds when performing deterministic actions with open information, risk vs reward decision making is replaced by binary "yes/automatic" or "no/impossible" processing. Mostly, you'll be searching for a bunch of arbitrary rules that may apply to your situation, get your head around as many exceptions for sake of convolution and so, ponder for ages before doing anything any given turn. Adding more friends to the table accordingly adds hours of downtime and proportional chances of walking through a cleaned-up map. To speed this bloated game up, the author suggests planning ahead (really?) and playing at the same time... even though you do buy cards from the same offer, pick mana dice from the same pool and a couple nasty skills directly alter your opponent's movement or deck, not mentioning it isn't calculating but searching for the right freakin' double sided reference card and ruling out what you can and can't do that takes time, not resolving your risk free action! And there's even a backtrack rule that allows the real active player to redo his whole turn from the start, yay!

Besides dispensable day & night cards, the wound mechanic was a neat idea to hinder possibilities before experiencing how limited your possibilities are any given time. With only a single different card per deck, knights are obviously empty shells so they surely are balanced? Try winning against porn actor Goldix or his battle thonged babe Arythea. At least, you'll have the pleasure of leading armies of powerful golems, arcane mages and the likes that will serve once then as meat shields. Mostly though, you'll try to desperately move your lazy ass a couple hexes a turn and go on adventures without narrative, wishing to discover easy orcs on accessible terrain, drawing the right cards at the right time, entering villages and monasteries that will offer the same companions and upgraded actions as any other on the map.

[i]Hint: remember that fire blocks ice, ice blocks fire, coldfire blocks coldfire but nothing blocks hotice![/i]

RATING: 9.9
A rare beast. It is, at first blush, simply a beast. Its alarmingly long rule-set is filled with finicky exceptions. Its tabletop footprint is gigantic. It presents an intimidating menu of choices at every turn. And plan on setting aside 4-6 hours to play the solitaire game at a leisurely pace.

Yet though the barrier to entry is high, the riches to be found are greater still. Mage Knight performs the most dazzling feat of balance of any game I know. The countless possibilities are calibrated with extraordinary delicacy. As a result, despite the game's complexity and its many sources of chance - card shuffles, tile draws, dice rolls - the game is almost purely one of skill. But somehow none of this comes at the expense of thematic immersion. All of the moving parts in this dense strategic masterpiece make good thematic sense, leaving you with the feeling of a powerful Mage Knight exploring the land and conquering ever more terrifying foes.

Mage Knight is the tabletop equivalent of War and Peace: grand, challenging, and immensely satisfying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I really like the idea here of deckbuilding your arsenal and exploring, conquering and collecting better stuff. The theme is great too. So all the elements were there for me to like it.

The problem comes when you try to play it! Each turn is a long solo optimisation puzzle. It's bad enough when it's your turn, as you AP up trying different permutations of cards, only to discover that you can't do what you want and then have to repeat the process for a lesser enemy. But when it's someone else's turn, it's much worse! And without PvP there's virtually no interaction of any kind - I can see why it's so recommended as a solo game.

The components and rules are insanely fiddly too - I constantly had to ask what each hex or monster did as they came up.

I can't imagine playing this game with more than 2 people, as my one 2p play took 5 hours. And with it being multiplayer solitaire, I'd struggle to find a reason to even play with 2. As I'd rather play multiplayer against AIs when alone, I can't see myself playing this much - a shame, because it has huge promise.

RATING: 10
It is hard to describe how addictive this games is.  After playing the walkthrough scenario, 3 of us played the next scenario.  The next thing we know, it is 9 hours later, 2:30am, and we don't want to stop.  After a brief sleep break, it was back at the board the next day and the day after that.

RATING: 9
A tough to egg to crack initially, but once I found my stride with the game it really became a strong favorite. The core scope of the rules are fairly intuitive but there are a very high degree of situational conditions that can affect how you calculate or determine the effect of your actions which seems to be the hurdle that throws many from this game initially.

To really "get" this game it is best learned from others, or by following the great Youtube walk-through videos put out by people such as Ricky Royal. After that process the game really blossoms and you are left with a very engaging adventure game that consistently causes you to puzzle out every inch of your options making even solo play an engrossing experience.

The main fault I have with the game however is the overall lack of real narrative or any storytelling quality. There is no quest framework or flavor text to add anything to the theme besides the card art and what you are actually doing during the game play itself. This lends a little bit of isolation to the world you are traveling around in, and it sometimes feels a little flat in that sense.

RATING: 10
Rating after one introductory scenario game.

*** Update after 20 plays ***

Well, it's a 10 for me as expected. Astonishingly thematic and well designed. The mass of rules have caught me more than once (there are a few too many special cases and exceptions for my liking, to be honest) but once you get it down you've got it down.

I really, really love how your character gradually becomes able to accomplish far more impressive feats over the course of the game. That Orc you had trouble with in the early game becomes roadkill to be nonchalantly swatted aside in the late game...

Cannot wait for expansions.

RATING: 10
Luckily enough to be sent the files to create a prototype of this game before it came out.  Now that I own the actual copy, I am extremely happy.

This is one of the games I've waited my whole life for.  I normally hate games where you go around killing things and getting xp because they are normally dice rolling and luck based.  This one isnt.  It combines the best bits of other games, gels them all well together.

It has well constructed game mechanics, a very clever combat mechanic which acts as a kind of puzzle.  The replayability is the best I have ever seen in a game.  You can play this game competitively, coop, solo.  You can choose whether to turn on Player vs Player combat or not.  The game comes packed with 11 scenarios and multiple variant rules already built in that you really can play this game however you want to.

Play time can be a turn off, because this game has a big rulebook and is moderately complex.  And a full first game might take about 6 hours, but the play time drops drastically with each play, coming down to 3-4 hours.

Epic game.  Thankyou Vlaada.

Unfortunately, some players of the original Mage Knight game are going to rate this game poorly because it isnt anything like the original game.  Oh look, there we are, someone has already rated the game low although he has never played it and doesnt know anything about it but is upset that he cant use his old Mage Knight figures :)

RATING: 7
"As people say, this is a complicated, puzzley adventure game. I wish the co-op scenarios had more cooperation. And I wish it were streamlined by 30%, which is what I tend to say about Vlaada games."

What I like:
- Fantasy theme with great components, including the modular board tiles
- Deterministic combat
- Sense of exploration
- Offers solo and a couple cooperative scenarios
- Box is appropriately sized

What I don't like:
- Could be streamlined by 30% without losing much
- Long, and takes up a lot of space on the table
- Co-op scenarios don't look that interesting
- Co-op mode doesn't offer many chances to actually cooperate
- The theme is a bit dark at times (e.g. burning down monasteries) 

When I say this could be streamlined, I'm thinking we don't really need ruins and mines and spawn points and dungeons. We don't really need artifacts or advanced units. In solo and co-op mode, we don't need tactic cards. Having night and day modes is of marginal value. We could live with half as many combat modifiers.

All of those things could be in expansions, leaving the base game to be far more accessible, and much shorter (especially with important learning/teaching games). With everything, the game isn't "too complicated", but it does feel needlessly complicated, to me (and many others, apparently). I would put the weight around 3.5.

RATING: 2
Too intimidating for anyone but hard core gamers. Supremely overrated. Not fun. Akin to wearing hip waders and walking through quicksand. Requires serious and constant rulebook study while playing. In spite of the density, I found the RACE to finish a scenario in time (3 days/nights) wholly unsatisfying and rushed and the end goal supremely boring and cliched. Everything was visible. Never felt I was on an adventure full of surprises. 

 Once I failed to conquer the castle, I had no urge to try and slog through the quicksand again. I prefer fantasy games with more surprises, a sense of adventure while exploring and a more casual pace. Even Arabian nights is more enjoyable for us. This is a gigantic puzzle and turns take far too long to figure out, even as two player, and include too many rules exceptions and clauses and constant references to the rulebook to make sure you didn't miss one of fifty important details. All work and no fun. 

 thought I might love this as a solo game, but in a year of it sitting on my shelf, I cannot muster the drive to relearn the game and attempt it. It's a job, not pleasure. This game reaffirmed that solo play goes against the concept of fun gaming for me. I like to socialize in a game. If I want to play solo, there are a million video games that offer more pleasure than this. 

Mage knight is a game that might have worked before electricity, books, TV, Internet, masturbation, were invented, when people had nothing to do but farm the land until exhausted then come home and play a game by candlelight...no wait, no one would have the energy to learn and play mage knight after working a full time job. It's for people in prison, who have a lot of time...no, wait, they could be bouncing a ball against the wall or doing push-ups, both much more satisfying and entertaining pastimes.  I suppose if I was stranded on a desert island with nothing to do all day...no, wait, I'd rather talk to a soccer ball.

RATING: 8
2/19/12 - Mage Knight feels like an epic campaign in a board game format. The only similarities it has to the old clix based game of yore is the name. Tiles are flipped as you explore the landscape with monsters, keeps, towers and cities to help you gain new abilities and level up. Chits are used  show your level and powers. Cards from a personal deck are used to resolve everything and you can customize it by acquiring new cards in a market.

The only warning I offer is this, Mage Knight is a long game. My 4 player game took over 5 hours with rule explanation but it never seemed to drag nor did I wait long for my turn.

RATING: 6
I actually quite liked the game. The exploration was great, I thought the wound mechanic was nicely implemented, and I loved the reputation. A lot of good things going for it.

What I didn't like was how strong some of the enemies were. Many times, I just had to flee and I knew I would never be able to deal with them. It always seemed that I didn't have the right cards in my hand. I was always drawing my reputation cards when I needed to move, or my movement cards wehen I needed to fight, and it left me hurting many times.
What I just really didn't like about the game is that it took forever. Our game took like 10 hours, and after investing so much time, I just had to look at the board and think "...is that it? We spent 10 hours and I managed to walk like 10 spaces and get into a few fights?..." If the game really only lasted up to 4 hours, I don't think I would have minded so much, but none of us were really slow or anything, so that wouldn't be achievable unless we were super familiar with the game and could make snapshot turns.

We played a competitive game without pvp, and to me, it just felt like a race as to who could snipe the locations first. In the end, I would much rather play cooperative or completely competitive with pvp. I do feel that this would be an amazing solo game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Despite the innovation, this game still very much has the feel of an adventure game, like Runebound.  Mage Knight adds a deckbuilding component to the game, where players start out with somewhat different decks that represent what their character can do, and can add to it as the game goes on.  Additionally, newly-acquired cards go on top of your deck, meaning that you'll be able to use them once before the vagaries of shuffling.  Normal CCG-fu doesn't really work here, as you don't want to burn through your deck as quickly as possible--if you deplete your deck first you'll get fewer turns than your opponents.  There are a ton of little fiddly rules everywhere, but after a couple of plays, things started to sink in pretty well.  What's neat about the game is the variability in card play--you have a ton of options, and often you can come up with a really impressive turn; it just feels satisfying.  In this case, I think the large rules overhead is worth it.

(5+ plays)

RATING: 10
[b]Update:[/b] Alright, after quite a few more plays of this game, I can honestly say it is absolutely amazing. I don't know why I didn't try bringing this back out sooner. The game always presents an interesting and challenging puzzle. If I can play this game almost 2 weeks straight every single day and not be bored of it, you know it's a great game. I'm constantly thinking about it and I can't wait to play again. This may move up to my favorite game ever and that's quite the feat.

If you're thinking about getting the expansion, do it. It takes this already amazing game and kicks it up a notch.


After a couple more plays, I can honestly say this game is amazing. I was a bit worried after the first play or two, but each subsequent play has gotten better and better. Turns can be a bit slow with new players, but man is this a brilliant game. So much to do and so little time. Leveling up is fun and acquiring new guys to fight for you is great. Each spell you acquire and each character you play can vastly change the game up. Quite replayable for being essentially the same objective each time.

Initially, as a solo game, I was turned off. Trying to learn the game and play it solo was far too much for me. After knowing the rules well enough, playing solo has gone from being a chore, to being very fun. I still find it more fun with 2 or 3 players, but solo is a very viable option now.

Even though I rate this game a 10, I wouldn't play it any chance I got. I love the game, but it's not something I want to play at any request, especially if I had to teach more than 1 new player at a time.

RATING: 9
This is a monolith of a game - large, imposing, inscrutable, and thoroughly impressive. There is game design for miles in this package. Truly a wealth of options and paths to be taken on any given game turn: many people will look at their hand, look at the board, and decide they can't do anything. They are wrong. 

Now, there is an ugly side to all this: the rules overhead is monstrous. It is sometimes quite difficult to find the rule or clarification you are looking for, and even when you think you have the rules down, there is likely some small piece you overlooked. That doesn't stop every game from being fun and epic, though.

RATING: 9.25
Fun Factor: 9 (Who doesn't like trying to build a hero and see how powerful you can become...)
Components: 9 (Nice insert, cards are silky but a bit flimsy- I sleeved, but comes with nice pre-painted minis and a faithful art direction that is immediately likable)
Theme: 8 (Good background info, good thematic elements a bit generic but this is kindof a good thing)
Mechanics: 10 (Several elements come together to make something magic.  At the heart is the deckbuilding as you adventure, which is quite well done and serves as the heart and soul of the game. Technically very tight in terms of design.  Rules fairly well written.)
Theme + Mechanics: 9
Replay Value: 9 (Very good replay value.  This game is adjustable in so many ways and it is quite EASY to make said adjustments)
Scaling/Players: 10

Subjective: +0.25 Very few games offer customizability of conflict level between players straight out of the box.  For this, the game receives a bump for innovation.

Ok.  Mage Knight.  What can I say.  This game is endearing on many levels.  It is Talisman for a new age, deckbuilding in an adventure game, and most amazingly, not only can you perfectly scale player count... 

you also have perfect scaling in terms of level of cooperation.  Now this is something fairly innovative! You can literally dial the cooperation in the game from solo to fully co-op to semi-co-op and anywhere from mildly competitive to severely competitive.  There is even what amounts to a "king of the hill" style scenario where the last man standing on the portal when the sun sets is the victor.  Now I must admit, this is something very useful.  I have groups that want conflict, and groups that don't.  This game suits them all with but a few minor adjustments.

People have said that Mage Knight is a bit fiddly.  I disagree.  I feel that this is the Goldilocks of the Adventure genre... JUST RIGHT in almost all respects.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Yes, yes, yes! This deserves a 10 and a spot in my personal top 10 on its merits as a solo game alone. I would never have thought a solo game could be so great. And it's not too shabby when played with friends either.

One thing I hadn't realized from all the reviews and comments I'd read, and something you won't get from playing the walkthrough scenario, is how much tension and pressure and thrill there is in solving the giant puzzle that is Mage Knight as well as you possibly can. Sure, you can do this and that, explore a dungeon here, fight some orcs there, do whatever you like, but everything you do has the ultimate goal of getting as strong as you can as quickly as you can, to be able to defeat the end bosses (the cities) before the game ends. So you have to constantly push yourself to engage enemies, squeeze everything you can from villages and the like, and take risks. The walkthrough is a bit ho-hum, "let's see what would I like to do now", but the full (solo) game is more "what do I need to do?? AAAAH I'm not going to make it!!!". Going in because you have to, risking success or failure on a single battle because there is no other choice, and then finding the exact sequence of cards to narrowly defeat the enemies, is awesome.

I dislike games that are basically linear puzzles, where all you do is calculate if option A or B will bring you more points, then take that action. But what I've found is that I LOVE games that feel like multi-layered puzzles, with the right amount of luck/randomness, a great theme and some fighting. Like Magic: the Gathering and Neuroshima Hex!, Mage Knight delivers, and is my favorite of this type of game.

RATING: 4
Adventure game where you are an adventurer trying to level up and kill monsters. Minor deck building aspect. Long game! Most ideal with 2 or 3 players, as with 4 one player tends to lag behind due to the board being cleared by the players ahead in turn order.

:star: Art and components
:star: Innovative mechanics
:nostar: Handles 5 or more players
:nostar: Good with different player counts
:nostar: Low time between turns
:nostar: Comfortable complexity
:star: Re-playability
:star::nostar::nostar: Enjoyment

RATING: 10
Things you need to know.

1.) There is a lot of downtime in a multiplayer game. It gets less as players learn the game. This game is best enjoyed solo, or with 2 players.

2.) There is a learning curve. It will take you a few games, and a few rulebook readthroughs before you feel comfortable. 

3.) There is *some* luck involved. It seems like a lot at first, but the more you play the game the more the luck fades and all you see is infinite choices, making it a tactical treasure trove. 

4.) This game is not for everyone. Read some of the game reviews on the forums before you buy.

5.) If this seems like a game you will enjoy, and you have a bit of patience and perseverance, there is a good chance that it will be the best gaming experience you will ever have. Was for me and many others.

RATING: 10
This is like an epic cross between a puzzle game, an RPG and Dominion.

Unlike most boardgames with a solo mode, this truly works as a solo game. It also works with more players, but can be on the slower end of the spectrum.

It encompasses a wide range of game styles; from co-op through to aggressively competitive games, including pvp - although, house rules are wanted for the more co-op end of the spectrum to prevent it being multi-player solo games.

It has impressively balanced asymmetric powers - different powers suit different play styles and scenarios better or worse, but there appears to be no online consensus about which is best.

RATING: 10
This is a crazy game. But a good game. It is also tough but fair. My hardcore PC-gamer little brother who hates 99% of everything because it's "too casual" absolutely loves this one, to the point at which he basically only plays this and Netrunner. It's such a rules nightmare though, but if you care about the core gameplay it's manageable.

Tentative rating: 10/10 if you love in-depth RPGs. 0/10 if you hate having to consult the manual during gameplay.

Update: My brother has at least 25 plays of this and still loves it. I play it with him whenever I can. I have to respect a design that can keep him, the most depth-driven gamer I know, excited to play it after all this time. It's not right for everyone, but I's great at what it wants to be.

Holy Vlaada ! What an Ameritrash beast, pre-painted miniatures, modular hex-board, scenario based, spells, artefacts, advanced skills. Great Ameritrash game with some Euro mechanics thrown in. It feels and plays great and I cannot wait to try it again, let's hope further plays prove to be even more exciting than the intro scenario.

The game is balanced and Euro-like that it never feels awesome or thrilling but drags along in a stale and calculating pace. Not bad at all, but I am less impressed than I was the first time I tried it.

RATING: 8
Took a little bit but I finally wound up falling in love with this one. A massive experience, with, levers, buttons and moving parts everywhere.

With so much to explore, conquer and reckon with, no two games have felt alike. 

The feeling Mage Knight rewards you with, when pulling off something big and ambitious, is not just what I was hoping for from this game, but what I hunger for through gaming in general.

Solitaire it has been great and I can already see that it is going to end up relegating some of my other solo fave's to the dreaded, "shelf". 

Two player the other night was also a blast and didn't take nearly as long as some would have you believe.

Yes, the rule books are a bit of a chore and you will be bouncing between the two of them once the game is on the table. But the community here at BGG is amazing and beyond helpful..better than any index.

RATING: 8
This is an absolutely phenomenal solo game. There is enough here to keep a solo player thoroughly occupied without the need for a human opponent. Be warned however, this is very long (and I imagine even more so with human opponents) very, very heavy game. It successfully combines aspects of fantasy adventure and deck building and feels so well crafted and tight that you won't believe it came out of one man's head. That said, this is not for everyone. If theme and story are why you like fantasy adventure games you may not like Mage Knight, there is basically no story and the theme, while present, is not nearly as thick or important as it is in say Runebound; this is all about the beautiful mechanics.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Loving this game!
Bought it for solo play, but I hope to play it multiplayer some day.

The possibilities in this game are huge! You can go for different strategies: should I get some spells, units or advanced actions? Should I try to get some artifacts?

Luck is a part of the game, and I've had a few plays where the cards I drew never seemed to work with what I wanted. Which is why it doesn't quite score a 10.

Overall this game is one of my favorites. Each game lasts around 2 hours, but each game just fly right by.



Some 15 plays later, the game has lost some of its initial shine. Considering selling

After 18 plays, the game is running a bit stale for me. I am happy to have owned and played it a lot, but feel like it is time to pass it on.

RATING: 7
First, I wish I would play it more often.  If you spend too much time in between plays you're doomed to constantly be referencing the rules as you play, which turns what should be a 90 minute game into 3 hours.  Ugh!

Sadly, this game just takes too long!  I like everything about this game, but it's so involved that I rarely get it out because there are just so many other satisfying games that take 1/3 the time.

Because of how long this game plays I don't think I can ever rate it higher than I have already.

There is just so much going on in this game.  The rules aren't hard per se...just so much to keep track of.

RATING: 7
Despite the laborious way doing anything first requires you to choose the right combination of cards from your deck, the end result is a very rewarding grind through hostile territory. There are plenty of meaty decisions to be made.

Everything is tightly tied into your deck, despite the map, and you can evolve your character in interesting ways. 

In an odd way, the challenging use of a deck to try to navigate safely around a map reminds me of the simple (but great) race game Snow Tails (the 1st edition).

RATING: 10
This is quite possibly the best board game that I own. It took me a long time to learn it and also to utilize all of my options when playing, with the little details and exceptions being the most frustrating to fully understand. But when I finally got past the learning curve, I started to love the game even more. The game has a very unique and complex combat system. Add resource (mana) management, recruiting and deck building to that, and each battle becomes a brainstorm. I had a lot of fun playing this game solo.

Edit: We tried it 4-players last night for the first time. Although it was fun, play-time was too long. After a while people just wished the game would end. We had to stop before we even got to the real action. That was right after we took the first city, and there were still 3 more cities to conquer. So I guess I would not suggest playing this game with more than 2, if you want it to end sooner. But note that we were already tired when we started to play and the game had to be introduced to new players.

3/3/14: After a 3-player co-operative game that lasted about 8 hours (because we had extended the game by 2 rounds) in which we conquered 4 cities, all of us felt really exhausted. It was fun from the beginning to the mid-game. Then it became painful, but stil fun. I think I wouldn't play this scenario again, but I'd play a shorter one.

RATING: 7
It is very easy to see the appeal of this game, real thought has been put into the components which are just delightful. They create an effect a lot like a turn based computer strategy game. The rule books are good, but not as good as the components (noticeable typos, and a separate scenario book would have really helped).
In the solitaire mode (it also plays co-operatively and competitively) you guide your warrior mage as they explore a map fighting monsters, recruiting armies, and looting spells. Accumulate fame as these are the basis of victory points - but do it quickly, you get points for time as well. 
Rule complexity will vary for players. I found them medium weight, but I come from a hex-wargaming/role-playing background. If you are approaching from a light-medium Euro background you will probably find them a little intimidating. Most of them are fairly intuitive, and with some minor exceptions it is relatively easy to find the relevant section to check.

RATING: 8
I had very big expectations of this game when I first heard about it in early 2012 - I loved the sound of the mechanics, it's by one of my favourite designers, and I watched it shoot up the BGG rankings into the top 10. I managed to buy a copy in May 2012, but it has seen very little play - one 4-player game with my regular group, a couple of solo plays by me, all using just the introductory scenario, and a 2p co-op game with my wife. While no-one seemed to hate the game in that 4-player experience, no-one asked for another game, and I'm loath to suggest it as the game takes so long (and everyone would have forgotten all the rules by now, anyway). And, while I've enjoyed each game, I can't ever quite get away from the feeling that there are too many rules (particularly for all the different types of site), which get in the way of the experience a bit. Of course, it's great seeing your character get more and more powerful over the course of the game. 

So while I want to love this game, in practice I can't quite bring myself to - and I will almost never get to play. It's definitely a great game, but I do fear that it perhaps attempts to do too much. That doesn't stop me wanting to play it.

RATING: N/A
+ Extremely deep game, some herald it as a modern Magic Realm. With some brief exposure to Magic Realm, I can say this is far more streamlined but will probably scratch the same itch
+ A big challenge even for players who love heavy thinking/analytical games
+ Ruleset is actually quite simple after a few plays
+ Chaotic neutral game, players can work together or against each other as they please (a pleasant change from pure cooperative games)

+/- Someone described it as "immersive, you'll spend a lot of your time immersing yourself in the rulebook". This is true, you will be referencing both rulebooks constantly even after having played a few times and I could see it being tedious for some. This game isn't for everyone but is very rewarding and engaging if you can get into it

- I can't imagine playing this game with anyone who hasn't played it before, the learning curve is very steep and introducing someone to the game would take multiple plays for them to get to the point where they can grasp the rules and appreciate the game, it requires a lot of patience
- Long, even for a solo game, this game can take 3 hours or more quite easily (not a major downside, but don't expect to succeed in under 90 minutes the first few times)

RATING: 7
For me, this is a good game that is let down a little by the lack of interaction between the players.

While you are all working towards a common goal - you are all working individually towards it. Early in the game, it is important to walk off in different directions. If you follow someone and don't get good movement cards - you run the risk of them getting all the level ups before you do. Once you get to the later parts of the board, lack of leveling will hurt you!

So while it is a 1-5 player game, I feel it plays much better as a 1-2 player game. Which is sad.

Good levelling mechanics though, and solid gameplay mechanics.

RATING: 10
I love this game. It is the perfect solo game. For me at least. A tough, thinky game in which the goal is to beat the game rather than beat your highest score. (I hate those.) The nice thing is, it’s hard but beatable if you can just figure out how to play each turn as optimally as possible to achieve your objective. And the nice thing is, every game is different due to the random map tiles and monsters. And all the different characters you can play are different and have a different combat focus. And who doesn’t love leveling up and becoming more powerful as the game progresses.

The one knock I have against this fantastic game is the long setup time. So many different decks of cards, types of map tiles, and stacks of monster tokens to shuffle. If it wasn’t such a massive pain to set up, I would have 10 times as many plays as I currently do. I want to play it all the time, I just can’t be bothered to do all that shuffling.

RATING: 8
[b]Learning Curve[/b]
Woah!  Took me 3-4 days of reading through the Game Play-through guide just to play the tutorial run-through.  Once I understood what was going on, the game play was fun.  There's just a lot to process.  I really like that they have a walk-through guide in addition to the rulebook.  It really helps and makes it a lot less daunting.  Plus, you can follow along with it as you learn.

[b]Components[/b]
The components are good and the insert is really nice.  Everything fits perfectly.  No idea how I will fit the expansions in though.  Will likely need a new insert. Also, if you sleeve your cards, they will not all fit in the insert, however there is space to put them under one of the insert trays which is where I keep my character decks. The only components I thought could be better were the crystals.  Their shape is cool but the plastic used to create them is crappy.  Compared to all the acrylic types of gems out there, these look super blah.  They are not shiny or transparent.

Wizkids seems to have frequent issues with their production runs.  I had to do a replacement for a piece I was missing in the base game, and also some parts that were incorrectly made in one of the expansions.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Once I got the rules down everything seemed to flow well.  Lots to think about and strategize.  I like how turn sequence is structured so that as one player finishes their stuff the next player starts.  Cuts down on AP issues.  

There are A LOT of rules and symbols to keep track of.  This can be intimidating for some.  Fortunately, there are player aids here on BGG and a reference sheet for download on the Wizkids website.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
My experience of this game is mixed. With several players, I have found it, so far, to be slow, painful multiplayer solitaire. On the other hand, it is probably the best game for solo play that I have ever encountered. At the same time the components are a massive let down. 

[b]Multiplayer[/b]: The first game certainly dragged; including rules explanations, we (four players) managed to complete four turns (i.e. two days, two nights) in almost six hours. Maybe it wasn't such a good idea to skip the walkthrough scenario into the main game. . . Learning this game is a complete pain, and in general Mage Knight should be avoided with four players, at least at the beginning. The second game took about five hours including set up, but with three players we did get through three days (i.e. six turns); none the less, we still spent a lot of time thinking about our cards, looking at the board, looking back at our cards etc. The third game was with four, and that took about seven hours. There is much militating against it as a multiplayer game: There seems to be little means of catching up with a player in the lead. Bad mistakes can cost dearly, and it is difficult to come back from them.

[b]Solitaire[/b]: Here, the game really shines. It's fun to watch your mage knight increase in power, to explore the different capabilities of the characters and learn about the interactions of the cards. With several players, I felt as if I was playing on my own anyway, so it's great to be able to cut out all that waiting around. For me, it's perhaps the perfect solitaire game: the challenge is not created by random card draws throwing up problems which you have to deal with; rather, you have a situation (not fully known to you) that you have to puzzle out to find the best way of using your resources to exploit it. 

[b]Components[/b]: I have the second printing,which has absolutely awful components: cards curled like pringles, territory tiles with damaged backs, counters printed on the wrong sides. It would require getting almost the entire game again to replace the sup-par components. How this, especially the misshapen cards, will work with the expansion is anyone's guess.

[b]Summmary:[/b] Basically, it's worth getting the game for solitaire play alone. I don't think I'd want to teach anybody the game, but I'd be happy to play it with experienced players. If you are worried about components, wait until they actually manage to publish a decent edition.

RATING: 5
Despite the large amount of rules and down time this game has a few fundamental issues down to its core. After a hand full of plays I have learned a few things:

1. Movement is difficult. In a larger game especially if the other players explore in a different direction and find something worth exploring too bad for you, you'll never make it in time (if at all). 

2. The player who takes the lead doesn't lose the lead. If someone gain a couple fast levels they are able to defeat the stronger monsters everyone else leaves behind because they are unable to fight them yet, thus pulling further ahead. 

3. Depending on the scenario scoring is superfluous. Unless the game is very close the players who already have fame remain in the lead. Scoring is based on what you have done in the game and the person who has the most fame has done the most resulting in them getting more fame and just winning by a larger margin. 

Maybe I haven't played it enough yet to "get it" but for now I think I need a break.

RATING: 9
This is one of my favourite games, and for me one of the few that is both interesting and entertaining enough to enjoy solo.  An RPG game for lack of a better category, yet not featuring/requiring much roleplaying.  This is a game in which you begin feeling rather weak, struggling to puzzle out how to move two spaces and vanquish a small pack of goblins with the cards you've drawn, and end the game (hopefully) staring deep into your large hand of cards, searching for the way to optimally defeat multiple formidable enemies and seize control of entire cities.  There is a real sense of progression there, but from the first turn to the last, you will be working on a puzzle.  For some people, this isn't what they enjoy, or expect from a game labeled an RPG, but for me and many others, it's an incredibly fun and rewarding experience.

The potential pitfalls here have to be acknowledged.  The game is usually incredibly long, particularly with players who like to evaluate several or all possibilities before making a move.  There can also be a "runaway leader" issue; if you have a few very successful turns in a row, and an opponent has one or two dud turns around the same time, the difference in your resulting positions can be massive.  Furthermore, the more successful you are, the easier it gets to continue to succeed, so usually nothing is stopping you from accelerating further and further into the lead.  Some people are fine with this and don't consider it a problem; this is a pretty low-luck game, too, so you might say the better player is winning and be satisfied.  Many people might not enjoy it though, and while those people often would opt to concede and ask to start another game, Mage Knight just isn't the sort of game that the winner will want to cut short, because the payoffs keep getting more satisfying as long as you are doing well.  Variants, which I haven't tried, apparently do address this issue.

Finally, though the "deckbuilding" aspect of this game is perfect for what it is, Mage Knight doesn't scratch the deckbuilding itch for me at all, and I don't think it will for most people; you play through your deck once each round, and you don't add or remove cards all that often.

Sorry Vladaa. Posters on this forum were rude enough to make me never want to play the game again.

I think there is just not enough deck control early in the game and going last can totally wreck your game.

Add to that the slow nature of movement. What does this really add to the game other than longer playtime? So, I move four two hexes, redraw my hand, and wait 30 minutes for my next turn.

Does this add anything meaningful to the game? What does it intend to abstract? Thematically the game takes place over 3 days and 3 nights. Are these biblical days and nights?

I think you could half movement costs and lose nothing but playtime and downtime. 

This is tough in a game that can easily last six hours.

Mixed feelings here. The game is beautiful, long, thematic, has lots of interesting mechanisms and requires as much thinking as at least a medium euro so it should therefore appeal to me. Sadly, it's a bit too random, bad hands can lead to turns where you can't do anything much, and being crippled early forfeits your chances for accomplishing much later on. If you don't have a constant partner I strongly advise you to try before buying. Still, I'll gladly sit down to it again, given time and an occasion.

RATING: 10
I enjoyed my one play of this, which was a 2player game, the other player helping me along with learning the rules as I went. The biggest turn off for me is that you only cycle through your deck a couple of times. It feels as though this would be a game that you'd get most out of solo, whilst yearning to have the multi-player experience with an equally matched opponent. Implements some ideas from Magic Realm well, and compared to that at least the rules are comprehendable, but I don't think this replaces its predecessor (nor indeed was it intended to, I'm sure).
2014 Edit: Now, I own the game, have got more plays in and am liking MK more and more. It is one of those games that really sticks in your mind after play (or during if you leave a solo game set up) - thinking about different ways it could play out. A surprisingly wide scope of ways to play, both from the subtle variation of scenarios and the very different approaches that can be taken during the game. The degree of determinism in the design  fascinates me for some reason. I've particularly enjoyed multi-player, which can get long, although certainly afternoon-able when playing Blitz. I'm much less concerned about the limited cycling, which only becomes another strategic factor to consider when making card purchases - but essentially with MK, the 'deck-building' label doesn't really fit: for me, a deck-builder needs to have deck-thinning and cycling as more significant considerations in play.

In multi-player, there is too much down time between players and the game drags on too long (our first game took seven hours with just two players). I can't comment on solo - it might be much better time-wise - but since I don't play solo (typically) this is a moot point for me.

Also, I was surprised by just how much the game was un-thematic (relatively speaking).  I think this is due to the fact that the scenarios were rather bland in their ordinariness (i.e. conquer three cities) so there wasn't much of a narrative arc (i.e. what is my character even attempting to achieve?). Also, the art/graphics were plain (i.e. enemies were just tokens with poor design layout) and that you are limited to a single miniature (in a solo game) where additionally miniatures would have drawn you in more (even if there still little in way of a narrative).

Lastly, the rules was needlessly finicky and the rulebook was poorly laid out (some rules were in the walkthrough, some in the main rulebook, and some on the cards - and each had information the other didn't!)

Aside from my complaints, I do admit the deck building aspect was fascinating, each card had multiple uses so I always had options, the night and day mechanic added an extra flavor, and the walkthrough was a great way to learn the game.

However, the game is simply too long, too finicky, and not thematic enough to warrant the effort of the play time and the complicated rules.

RATING: 9
An incredibly fun game with a lot of moving parts.  Components are a bit erratic in quality (i.e. colour quality) especially mixed with expansion.  Cards are great however.  You'll need a lot of table space to play.  The criticism that MK is a bit luck dependent is valid BUT I argue that lowering the difficulty a bit fixes that.

The best part of MK is the sheer flexibility of the game systems to adapt to whatever difficulty level you want, number of players, time to play etc..  Want a casual competitive scenario for couple of hours?  Or a epically long, cooperative one, without a dummy player pressure clock?  No problem, you can do it.

The inclusion of a detailed walkthrough, learning scenario is excellent.  It really smooths out the learning curve.

Finally, I think the expansion is almost required to complete the experience.

Fun, period.

RATING: 9
Mage Knight is a great adventure game. There is some randomness in which tiles flip up, which cards you draw, and which enemies are placed. A large element of this game is figuring out how to get things done with the available resources. Each turn is a puzzle to solve, but there are often many possible solutions, so optimizing turns can be challenging. There is an enormous amount of strategy.

This game takes up a lot of table space, and is fairly fiddly. There are many rules, and it is easy to forget the details. 

On the other hand, this is one of the best solo games I've played.

RATING: 10
Perfection
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Mage Knight is generally lauded as the return of the gamer's game that takes no prisoners. I'm all for HARDCORE games, but this one felt like complexity for complexity's sake, like Chvatil just threw everything in there without any editorial restraint from the publisher. Also lacks any cool/awesome/original ideas to justify the complexity, like Dungeon Lords, Trucker, Space Alert and Through the Ages all had. Just layer upon layer of complicated, disparate text abilities and rules to keep track of, plus seemingly endless combinations of options for your turn. It makes the game unplayable with more players, another sad trait shared by Through the Ages (best with 2, unplayable with 4, solely because of a lack of oversight in streamlining the decision process).

3 kinds of cards you can put into your deck, all with slightly different ways to use them, and all with complicated text. Units you can drag around to fight with, that you have to recruit at different types of places. 4 types of buildings and 4 types of adventure sites to keep track of. You get skill tokens as you go along, which are interpreted by reading a player aid with small text, and you may pick up your opponent's eventually, and read [i]their[/i] tiny player aid. Combat is reduced to an accountant's wet dream: interpret a few icons which permute all the halving of all the stats possible, and play  cards to match a bunch of numbers, while ensuring the keywords are a match. I want to walk around and smell the roses, not think to myself, "Put my left food forward, put my right foot forward, now raise hand. Can I reach there this turn? Calculating...". Not even the turn order is safe from all this piling on: instead of a simple and sweet fixed turn order or simple variable turn order procedure, players have to draft complicated abilities alongside their turn order for no reason other than "PHWOAR, MORE COMPLEXITY". Pages upon pages of optional rules.

The game is so weighed down, that it actually works well for solo play, where you have unlimited time to tackle an ocean of complexity. But it is also backhanded praise, especially since the advent of video games, to say that a board game plays best with one.

I'm usually one-and-done with Chvatil games, which usually have one or two cool ideas completely buried under a pile of unnecessary cosmetic rules (while this one doesn't even have that spark). [-]But this one I'll give a couple more chances since I do like the theme, I own the damn thing, and I already sleeved the damn thing: 200+ cards with thin/bent cardstock.[/-]

Wonder if people like this so much because to appear overwhelmed by complexity is to sound weak. There is nothing wrong in calling out Chvatil's lack of restraint in any of his designs. We should laud decision complexity, not "how many rules can I fit in this game and see BGG users drool over it and yell 'HARDCORE!'?"

This Ameritrasher says MK is a total wannabe, a Euro-in-AT clothing that panders to the Eurosnobs who think they're enjoying some authentic experience whilst sipping on their glasses of wine, whereas Chaos in the Old World is the true steel, the best Euro-AT hybrid ever made.

2+1

RATING: 7
Hated the first training session short game, way way too much randomness.

After playing an actual longer scenario, I don't hate the game anymore, but don't love it either. The followers you are able to hire later and spells/ artifacts/ advanced abilities you get from conquering certain things and leveling up help counter the large amount of randomness that otherwise dominates the game.
Still I would relate the game to a long and complicated version of 7 Wonders, not in game mechanics or theme, but tactics. You cant necessarily have a strategy to start with, nor can you even stick with a certain strategy you have been using through half of the game. Its more about doing the best with what options come available to you. The winner will be based somewhat on that, and somewhat on luck. Seems a bit long of a game for that level of randomness to me, but still fun. I would play again but probably not regularly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Update (May, 2016):  This is such a hard game to rate.  After playing it a few times right after purchase, it lamented on my shelf for 2 years.  I just recently pulled it out, had to relearn the systems, and played 2 monster solo-games back-to-back.  30 min into the first game, I was all like, "This game is terrible.  Why did I ever rate this so highly?  I'm rulechecking every 5 minutes and it's driving me crazy."  But I persisted.  Ended up maybe winning the first game, if it wasn't for a couple rules infractions (see?).  Decided to load up a 2nd one right away, and i'm glad I did.  IF you have the rules fresh in your head, this game is an amazing solo experience.  So much crunchy decision-making, so much emergent narrative.  Every game different.  I love it.  I just wish I didn't feel like I've never played a "perfect" game (in terms of not breaking any rules).

2013:  Sure, there are a lot of rules to remember, but it's actually not as fiddly as I imagined it would be (less so than Arkham Horror, in my mind).  Watching a play-through online before playing was essential.  I'm glad I purchased it.  My 2nd game took around 5 hours, including set-up, which I consider to be too long.  Maybe I can get this down to 3-4 hrs.   My two games were quite different, largely because of the randomized map and what it gives you.  Surprisingly, I won my first play and nearly won my second - and I don't think I'm getting any major rules wrong.  I "grok" the game and it suits me well - a real brain-burner, where the focus is on efficient use of turns and cards.  Haven't played anything else like it.

RATING: 4
Way too heavy for what it does. Looks like an adventure game, but is not. Takes very long and frankly, I do not think it has much reason to do so. There are not many major decisions and the minor decisions are puzzle solving. If you are into micro-managing puzzles, this is the game for you. If not, well - maybe not. 
My feeling is that something like this could be done with much simpler rules. Its more complicated than complex. Its certainly not elegant.

UPDATE: Played it again in June 2014 to test if its good as a solo game. Its still numbercrunching, its still a complicated puzzle, its still extremely fiddly and I still think that the same effect could be achieved by a much simpler design. Its just too much work and then too little result to make it worthwhile.

RATING: 9
This is still early days, but so far I am in love :).

Mage Knight is one of two games that absorb my attention so completely that I don't notice the passage of time at all (the other being High frontier). 

We are still busy working our way through the base game scenarios (currently as far as 'Mines Liberation'), and I find the game an excellent, strategic two player experience.

Will update this in detail as we play more.

Update: Still loving the depth, immersion and strategy that can be found in this game and will be purchasing the upcoming expansion as soon as it is available (though honestly, the game doesn't require it). We are still busy working our way through the basic scenarios after some 4 months, and each play still feels fresh and thematic. 

The beauty of the game lies in the fact that it has a fantasy theme which shines through, but lacks the randomness of Ameritrash games. Everything you do matters. Every hand can be used to further your position (albeit not always in the way you wanted it to). Best of all, despite the games complexity, having learnt it, Mage Knight becomes almost entirely intuitive in terms of keeping track of rules whilst playing.

Update 2: With the expansion this game has managed something extraordinary - it got better! The fact that the co-operative scenarios against Volkare are so enjoyable to me (as someone who usually hates co-op) just adds to the value of this game. We usually play the game co-operatively and tend to ignore end scoring now in scenarios where the objective is to "clear out all the mines" or dungeons or whatever the case may be. Succeed at the mission and its a win for all concerned.

RATING: 8
I'd probably rate this higher if it weren't for 2 things:

1) It takes a long time to play.  While it's not "tedious" long, it's a bit too long to fit easily into a busy schedule, and so it doesn't see as much play.

2) While I appreciate Vlaada's efforts in the storyline, it just doesn't feel like "Mage Knight" to me, based on the original minis game.  Rather, it's more like "a game loosely based on Mage Knight".

The gameplay is fun, though, and definitely very tight.  You have to manage your hand well to succeed in this game, something I've not quite mastered yet.

I'll admit, I don't like it nearly as much in multiplayer mode because unless the players are really evenly matched, the worse player is just going to fall behind early with really no chance of ever catching up, and the good player is just going to take all the juicy stuff along the way and leave the lesser player with the dregs.

RATING: 9
Initial rating after 1 full play and a solo walkthrough.  Excellent rpg-style boardgame with all the necessary bells and whistles.  The main innovation here is the use of your hand of cards to limit your actions for the turn.  Your deck size controls how long a day/night lasts.  Makes every turn a tense puzzle-like experience with some angst as if you don't cycle through your deck in the full turn, you may be left behind.

RATING: 9
Buying this purely for the solo really.  I can't imagine ever getting this to a table with other friends. I have an ex-RPG'er fantasy adventure itch that needs scratching and this looks like a good option.

Very positive impressions after 2 training games. Hard, but not clunky. Quite a few rules lookups at first but the system makes sense.

The 'game timer' seems really short - I feel like I'm having to sprint around to complete the game in the alloted time, rather than explore fully. Perhaps a 'Solo Conquest' game with 6 rounds will be different.

Edit after four games... I'm giving this a 9.  I love it. The only thing stopping it getting a 10 is the slight anti-climax when you fail to win.  You have 1 or 2 turns left to take the final city... and you look at your spent skills and units and useless cards and think 'there's just no way I can win'.  It's a real balance between moving fast enough to reach the cities in time, and gaining enough 'stuff' to actually win when you get there!

RATING: 8.5
A beautiful scenario-based RPG in a box! I am impressed with how this game challenges you to squeeze every bit of utility out of your deck. Vlaada Chvátil thought of seemingly everything: a "clock" to ensure the speed of solo play, a huge variety of combat mechanics, different ways to build strength, etc.

I've only played the game solo thus far. I doubt I will ever play it multiplayer, which is fine with me, as I only got the game for solo play. I'm interesting in trying out the Lost Legion expansion after a few more plays of the base game.

RATING: 8
This is a classic Vlaada game. Play it, check rulebook for any mistakes you made, play it again, check the rulebook again, play it, check FAQ, play it etc. For some reason I find Vlaada Chvatil's games to be the most difficult to internalise the rules for. There's a high barrier of entry, making it difficult to bring new players to the table. 

I still have to give credit where it's due, and there's a lot of credit due here. The game is full of clever ideas, there's so much content you will have to play it a lot to even begin to grasp the tactics, the experience is always memorable. I just wish it didn't come at the cost of rules obfuscation.

[2013-02-09]
Olyan semleges várakozással ültem le ahhoz a játékhoz, ami egy év alatt beverekedte magát a top tízbe. Nem vártam se sokat, se keveset. Nagyon kellemes meglepetés a játék. Teljesen érthető a nagy rajongás iránta. 4 fajta kalandozó van, akiknek egy kivételével teljesen ugyanolyan 16 kezdőpaklija van. Ezzel tudunk mindent csinálni a játék során. Lépünk, harcolunk, befolyást szerzünk, varázsolunk. Ezen túl abban különböznek a varázslóink, hogy szintlépéssekkor különböző tulajdonságokkal fognak rendelkezni. Pont jó a különbözőség-hasonlóság mértéke véleményem szerint. Thunderstone szerű a lapmenedzselés. 5 lapból kell valamit alkotnunk a körünkben, de nem vészes a pakliépítés része, mert bővülni a kártyáink csak szintlépéskor, illetve adott helyen való lapvásárlással tudnak. Nekem ez is pontosan megfelelő mértékű. Kezelhető. Jó a harcrendszer, jó a manaszerzés és használat lehetősége. Minden kártyának van egy alaptulajdonsága, adott színű mana felhasználásával pedig egy erősebb. Nem éreztem nagy szerencsefaktort sem, mert nem lesz óriási a paklink a játék során így mindig tudunk valamit csinálni a körünkben. Érdekes a felfedezés is, a sok különböző szörny és épület. Valahogy megint sikerült a cseh szerzőnek jól eltalálnia minden mértéket. Nagyon tetszett a Mage Knight, eddigi legjobb játék, amit az ilyen típusú fantasy játékok közül láttam. Egy negatívumot találtam elsőre a nagy holtidőt és sajnos amíg másik játékos lép szerintem keveset lehet előre gondolkozni, mert cselekvésétől és a körönként egy közös manahasználat miatt nem mindegy milyen lehetőség marad nekünk és aszerint kell terveznünk. Tehát tényleg ketten lehet a legjobb és négyen már nagyon hosszúra nyúlhat. Nagyon erős 8-as.

RATING: 8
Mage Knight may be the most complex game I own, but it's simply amazing. The card play and customization is so satisfying. The production, despite some small issues, is also very good. This is the closest I've seen anyone come to replicating a video game RPG in board game form. There are a few things that hold it back from perfection for me: 1) It's really long. I think my first play was 8 hours and that was solo. I can finish a game quicker now, but it's still a good 3 hours. I can't even imagine a four-player game of this. 2) There isn't much variety in terms of scenarios. They are all pretty much the same thing and there are few that I find engaging or interesting. 3) It's a lot to setup and it takes up a lot of table space. It takes some time to get this game ready and I normally prefer to start playing as quickly as possible. Still, this is an excellent design and one of my favorite "heavy" games.

RATING: 9

RATING: 8.1
Just played the learning walkthrough and then one full solo game. Took WAY too long. The rules are pretty bad. I mean, conceptually they're good, but you shouldn't have to look in either the rulebook, the walkthrough, or the dozen player aid cards to find which blinking rule you need. (If you find it even then. Too many trips to BGG or the FAQ.). I've seen fans defend the rules, but they're fans, which is to say fanatics. I did download a 2-page player aid that helped a lot, but it only went so far. Harumph.

Thematically it's a puzzle, not an adventure game. The theme came through medium ok. There were monsters. There were cities and tombs etc etc. But... The cards are pretty cool, both units and spells, they're the best thing thematically. The world is generic. Terrain has no special names and cities are called Red City and White City etc. The heroes you pick have names and backstories but they're very cliche backstories. So B- on theme. 

The game, however, ah, the game. THAT was fun. I'm not a super puzzle guy, or maybe I am. In my early turns the puzzles were simple. As your Mage Knight gets more powerful (better cards and skills) the tricks and combos you can pull are pretty cool, and the puzzles get harder. My final battle in my solo game took a LOT of thought but was great when I pulled it off. (Assuming I did. I'm hoping I didn't make any rules mistakes. I feel a little nervous that I won my first solo game, albeit on a low difficulty level and only on the last possible turn.)

So an 8 right now. It's clearly going to be a beast to get to the table but I'm intrigued by the challenge of it. There's also a lot of variety with various extra scenarios and the expansions.

RATING: 8
I like the fact that while I play this game I don't have to maintain a player card with all my stats displayed.  Your hand of cards are your stats.  But there is still plenty of stuff, cards, counters, dice, chits, score tracks etc. sitting around the playing area.  This is a pretty elegant game, yet still is cluttered.  I think the game world has maxed out on the managed-depth-to-clutter ratio.   Until game components start to appear with embedded microprocessors and neat little digital displays that change to show current stats, this is the limit.   Nevertheless, this is an excellent game.  I've enjoyed it very much.  Combat is abstracted in such a way that each battle is presented to the player as an individual puzzle requiring a judicious combination of card plays to ensure that multiple features can be activated, usually optimized by a distinct linear timing sequence which is critical.  Very clever.  Not quite the "blow by blow" experience of Magic Realm that creates a visceral sense of immediate peril, but this is close.  Much more engaging during combat than, say, Runebound. 
- I've played 7 or 8 solo games so far.  It is definitely a "self improvement" sport.  With every game you get a little better, get a little farther and have a little more fun.  It makes you want to play more.   I think it would be a good two-player game, as well.  But I can see how three or four players could drag the game endlessly.  I cannot endure a game where I sit for 10-15 minutes between turns.  
(Note: I downgraded the game from a 9.0 because of several recent games in which the card draws were so very bad in terms of not providing even basic movement cards in multiple, subsequent turns, requiring sideways cards that just make no sense thematically.   The luck of the draw can definitely put a sour taste in the mouth.  I know the game is about playing the hand you're dealt but c'mon.)

RATING: 10
Truly the adventure game we have all been wanting all our lives. Know that if you play with more than, well...yourself...it's gonna be a long one. But really folks, it is so filled with depth, and exploration, and gaming goodness that it is totally worth the time. But it's best with 2 or 3 max, in my opinion. For solo play, its my absolute favorite. 

I have to say, when you have a bunch of units, spells, advanced action cards,etc. and you're attacking three or so foes - it gets really complicated, really quick. There are so many undulations of the battle system, and so many ways you can manipulate your cards to fight, that it becomes very much a trial and error puzzle - and that can make players turns reaaaaaaallllly long. This, in my opinion - and I hate to say this - is a design flaw for sure. Don't get me wrong though - I absolutely love this game to death (its a ten...) but, the system of battle should really be tweaked so that it doesn't turn into a big logic puzzle that takes so long to figure out. Im not sayin' you should just throw some dice - I like the system - but it needs a serious streamlining and an elegance check. I mean, I would love to play this game with 4 - but as is - no way will I be doing that again.

RATING: 8
Pros
- Puzzle-y mechanics through hand management are SO much fun
- The slight deckbuilding mechanics make you really feel like you are getting stronger as you play
- Good replayability due to variability of characters, cards, and randomized options that show up on the board

Cons
- The rules in this game are needlessly complex to the point of absurdity. It took me hours of watching videos, reading rules, and mock games to feel like I understood how to play. It is the opposite of "elegant."
- Playing with any more than 2 people and I imagine the down time between turns would be excruciating.
- Setup and game length cause this game to get to the table much less often than I'd like

I really enjoy this game when I want a really think, crunchy game. Rules complexity, setup time, and game length are unnecessary barriers to entry here, but once you get past those this is a fantastic game that is fun to play from beginning to end.

RATING: 10
Holy crap, this is a monster of a game and somehow still all the elements are so well designed and the game is kept interesting and loads of fun.

The game is a weird amalgam of a deck-building game and a fantasy adventure game with about a million other elements mixed in to the most elegant well-designed game system I've ever seen.  Make no mistake, trying to understand the rules yourself, let alone trying to explain them to others who have the patience to learn and understand those rules is a chore but one that is well worth it.

The game is a decent length (probably about an hour per player give or take depending on the scenario and the players) and very complicated and requires keeping a lot of balls in the air to play but I don't think there is a single element that I'm not a fan of.  The only downside to the game is that because of its length and complexity the opportunities to play it aren't as many as I would like.  The balance and increasing power levels of the basic and advanced actions, spells, and artifacts and the ability to use any card as one of four basic effects provides a wealth of strategic options and variety each turn.  The magic system is unique and balanced.  The spacial and time (day/night rounds) system adds another delicious layer to the game.  The monsters are varied and balanced against the increasing power of your heroes.  The leveling system is deep and also unique (especially the ability to take skills from your opponent).  The wound system is punishing without being crippling.  And most of all it is engrossing, thematic, and fun, fun, fun!

I am thoroughly impressed with what Chvatil was able to accomplish here.  I've seen games not 1/100th the complexity of Mage Knight unable to properly balance and blend two mechanics let alone the machination he was able to create here that does it all to absolute perfection without feeling like a chore.  Quite the contrary, one of my new favorite games!

I will say though that the rushed components really pissed me off.  Because of how much I love this game I would have loved it if it looked nice.  The enemy tokens are all horribly printed/cut to where some actually have vital information obscured.  Some of the cards are the same way and are also oddly sized so it is difficult to sleeve them well.

RATING: 7
What I've found interesting about Mage Knight is that it shouldn't feel as immersive and thematic as it does--it's a brutal optimization puzzle from the get-go when played solo. But it feels like I'm in for such a long haul, such an uphill fight as I look down at all those tokens and cards and think and think and think on each turn, that I start to feel like a war-weary knight in a world that wants to kill me, so it winds up being strangely absorbing. In the end, I'm not convinced the decision to marry a voluminous rules set with gameplay so tight that slight fuzziness in rules knowledge can have such harsh effects is great game design. When something demands this much methodical calculation and logic and mastery of all your options, I feel the rules should be greatly slimmed down; as Mage Knight stands, it's just crazy cognitive overload of a kind I kind abide. But obviously there are other people who can handle it all quite well.

RATING: 9.5
Mage Knight is remarkably good for solo play; it doesn't feel all that different from multiplayer (probably because there's not a whole lot of interaction unless you use player-vs-player combat, which I haven't done yet.)

Each turn seems like its own little puzzle of how best to use your cards; can you manage to move over to there AND defeat that enemy?  However, if you focus on the puzzle aspect and just concentrate on maximizing each turn, you'll neglect the higher-level planning and fall behind.  Likewise, if you concentrate on playing "perfectly" and avoid ever getting wounded, you'll also fall behind.  Wounds are something to take when necessary and work around, not something to avoid at all costs.

One BGG member explained that Mage Knight provides randomization of [i]opportunity[/i], not (usually) of [i]outcome[/i].  So you don't know what you're going to draw for your next turn, or what monsters are waiting at the next altar.  But once you see them, you can plan out and fight them with no uncertainty (except in the case of a summoner).

I also appreciate that there are any number of viable builds for your hero, which are partially guided but not limited by your unique action and your skills; also by what actions and spells come up and what you have the chance to buy.  I've played several solo games and never had the same kind of character by the end.

Reading the comments for the low ratings, I actually agree with a lot of them.  Horrible rulebook?  Check.  Forcing click-miniatures in when they don't need to be there?  Check.  Lots of downtime?  Mostly check; this shouldn't really be played with four, or even three if they're newbs.

Then there are those who complain about it being too random.  I don't understand that.  Just about everything you do in the game is deterministic.  But as I said above, the opportunities are randomized.  I guess that's not for everyone.  I suspect that if I play this with my Ameritrash-loving friends, they'll complain that it's not random enough!  EDIT: And indeed they do!

RATING: 9.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Deckbuilding adventure game where each player controls a questing Mage Knight, wandering around the map looting tombs, recruiting followers, burning down monasteries and so forth. Card play is complex: each hand-card has six abilities, a normal one and a stronger effect that requires an additional payment (usually mana, but in the case of artifacts, permanent loss of the card), and the possibility to be played for a single point in any of the key "currencies": movement, influence, attack, block.

The deckbuilding does provide a very clever character development mechanism -- levelling up or acquiring new equipment provides superior cards -- but on its own it is a fairly weak implementation. (Card cycling is too infrequent for new hand cards to provide the same degree of accelerating improvement as in Dominion et al.) That is not a criticism per se, because deckbuilding is only one part of a player's engine. Recruited units are kept face up and can be used once per round; likewise, character skills acquired when levelling up can be used either once a round or once a turn. Mana crystals can be kept and used to power spells. Players also draft "tactics" cards, which in addition to setting turn order also provide special abilities. The combination of all of these game elements makes for an exceedingly rich hand- and resource-management experience.

As might be surmised, movement points are required to move: 2 points per plains, 3 per hill, 5 per swamp etc. It's [i]expensive[/i]. Moving to, or in some cases adjacent to, a special location allows the character to interact there. Block points are needed to avoid taking damage in combat with monsters, attack points to kill them, and influence points to recruit followers. Managing resources such that it is possible to both move to a desired location and do something useful is a complex optimization puzzle.

Thanks to the luck of the cards, it's sometimes an optimization puzzle that can't be solved for the result you want; at a strategic level, the game is about building an engine and moving around such that opportunities for success are maximized. Early plays are far more likely to have useless and frustrating "I can't move anywhere!" turns.

Unfortunately, the puzzle is also a largely solitary one, though other players are useful both provide time pressure and some direct interaction through PvP. Frequently, though, you will have very little interest in what other players are up to.

(It hardly bears mentioning, but as with similar games in this genre, theme is only there if you squint; it's not one to play for the story. Get an RPG.)

I'm just not convinced. Mage Knight asks some difficult questions, but not terribly interesting ones, and it asks them over a long, fiddly, themeless session.

RATING: 6
The rulebook for this game might be the worst one I have ever read. Rules are spread out, and randomly placed in one of the two "rule books". I had seriously a much harder time understanding the simple rules in mage knight than the complex rules in "The rublic of rome" which has a 50 page long rulebook. 
Once you have an understanding of the relative simple rules in this game it is a fun game, but suffers from a "snowball" effect. If you do not have a good start you may never come back into the game because the other players take all the loot. 
I once had a game where I got last pick on starting positions, and started out last of 4 players. The other players moved out and basically blocked me in such a way that I could not get any experience on my hero on the first turn (and I could not even take a double turn to secure something). At the start of my second turn the other players had once again taken the experience I could have taken. From that point (at the start of the second turn) it was clear that I could never win this game because of the snowball effect.

A fun game for non competative play, and a seriously flawed game for competative play.

RATING: 10
Amazing game with a ton of depth, strategy, and replay value. It takes a bit of time to learn, but it's not nearly as difficult to get into as I've heard a lot of reviewers say. It's a very deep and rewarding play experience - think of it as a self-contained RPG that you can start and finish within 2-4 hours, depending on the scenario and how much time you take with your turns (I've only played it solo so far). Follow the walkthrough scenario and take it slow with the first few games; after that, everything will come as second nature and the play experience will be smooth and deeply engaging.
