RATING: 8.4
Amazing solitaire game if you have a some hours to learn and some more to play. Great replayability and ajustable difficulty.

Multiplayer can take a long time, specially for more than 2 people. That's a pity since is in the competitive modality where the game shines in all its esplendor. However, solitaire mode is still great.

***********

After some time;

This game gets better when you invest more time in it. The game is great as solitaire (specially if you add the expansion), but it is better as competitive, specially with 2 players.

As competitive, it has some design problems (AP, downtime, unpayable with different skilled people); if played with more than 2, it has more problems (one player can easily get behind, with any chance to do anything; few interaction; luck factor in the first 10 minutes determining the fate of the game...). However, it also provides much more to the game. It gives more dynamism, it makes you reconsider you strategy every turn.

For me, the game is better as 2 players: in that case, downtime and AP is minimized. The game interaction is maximal. And if one player gets too strong, the other can resign and start another game.

For me it isn't a masterpiece. It really has some important problems. However, it's a nice game to play, very original and fun.

RATING: 8
The rules may seem daunting, but the rule book is very well laid out and understanding Mage Knight seems to be mostly about retaining a lot of data (and of course the pertinent exceptions) more than anything being unclear or hard to comprehend, though the combat is cluttered and my least favorite thing about the game.  The variables in each turn are cool and the limited progress on the board and the acknowledgement of terrains and time of day give nice sense of scope. At it worst, which is the combat part, this game has the same problem of playing a high level character in an RPG: too much time dealing with modifiers and not enough time in the world making character-driven decisions.
Yet ideas like wounds limiting a player's options (hand size) and resurfacing if not properly tended (in the next round in a new deck) and the alteration of day and night and the handling of the units are all very good conceits, as is the ability to explore certain sites deeper or chose to forego such explorations while sticking to a different agendum.
Mage Knight is not as good as my favorite game, which is Cave Evil by a significant margin, but I appreciate the well conceived solo mode of this thing. Grand, patient fantasy from Vlaada Chvátil when things aren't getting too bogged down with modifier accounting.

RATING: 7
Actual rating is a split 5/8. In an optimal configuration, on its best day, it's an 8. And even that is padded with a bonus for cleverness. On its worst day, or foolishly with four players, it can sink to a 5. After four plays, I've yet to witness the game overcome its base fantasy-themed puzzle nature. For all the detail and "theme", it has a surprising lack of emotional engagement or narrative element. Tension doesn't build, or careen about like a rollercoaster. You're plodding through a fantasy world wearing an Amulet of Angst.

What rescues the game is that the card-driven engine is clever, the several ways in which your character powers up provides for satisfying growth, and the card play itself is frequently (though not always) interesting.

Ouch.

RATING: 8
This is a gamer's game. It has some of the most exhausting game-play of any board game out there. After a game of Mage Knight, I feel like I am in need of nice rest and a cold drink. While this game completely wears me out, I absolutely adore it.

It takes quite a lot of time and table space, but trudging through a game of Mage Knight is one of the most rewarding experiences I have come across in gaming. No other game has given me the sense of progress like Mage Knight has. Watching the decisions you make start to shape your experience and turn your fledgling adventurer into an all-out force of nature is just so satisfying. 

I drop Mage Knights score to an 8 for a few reasons. The first reason is the length of time required to play. This game can take over 3 hours for just a solo game. Adding more players only increases this exponentially. The second reason is the sheer weight of the rules. Nothing about Mage Knight is intuitive. I mean, the game has 2 rule books! Granted, the rule books are split nicely for sort of an intro to the game and the full rules, but it still may require flipping through both books to get through a game. 

Having said all of that, I feel like this game would not be possible without the insane amount of litigation and time required to get through it. I think that is precisely why I enjoy it. It is a crunchy, mind-bending experience that will truly test your endurance.

RATING: 8
I'm giving this a 10 based on sheer ingenuity.  That being said, most people will not be attracted to this title because it has, by far, the highest learning curve of any board game I've ever seen.  I spent about a week learning this game (not exaggerating).  There is so much to absorb that, along with a 20 page rule book, it comes with another 20 page book that takes you through a game walk through.  You definitely want to do the walk through before attempting a game on your own.  

The beauty of this game, though, is that it's an outstanding single-player game.  This amazing and epic world unravels as you explore all that it has to offer.  There is no set path to follow.  Your options seem almost limitless.  

You come across villages, where you can recruit units to help you in your battles or you can receive healing from battle injuries or you can choose to be a bad guy and plunder the village, helping your immediate needs but hurting your reputation.

Throughout this mystical land, you'll also encounter a variety of rampaging monsters, or dungeon adventures, or ruins, or keeps, or monasteries, or mage towers, or many other sites that offer a variety of choices that help you build fame and treasures and new spells along the way.

Also, the map expands as you explore, each tile offering unique challenges.  Then after you have built up your army and learned all the spells and acquired all the powerful artifacts that you could, you assault the city gates and attempt to be victorious by overthrowing the powerful cities and their powerful defenders.

I've only began to touch on all the cool things this game has to offer.  It is truly an epic adventure, that requires a little luck and great deal of skill and strategy.  There are no dice for determining battles.  It's all about figuring out the best way to play your hand and build your deck and make use of the available crystals, which strengthen your cards.  Play it alone or cooperatively with some friends or competitively with friends.  There are a whole slew of scenarios to satisfy each type of challenge.

If you don't mind (or even enjoy, like I do) taking a lot of time to learn a game, then your investment will be well paid off.  Outstanding adventure game!

Update - 3/25/14 - Downgrading my rating to an 8 due to game length.  Played a 3 player game and only completed half the game in 5 hours.  The other two players did not enjoy it enough to try it again.  Still a very strong single-player title but the multi-player version has not been well received.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Probably not as bad as I'm rating it.  My issue was the "end of round" mechanic which requires you to forfeit your turn when you end the round, and your opponents each get one more turn.  I was the last player to play, but also the first player through my cards.  So by ending the round my opponents essentially got two extra turns then I did.  The scenario we played was supposed to last 3 turns, but could potentially last only 2.  It only lasted two and triggered by the player before locating a city.  Essentially that meant every player got one last turn, including the player who found the city.  Again being the last player it essentially allowed my opponents one more turn then me yet again.  All in all I think our two rounds only lasted like 4 or 5 turns each, and in this time frame I received 3 less turns then my opponents.  It seemed like a poor mechanic to essentially lose that many turns in comparison to my opponents.  Again, the game is probably better then I'm rating it, but that mechanic soured me on my first play.

RATING: 10
This game is a 10 out of 10, ANYDAY!! 

It's a very complex game & you may get discouraged trying to understand everything at first. But, I think if you give it the time, it will be very rewarding.

The different scenarios all play very well, I personally enjoy the conquest ones the best. Your entire game (in the conquest scenario) is comprised of Leveling up your Mage Knight, Learning new spells, learning advanced actions, getting a lot of artifacts & some units that you will use in the city conquests! 

Those 2 cities (playing the Solo Conquest) are difficult & should not be done prematurely! But, you only have 6 rounds to do it, so doing it efficiently & effectively are crucial!

Overall, every game will play differently, whether you are playing alone or with some friends. A typical game will run about 2-4 hours easily, but you are so involved within the game, you wouldn't even believe where the time has gone to!

RATING: 8.5
Vlada is probably the most versatile game designer around. I'd say his games are either "the beer & pretzel type of games with upraised demands","the ameritrash sort of games with micromanagement elements" or they belong to a third category - that category is reserved to the games where you can't really make up your mind which one of the two previous categories the game would fit into best. That's how I feel about Mage Knight, because it's got so much going for it. 

On one side it's got flavor all over the place ( Magic in elusive or in stored form, Artefacts, levying units, sites (dungeons, ruins, keeps, etc.), exploring, miniatures, atmospheric artwork, Pillaging, Plundering, Spells, day and night differentiation...
On the other side there's the optimisation in terms of which mana to get from the source or which cards to play sideways for best effect. Things to go through in your head over and over, slightly altered to figure out what works best. 

There's two things I didn't like so much, which would be:
-there can be quite some downtime
-  you can have pretty bad luck with exploration

And did I hear people complaining about a lack of interaction? Why? I really must me be misled with my parameters for interaction.
Sometimes people sing in praise about the interactive ways a game has. And they won't hesitate to tell you that the superior interaction lies within this: Someone on a turn previous to you drew a card from the table. And this new constellation of cards- being that there's one less to choose from - is what they will call interaction. 
Really, if one can't see the interaction in this game, you wouldn't spot interaction if it was a 500-feet Godzilla. A 500 feet Godzilla that's alread grabbed you and holds you close to his face for you to see.

RATING: 3
Adventurous magical warriors wander a newly discovered land, fighting monsters, exploring ruins, influencing factions and recruiting heroes, and conquering enemy cities. The core of the game is using a deck-building mechanic to generate resources like movement, strength, defense, mana, and influence to take actions across the board.

RATING: 4
As a general rule with board games, my tastes break towards "The more complex, the better". Mage Knight is an excellent demonstration there are exceptions to every rule. It plays like a Legendary style deck builder combined with an adventure sim like Runebound, mixed in with aspects unique to either... and is somehow even more complicated than that sounds while capturing the fun of none of the above. Rinse and repeat till your arbitrary goal is met, add up points, that's the game. Victory feels hollow, defeat almost a relief as it means you can stop playing. Compared to a game like Hero Realms or Xenoshyft, there's just no context... this may have a plethora of added mechanics, but they do anything but make it interesting.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A phenomenal game.  This game fits perfectly into the dungeon-crawler genre for me.  I usually don't have the patience for the playtime or mechanical lightness of something like Descent, or a tabletop RPG, and I don't really miss the loss of an explicit narrative.

One thing that Mage Knight does better than any other game is impart a sense of character progression.  The additions to your deck, skills and stats happen very incrementally, and so almost without realizing it you become much much more powerful.  Enemies that would have been too powerful to take on alone at the start of the game are suddenly manageable in groups of 3-4 (with a little clever planning).

The game suffers a bit from analysis paralysis, which somehow manages to be both mitigated and exacerbated by the rulebook's explicit allowance of winding back a turn and replaying it provided no hidden information has been revealed.  On balance, however, this rule makes the game a LOT more playable and overall lowers the level of AP.  As with many games like this, having one player substantially slower than the others has a compounding effect, because the other players will complete their turns that much more quickly (having had the slow player's turn to do their planning as well).  I don't recommend playing with more than one new player at a time, if possible.

Includes Lost Legion, Shades of Tezla, and Krang expansions.

RATING: 7.5
2/4/2012 - I need a few more plays under my belt before I give it a proper review, but after one play it has the potential to be a one of my favorites!

::UPDATE::

3/29/12 - I'm conflicted. I know there is a brilliantly-designed game here. I know there is an adventure game that is more than just moving around and getting lucky or unlucky. I know there is a lot of variety. I know there is a great mix of mechanics throughout. Yet I really struggle with the game's pace. Perhaps it's the rules. Perhaps it's the set-up time. Perhaps it's the slow deck play and deck build. I'm not sure. But after my second play, I felt like I had been to a long day at work. I just wanted to go to bed because I was so tired and spent from working through such an incredibly heavy task.

Maybe I'll give it another shot or two in a multi-player situation, and with people who know the rules well. But for now, I'm starting to think it might be the first game by Vlaada that will get traded away. I'll have no problem finding willing traders, btw. It's currently between print runs and in high demand.

::UPDATE::

12/1/12 - I'm putting it up for trade and dropping my rating to a 7.5. After three plays, I've decided the slow pace, multitude of slightly-different rules for every type of terrain feature, and the infrequency with which I play it means it's taking up precious space on my shelf.

RATING: 8
An very enjoyable experience, and that means a lot considering I dislike fantasy settings. 

Interesting hand management element makes combat luckless, the components are amazing and the game really immerses. Background story also adds to the theme. The game works extremelly well mechanics wise, and manages to combine the best of the two worlds - strategy and theme. There is great depth here, extremelly tough decisions, an amazing progress arc with rpg elements, amazing variability and replayability... the game shines in almost every aspect a gamer would like it to.

So, any cons? Your campaign progress is still luck dependant due to the luck of the draw and exploration. The character progression is over just as it pays up, which half the time feels a little too short. It's a multihour experience, but that is really a design choice. Yet the major flaw is this game almost is multiplayer solitaire, no matter what mode you play in. In competitive mode the only thing you need to do is pay attention for the bonus scoring at the end of the game (which is not enough to make that much of a difference), and in cooperative mode you don't really plan anything as a team.

All in all, I'd like to play again, despite the fantasy theme and the lacking interaction -  it's that deep and immersive.

RATING: 10
What I like:

-Very interesting and original mix of mechanics that just somehow blend together seamlessly. Deck-building, exploration, dice, different card mechanics to name a few. It works really well. 
-Great brain teaser! You really get to exercise the grey matter with this one.
-The board and miniatures look really cool as you explore throughout the ever-changing landscape. 
-Absolutely the best solitaire experience in any board game bar none. I have yet to hear from someone who plays games alone who does not have this as their favorite. 
-Cool and well-done fantasy theme. 
Amazing replay value with all the things that change every game, the different scenarios and different characters that are very unique from each other.  

What I do not like:

-The rules to this are ridiculous! I have always insisted on playing by the rules and so I have spent 20-30 hours reading the 3 different manuals (with the expansion one) and the FAQ's and forum disscussions. Yes, it's that complex if you want to do it correctly.
-Game length. This games takes forever and may the lord have mercy upon your soul if you accidently get into a 4 player adventure. This is going to take alll day regardless of scenario. Actually i have only ever played it 3 players one time, and this was the absolute limit for me. After having played this game over 50 times I was able to complete the full solo experience in "Just" 3 hours. 
-The card quality could be a little better (then again, most folks are probably not gonna play 50-100 games of this like me ;) )

In summary: My absolut favorite solitaire game, works great with 2 also. Very long and complex but it's so worth once you have invested the time into learning it.

RATING: 9
This one was tough to get my head around.  I read the rules, read them again, watched youtube videos of people teaching how to play, then played the walkthrough scenario a few times, referred to the rules a few times.

Anyway! this game is really interesting, when I was looking around i read a review that likened this to sort of a Gandalf simulator.  I think that statement is pretty much bang on the money.

You step through a portal (start of the game) and proceed to interact with locals (to recruit armies), learn new spells, gain new artefacts, learn new advanced techniques, move about the land, kill monsters and all through your hand of cards.

It comes across as a clever game, a really clever one.  This is a game i'm definitely keeping, it's got a lot of replay value, it's deep, I can play it solo (all my games have been solo so far, I don't think my mates will get past the rules).  That's probably the only downside, the rules made it tough for me to just pick it up and start playing but once i got through them and played the walkthrough enough to get them to stick in my head, it becomes pretty awesome.  

I was unsure for a while but i'm really glad I stuck with it.  Looking forward to expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Quite simply one of the best fantasy games around offering a wealth of flexibility: solo, co-op, competitive and PvP all catered for. This is not a game like Dungeons and Dragons because of the competitive element in each scenario - whilst you can play friendly there is a final scoring system, which brings in a strategy element.

The rules are well written and examples helpful but it will likely take you a few plays to get your head around it all and ensure you're playing correctly; I would highly recommend watching a (solo) game on Youtube for clarity. The map and different scenarios allow a lot of variety meaning it is never the same game twice and there are optional rules that you can adopt to change the playstyle/difficulty.

I believe many reviewers have talked about significant downtime. The game is a major time investment requiring a great deal of set-up and (frequent) consultation of the rules; presently our group is at 45-60 minutes per round, of which there are usually 3-6 of in one game, however, I believe we are beginning to speed up as we become more familiar with the game and the rules of each scenario. Turns are not always straight forward and you really have to think how best to use your actions, which frequently involves reviewing the end result; our group has, so far, found the task of problem solving other players' turns rather fun. I think the designers have done what they can to reduce downtime but it does require someone to keep the game rolling.

Although the game is an investment of both finance and time, we have found it to be an addictive game of superior quality. Looking forward to the expansions.

RATING: 8
A big game, in many senses. Lots of physical components taking up a big table's worth of space and it takes a long time (for new players at least), but it also has a nicely large scope. A good sense of building from the nearly claustrophobic start to a wide open map. I want to play with PvP next time, since sometimes the "good spots" are taken by other players. I like how players can control how fast they want to go through the rounds, although you don't want to be much slower than the fastest player. Each turn is full of interesting decisions, since each hand can be used in so many ways. The game isn't without problems. Besides sometimes-significant downtime, there are almost too many rules, in that it's so easy to miss something in the sea of words and pictures. Not an easy game to learn, but once you're in, it flows nicely. Sort of like a fantasy combat Through the Ages.

RATING: 8
This is a hard game to rate. 

It's not an adventure game, yet there is adventuring. 
Its not a deck building game, yet I get a deck I can (semi) customize. 

Rather it's really a hand management puzzle solving game. 

Incredibly frustrating, as you spend most of the time trying to solve the least worst turn you can have given the cards you were dealt. 

However you can tell the game is very well designed. Virtually no rules ambiguities despite the complexity of the game, and a lot of the mechanics (especially wounds) are very well done. 

Going with an 8 after 1 learning game and 2 actual games. Can see it going up or down depending on future plays.

RATING: 7
Initial rating. 

This game has lots of stuff going on. Some of it is very cool! I really like how the leveling up works by building up your deck and learning new skills. The game has good progression all the way - characters and enemies get better etc.

I am partial for the puzzle type combat. It reminds a lot of what Dungeon Lords has (although there you can do it simultaneously, I think). This creates a lot of downtime and I don't think it feels too exciting or rewarding to slash the enemies as it could be. I think also that the combat is perhaps just a bit too complicated for my tastes. Learning all the special skills and powers is huge commitment and it is easy to play something wrong.

I'm not sure if I really like the how the round structure works (day and night cycles + playing until the deck is exhausted + and after one player announces the turn end). 

The game has nice theme, but it feels mostly like a solo-puzzle type game. Not that there is anything wrong with this type of games. Just don't expect too much direct interaction in the game.

RATING: 8
Update: Played quite a few full solo scenarios and I'll stick with my 8 for now. It's definitely a well-designed game with a lot of depth, but between the game length, setup time, table space, and demands on opponents, it's not going to be something I could play all the time. But I could easily see how certain players/groups could play the heck out of this thing and rate it higher.

I just purchased Mage Knight a couple days ago and have only played the walkthrough scenario once, but this is certainly going to be at least an 8 for me long term. It will completely replace several other adventure games that I keep around for occasional solo play.

It's clear that this game aspires to the "serious adventure game" niche once held solely by Magic Realm (amongst major games, at least), though just calling it a "modern version of MR" would be too loose to do justice to either game.

Despite many comments I've heard, the rules (in my copy purchased October 2012) seem quite clear and thoughtfully presented to me. There are a lot of them, for sure, but they seem both precise and thematically appropriate, which makes them easier to remember. Perhaps I'll feel differently after digging into the full scenarios, but I suspect otherwise. I feel good about these rules, whereas I'm generally very critical. Perhaps the designer is just a good match for my style of thinking.

I'll certainly update these brief comments in the future.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I simply don't understand how this game is on BGG's top ten. It's the worst of both worlds - like the worst Euros, it's a dull and un-interactive optimization puzzle ; like the worst thematic games, it's fiddly, full of arbitrary little rules, has busy visuals, and is overly reliant on chance. Furthermore, that chance seems to be in all the wrong places. You can answer the question "what will the outcome of my hero's battle with these orcs be?" with absolute certainty, but the question "will my hero be able to pick up his lazy feet and walk to the nearest village next turn?" is anyone's guess. This is the dreaded "roll to move" in card form - why don't people see this? Combat is sucked free of drama, while merely moving around is a frustrating endeavor. It is extremely easy to get screwed by poor draws, and there is no way to mitigate this possibility.

The deckbuilding element is minimal, a shoddy cash-in on the mechanic du jour. You get one measly advanced action card every other level. Want to get a spell card? Well, you'll have to find a mage tower, walk to it (provided you have enough movement cards), try to defeat the defenders (oops, you didn't have enough movement cards last turn, so you played your attack cards sideways for one movement point each), then spend 7 influence points to get a spell card (which means you have to spend two cards at the very least, provided you drew influence cards this turn.) Walking to the tower probably took one turn, defeating the defenders took another, and gaining the spell took yet another turn. Meanwhile you're eating through your deck at an alarming pace trying to accomplish all these things, so that by the time you've gained your lonesome spell card, the better part of a round (you get six in most scenarios) is gone. 

John Sizemore's review pretty much sums up my problems with the game. "An adventure game with no surprises." 

http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/800679/an-adventure-game-with-no-surprises-a-negative-rev

RATING: 10
Foreword: I have logged about 10-15 games so far, without any competitive play.
Mage Knight is not a game for people with short attention span. It may also appear somewhat random if you don't understand the game mechanics very well. Also please don't except a deckbuilder at the game's core. 
If you however make it past the long and somewhat tedious rulebook (which redeems its tediousness by having very precise and well defined rules for later reference) and a few misconceptions regarding possible expectations for an epic fantasy exploration game, Mage Knight unfolds an unrivaled epic marathon of turn-by-turn optimization and puzzle solving. The feeling of accomplishment after a successful city assault, knowing how much thought and hard work was required to do so, simply can not be beaten by any other co-op game for me.

RATING: 2
I did not enjoy this game. However, there are a couple caveats:

1) I bought this game specifically for solo play. I have not played it multiplayer.

2) After trying other solo play games and not enjoying them too much, I thought I'd try Make Knight because it's the consensus #1 solo game out there. After not enjoying Mage Knight, I'm sure it's partially because I don't personally enjoy solo gaming. I will play a game solitaire on occasion, but I much prefer Lord of the Rings LCG, or even games not designed for solo play but which have theme and mechanics that I really enjoy. 

I like the fantasy theme, but I am really not a fan of the mechanics in this game.

I would never play this game multiplayer. It's just too complex and....how do it put this....not fun.

So if you like solo gaming, I do think this game is worth a try. For me personally though, I just don't find a solitaire solve-the-puzzle type experience very fun. 

I don't plan to ever play this game again.

RATING: 10
PERMANENT PLACE IN COLLECTION, EXTENDING INTO THE HEREAFTER. OUR FAVOURITE GAME OF ALL TIME. EVER AND FOREVER.

Simply perfect. Play cooperatively or competitively. Play a short game or a longer one. Play alone. With two players or more.

Thematically strong. You can almost feel yourself exploring a strange land looking for cities to attack. The fantasy setting is a bit generic, but that's not a problem.

Huge numbers of tactical options for spells to buy, fighting units to recruit, and ways to play. You can choose to attack monasteries and be a bad guy (who finds it harder to buy stuff at settlements). Or fight orcs and attract the admiration of villagers (making stuff cheaper to purchase in towns).

Whether or not you like fantasy, it's an amazing game. A must buy. I can't see anyone becoming bored with this ever. It's incredible.

RATING: 6
I own Mage Knight, and have played it mostly solo, and once with two player co-operative with the Lost Legion Expansion.  I rated the game a six because I find the game length to be too long, the rules to be too fiddly and confused, and the combat to be unsatisfying.  But, these are simply the drawbacks to an otherwise very impressive game.  I have chosen to focus on the negative because this game is not for me.  My main criticism is with the combat.  For me, there is no sense of accomplishment upon having defeated a bad guy.  

This game does retain it's value well.  I purchased it for $50 on Amazon with free shipping, and was able to re-sell it at a board game convention for $40 after a few months and a good number of solo play troughs.  I certainly got my monies worth and I think you will too.  But, just not the game for me.

RATING: 7
Wonderfully thematic fantasy adventure game. There are many complex decisions to be made, but the gameplay in itself is not that complicated. The mechanics are strong and the game flows beautifully along as you explore, fight and conquer. It manages to be an adventure game while also being a puzzler. You can play Mage Knight with several players, but for me it's a game I prefer to play solitaire. I really like the components. Beautiful pre-painted miniatures, custom dice, solid map tiles, nice little crystals and of course the HeroClix city minis. The cards needed sleeving, but this is not a problem at all as I would have sleeved regardless of card quality.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Vladda has released another masterpiece. I have no idea how he continues to put out game after game that completely breaks the mold of traditional designs, but he continues to innovate in every game genre he tackles. Here he has created a fantasy adventure game in the vein of Runebound or Talisman but with a deck building mechanism that turns the usual character growth system on its ear. The game is also ridiculously complicated, yet the rules are so intuitive that it really isn't hard to keep them straight. Even the little exceptions that spring up from time to time are so logically presented that it is fairly easy to remember them without even opening up the rulebook.

My only real criticism is that I could do without the Mage Knight license. The game was clearly NOT designed around the old miniatures game, as the story presented in the game's introduction has almost nothing to do with what has come before in Mage Knight fiction. The day and night mechanics as well as the concept of mana to drive spell casting are also completely alien to the Mage Knight setting. It smells like a retro-fit and I'm still not completely sold on that aspect of it. Tying the game to that license seems a little counter-intuitive, especially when the game does such a nice job of separating itself from every other fantasy game on the market. Hopefully the Mage Knight tie-in doesn't limit it's appeal to fans of heavier games, because this one has what it takes to be an all-time great.

Not fair to rate this, since I had to stop partway through the session, but it was heading for about a 4.

This reminded me a lot of a jRPG video game: there were tons of little fiddly things to keep track of that weren't really all that interesting, and the gameplay just isn't compelling enough to fill out the long playtime unless you're engaged with your character. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Mage Knight is a beast. Although I haven't grasped all the tiny little rule details yet, after a few plays I can definitely tell that this is a brilliant, one of a kind game. High learning curve though - you have to play it all the time in order to feel comfortable with the rules.

The downside is the length of the game and the fact that it gets a bit too repetitive. After 3 or 4 hours of non-stop moving from point A to point B and killing monsters I tend to lose interest in what's going on. And I can't imagine playing this game with 3 or 4 players - the downtime would be unbearable. 

Also, it's not that uncommon that you get a hand of cards without any movement points - if this happens, all you do in your turn is struggle with moving even to an adjacent space. Instead of focusing on cool stuff, you just keep solving the movement puzzle. And don't get me wrong - it can be fun, but only in small doses... Doing that over and over again can be rather dull.

Mage Knight has some amazing mechanisms and I really understand the love it gets, but since some things about this design really bother me I can't give it my top rating...

Got my first play in recently.  I can tell this is going to be a game I will really get in to.  It has adventure, exploration, and tension.  You level up, increase your skills and grow as a hero.  It is very rules-heavy, but the walk through is great and there are a few excellent tutorial videos online.  

Update as of 2/16/15:  I love this game.  at this point, I have exactly 17 plays and I dig this game so much.  Some times, I think, "ug, do I want to go through the hassle of setting this game up to play it?" and the answer is always "absolutely!"  This game is well worth the time and effort.  Its like one big optimization puzzle, and with some imagination it can be a very immersive game.  I know it is not for everyone, but any solo gamer, D&D player, or adventure seeker should at least check it out. 

Update as of 3/12/17: Wow.  I just played my first game of the Volkare's Return scenario for my 40th play.  I got slaughtered.  It was not even close.  He sacked the unconquered city half way through the second day.  This will be a steeper learning curve than the base game!

Update as of 12/24/17: 49th play. 3rd Lost Legion play. 1st win. Of course, it was on the easiest of the easiest setting...but still!

RATING: 9.5
I'm rating it a 9.5 after three long solo sessions, the game just keeps getting better with each play.  

There is enough complexity and depth in the game play to keep things interesting as a solo game.  I'll be playing with another player soon and I expect the game to be even better with two players.

The deck building mechanic does a good job of simulating character growth over time.  Add in artifacts to loot, spells to buy, allies to recruit, new abilities cards and skill tokens per level and you get characters that start the game the same but end the game vastly different.  

There are monster dens to clear out, dungeons to raid, ruins to explore, keeps and mage towers to siege, cities to conquer, villages to plunder, and monastaries to burn.  The game also tracks your allignment through out the game.  You can be evil and burn monastaries for their rare artifacts or good which makes it easier for you to recruit new and powerful allies.

All in all this is a great game and I look forward to many expansions in the near future.

RATING: 9
This game is epic is almost every sense of the word, and it has certainly earned its place as one of the best solo games ever created.   It creates a big adventure for you every game, and only through clever card play do you make it through successfully.   The artwork is great and the game comes packed with stuff, including miniatures that are of similar quality to the ones the [i]old[/i] Mage Knight games were known for.   There are a whole bunch of different scenarios each with a ton of variability within them, so you'll always be facing something new each time you play.


On the downside, this can be an epic brain-burner too, with many turns where you spend several minutes just staring at your cards trying to figure out how best to get where you want to go and do what you want to do as efficiently as possible.   I suspect that downtime with just two players would be significant, and with three or four would be unbearable even when everyone did know what they were doing, much less with anyone new.    There are TONS of pieces to this game and everything has its own unique rules, so unless you're playing this several times per week you're going to be spending a lot of time checking the rules and reference sheets to check how things are meant to work.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I gave it a second play because the first one left me ambivalent, I'm a big fan of a lot of Chvatil's games, and this one is both visually and thematically attractive to me.  The second play convinced me that I probably don't need to play this again.

There is a complete disconnect between theme and mechanics.  Each turn is a puzzle on how you'll do something good with the cards in your hand, but it doesn't make sense that something as basic as, for example, moving from place to place is so constrained in an adventure/exploration game.  Movement costs are high so moving around the board takes a long time if you don't clear things out in sequence.  There's very little to do on an opponent's turn because you need to see how the mana dice are going to come up in order to plan.  

Combat feels very generic--each time trying to total things up to get just the right number of range attack, block, or attack to defeat the monster.  Repeated number crunching to get things to work out just right gets old fast.  And I'm a mathematician.

Character advancement comes from a relatively small number of skill tiles that you can acquire during the game, new spell, skill, and artifact cards that you add to your deck, and followers that join you.  But the cards come into your hand at random (of course) so your new spells or abilities won't necessarily be there when you need them.  Your followers, while always available, can only be used once per day or night and they take up a precious turn to acquire.

Which brings up another problem:  you actually only get a small number of turns over the whole game, I'm guessing 4 to 6 turns per day or night (each day or night is called a round) with a game lasting 4 to 6 rounds.  Now there can't really be more turns in the game because each individual turn drags so much, but that still doesn't leave many opportunities to actually do something.

The whole thing just feels like an exhausting exercise rather than an fantasy adventure.

Tedious.

RATING: 7
2015/2/15: Played the intro scenario with Schrope. Woof. Quite the beast of a game; lots of smaller mechanisms dancing around creating a much large machine. Once you get to grips with all the intricacies of each mechanism (combat, moving, card/deck manipulation, etc. etc. etc.), things start to fall together.

I'm not entirely certain how heavy a game it is; it might just need a better fucking rule book. As is, it makes sense but it's like trying to read a tech manual: 'See page 342 for information on DRAWING Cards' 'See page 107 on DISCARDING cards.' 'For information on when to DRAW or DISCARD cards, see table 4b on page 44.' It's an endless sprawl of references, or in the worst cases, no references on how to complete a given action/task within the game. So you spend half the time searching for key words or unrelated sections to find an answer to your rules question.

A few parts are still ambiguous and will require further play or a FAQ. Overall though, I enjoy what the game does and how it does it. I seek further plays to cement an opinion.

RATING: 9.25
This is the game that started it all for me back in 2012.

For a game that truly love, I haven't even begun to scratch the surface of it. I have played the Full Conquest scenario with 2 players, the walk-through of this game solo, with 3 players and with 4 players. The walkthrough is a great way to get your feet wet but it doesn't really shine until you start playing the scenarios... and with respect to that... I've only played one of the 9 (?) included scenarios.

To this day, I haven't played a game that comes close to combining so many different things in such unique ways. It's as much a brain-burning puzzle as it is an epic fantasy exploration and combat game. There is so much going on and so many tough decisions to make on every turn. How you can use the cards in so many ways is amazing, and the fact that they act as the round timer make you agonize about how to optimize every single action. That leads me to my next point...

Overall, I think that this game is amazing as a solo game and great with 2 players. However, once you get over 2 players, you need to be ready for a very long game unless the people are experienced and don't take a ton of time with their turns. The nature of the game and its mechanics leads to AP. I do think that this would decrease dramatically as the players became more used to the game and its mechanics but the fact that it's such a heavy and time (and space) consuming game... that becomes a very difficult obstacle to overcome.

I believe that this will remain a game that sees limited plays over the years and is something that I'd end up playing more solo than with a group of people. It's unfortunate that such an amazing game will forever be caught in a cycle of gathering dust only to be brushed of once in a blue moon but I guess that's the nature of the beast and where I currently am in the stage of my life.

RATING: 10
Own with Lost Legion. I love this game. I play Solo and I bend a few rules to turn it into an (easier) open world RPG with no time limit and leave it on the table and play through out the week. I start with a standard Volkaire start on a big table. As I get to the sides, I just keep adding tiles and exploring and if I run out then I pick up one of three of the tiles furthest away and shuffle them. Once I get to the max level, I go back to 0 and use the better Units. Every day that passes, Volkaire ticks up one level. Game is over when I defeat Volkaire so it can be a shorter game if I choose. It's so immersive and unlike anything else I've played. Great for inspiring writing and great for avoiding writing! It really does capture the theme for me. It's a wonderful game

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a highly thematic, very fiddly, adventure game with a side order of deckbuilding. The first couple games I played of this I wasn't enamored because I felt like I got stuck being unable to do what I wanted to on a given turn.

As you acclimatize to the game, however, it becomes pretty amazing. You need to get used to the scarcity of your various pure action cards (move, attack, block, and influence) and learn when to hold and have a subpar turn rather than just playing your entire hand sideways for the immediate need. Once you get to that point, Mage Knight completely opens up.

I love the feeling that the game evokes as you advance in levels - you gain new abilities, more cards, minions, and stats. It does an amazing job of capturing your character's power growing.

RATING: 10
Colosal. Pídele y te será concedido. Un juego en formato Scope, necesitarás mesa. Hay quien dice que las partidas a un buen wargame son memorables y se recuerdan siempre, mientras que las de un euro no. Con Mage Knight cualquier prejuicio o complejo al comparar euros con wargames queda completamente disipada. Después de catarlo el resto de tu colección brillará un poco menos. Toda una revelación.
--------------------------------------------------

Posiblemente sea mi solitario favorito. 

Precioso a todas luces. Descubre nuevos horizontes, enfréntate a todo aquello que sea tan ingenuo como para desafiarte. 

Que tu nombre se esparza por llanuras y haga retumbar las montañas hasta sus raíces. Empezarás sólo y terminarás al mando de legiones, serás leyenda.

Toda una experiencia.

Actualización:

Empiezas sólo y tienes ante ti tierras, montañas y tras estos anchos horizontes por explorar. Es de día y empiezas avanzando arrogante hacia una colina donde unos orcos tienen su tribu. En el combate se tiene la posibilidad primero de asediar o hacer una ataque a distancia con la idea de aniquilar al enemigo antes de que te pongan la mano encima. 

Con altivez le dices al orco más grande que "pegue". Me salto aquí todo el tema de los rasgos especiales que alteran, dan variedad y caracterizan maravillosamente cada bicho, mago, criatura, dragón, etc...

El orco golpea y tu armadura trata de absorver el daño- ya coges una carta con esa gotita de sangre tan chula en el centro- . Si no lo reduces a cero vuelves a aplicar tu índice de armadura para absorver el excedente adquiriendo una nueva carta de sangre. Estas cartas se te acumulan en la mano y MOLESTAN. No puedes deshacerte de ellas a menos que te cures y si no lo has hecho para cuando te toca descartar y remezclar tu mazo como cuando el día o la noche termina tu baraja se te queda sucia de sangre y volverán a salir cuando robes. Fantástico. 

El orco deja de sonreír cuando ve que tú también te ríes. Entonces te toca a TI. Usas tus cartas para atacar para acumular una cifra que iguale o supere la armadura del orco. Y muerto. Los destrozas y empiezan a correr rumores de un extraño ser que ha surgido de un portal y que no se sabe muy bien a qué viene. Ganas fama y prestigio.

Te acercas a una aldea cercana y puedes gastar tus cartas para curarte de tus heridas o reclutar más o menos amablemente a los que te seguirán en la búsqueda de no se sabe qué castillo. O también puedes saquear a los aldeanos  De ahí a asaltar fuertes, monasterios, ciudades; por el camino mazmorras, ruinas que encierran tesoros o prisoneros que se unirán a tu causa- sin importarles si es buena o mala-, tomando y dominando siniestras torres controladas por hechiceros de las que luego te podrás servir para reclutar; obtendrás anillos mágicos, alzarás poderosos estandartes.  

Y cuando vuelvas a pelear ya no lo harás sólo. Les dirás a tus guerrero cuándo, cómo y dónde golpear. Con los cristales de maná que guardes con codicia en el bolsillo y absorviendo los vientos de magia que soplen tanto por el día como por la noche potenciarás los efectos que desees de tus cartas e incluso de tus propias criaturas.

Tus soldados caeran rendidos de cansancio una vez los uses para lo que sea en cada jornada, pero tú no, porque tú eres un héroe y los héroes no duermen de noche. Errarás sin cesar con los ojos abiertos, azuzando a tu hueste con tus gruñidos. Tu poder crecerá sin cesar hasta que seas capaz de desintegrar de un sólo golpe incluso a un dragón. 

Y aunque no lo he probado, pues lo mío hasta ahora ha sido sólo un coqueteo con el juego, lo único que tal vez más debe infundir intranquilidad en tu mago-guerrero es que no está sólo en su búsqueda, hay otros como él que arrastran tras de sí por las llanuras todo tipo de criaturas temibles. A tus oído también llegan sus gestas y los horrores que han provocado, la fama de aquellos también crece. Y cuando te topes con ellos tal vez colaboréis por ejemplo para asaltar una inexpugnable ciudad o no.

Ocupa mucha mesa incluso jugando en solitario. El reglamento requiere una digestión lenta. Hay mucho contenido en él, muchas modos de juego distintos. Yo por ahora lo pondría en dificultad a la altura de Through the Ages. 

Nota: Ojito con pecar de confianza. 

Turno uno. Desde el portal veo un chamán orco cogiendo margaritas en un prado. Miro mis cartas y empiezo: digo, psé, llevo lo justo para llevarle al otro barrio. Asumiré las heridas sin una queja. 

Me muevo a su alrededor para llamar su atención cuál espontáneo impala frente a un hambriento guepardo. El sorprendido chamán aprovecha sus margaritas para invocar a un bravo minotauro llamado Ratón cuyo talante es de nivel cinco.

No puedo bloquearlo. Como tiene fuerza brutal el daño se duplica coincidiendo con el número de costillas que me parte. Me chupo cinco cartas de sangre en la mano y encima me noquea haciendo que me descarte de todas las cartas que llevo, y dejando mi mazo en pulpa y a carne viva. 

Luego el chamán sigue con sus margaritas...

RATING: 9.5
I think this is the best solo gameplay boardgame. It has the same puzzle element as ghost stories but with a more epic feeling. It is also a very harsh and unforgiving game although you can adjust the level of difficulty. This is a game that builds up. You don't need all the rules in the first turn. You can gradually experience and learn the game. Although you'll probably not win your first games, since you need the knowledge of rules to evaluate the pieces and situations. 

There's a great deal of evaluating going on during play. Each turn you must evaluate everything from the cards in hand, to cards you could buy, to routes you will follow, units you bought or can buy, the mana that you'll pick etc. 

Since there is a lot of this kind of thinking involved, in a non solo game this can cause a lot of downtime. I would not play it with 3 or 4, but 2 seems fine. It takes some time to figure out all the rules, but in the end it is worth it.
